headline: The First Afterlife of Pope Benedict XVI
abstract: Pope Benedict’s legacy will be felt across decades or even centuries.
lead_paragraph: The first pope to resign was Celestine V, born Pietro Da Morrone, who was living the life of a pious hermit when he was elevated to the papacy in 1294, in his 80s, to break a two-year deadlock in the College of Cardinals. Feeling overmastered by the job, he soon resigned in the expectation that he could return to his monastic existence. Instead, he was imprisoned by his successor, Boniface VIII, who feared that some rival faction might make Celestine an antipope.
snippet: Pope Benedict’s legacy will be felt across decades or even centuries.

headline: Why India and China Are Fighting in the Himalayas
abstract: The countries share a volatile disputed border that is not marked on a map.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On a freezing December day on a remote Himalayan mountain ridge, Indian and Chinese soldiers fought with sticks, stones, clubs and bare fists. Scores were bloodied and injured. The incident, according to the Indian authorities, occurred on Dec. 9, when about 300 soldiers from the People’s Liberation Army of China attempted to occupy Yangtse, a mountainous border post on the disputed India-China border in the Tawang area in northeastern India.
snippet: The countries share a volatile disputed border that is not marked on a map.

headline: Forget the Beach Bod. Try These Soul Resolutions Instead.
abstract: New Year’s habits that are good for the soul.
lead_paragraph: I never know how to think about New Year’s resolutions or whether to make them. On one hand, I am drawn to the idea of new beginnings. I love the intentionality and thoughtfulness that are required to make a resolution. They force me to reflect on what I long for, what the good life might consist of and how to get there, which is a good exercise for all of us at any time.
snippet: New Year’s habits that are good for the soul.

headline: There Has Never Been a Better Time to Be Short
abstract: Short people don’t just save resources; as resources become scarcer owing to overpopulation and global warming, they may also be best suited for long-term survival.
lead_paragraph: From where I stand — at five feet even — being tall is a widely held fantasy of superiority that long ago should have been retired.
snippet: Short people don’t just save resources; as resources become scarcer owing to overpopulation and global warming, they may also be best suited for long-term survival.

headline: Putin Has No Red Lines
abstract: There are better ways to think about strategy.
lead_paragraph: “What are Putin’s red lines?”
snippet: There are better ways to think about strategy.

headline: A Failed Speaker Vote for Kevin McCarthy Would Be a Historic Event
abstract: A small group of Republicans has promised to vote against Kevin McCarthy this week. They could throw the House into chaos not seen for a century.
lead_paragraph: News update: On Tuesday, Representative Kevin McCarthy of California fell short in his bid to become speaker of the House. The House is set to reconvene Wednesday to continue the election process.
snippet: A small group of Republicans has promised to vote against Kevin McCarthy this week. They could throw the House into chaos not seen for a century.

headline: I Know What Savage Fear Really Lies at the Heart of the American Dream
abstract: It’s the fear of failure.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a book in praise of failure, which is like a fish praising water. I’ve been swimming in failure for as long as I can remember — even before that. Quite a lot of who we are, what we do and especially what we cannot do is determined well before we are born, by history, geography, the rise and fall of empires, that farcical god we call luck. I came into this world with failure in my blood and bones. Sometimes I wonder if there is anything else there.
snippet: It’s the fear of failure.

headline: A Chorus of Hopes for 2023
abstract: A mayor, a veteran and others share their visions for the coming year.
lead_paragraph: I outsourced my first newsletter of 2023. I asked a variety of people, from many walks of life, both from the United States and abroad, to share their hopes for the new year. The results were so fascinating that I’m thinking of making this into an annual feature. Here’s what people wrote (or, in one case, said).
snippet: A mayor, a veteran and others share their visions for the coming year.

headline: Dare to Survive
abstract: I came to document Tracy McCarter’s experiences in court because I wanted to see how the criminal justice system works.
lead_paragraph: In 2021 the New York City Mayor’s Office to End Domestic and Gender-Based Violence commissioned me to create a public art piece about the criminalization of survivors. I’ve dedicated my life as a photographer to documenting domestic violence.
snippet: I came to document Tracy McCarter’s experiences in court because I wanted to see how the criminal justice system works.

headline: We’re Going to Miss Greed and Cynicism
abstract: We’ll be nostalgic for the days when the culture war was phony.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2023. What will the new year bring? The answer, of course, is that we don’t know. There are a fair number of what Donald Rumsfeld (remember him?) called “known unknowns” — for example, nobody really knows how hard it will be to reduce inflation or whether the U.S. economy will experience a recession. There are also unknown unknowns: Will we see another shock like Russia’s invasion of Ukraine?
snippet: We’ll be nostalgic for the days when the culture war was phony.

headline: I May Have Started a Rumor About K-Pop, and It May Be Ruining My Life
abstract: I wrote a book about Korean pop culture, and that’s when things started to get crazy.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean boy band BTS has been low-key ruining my life for years.
snippet: I wrote a book about Korean pop culture, and that’s when things started to get crazy.

headline: The Key to Success in College Is So Simple, It’s Almost Never Mentioned
abstract: Students must be willing to learn.
lead_paragraph: For Emily Zurek Small, college did what it’s supposed to do. Growing up in a small town in northeastern Pennsylvania, she had career and intellectual ambitions for which college is the clearest pathway. “I just kind of always wanted to learn,” she told me recently. “I wanted to be able to have intelligent conversations with people and know about the world.”
snippet: Students must be willing to learn.

headline: A Con Man Is Succeeding Me in Congress Today
abstract: Now we know that no one voted for the real George Santos.
lead_paragraph: Today is my last day as a member of Congress, and George Santos is about to be sworn in to take the seat I held for six years. He will take an oath to “bear true faith” to the Constitution and take this obligation without any “purpose of evasion.” I’ve lost track of how many evasions and lies Mr. Santos has told about himself, his finances and his history and relationship with our stretch of Long Island and northeastern Queens. When he is seated, it will diminish our Congress, our country and my constituents — soon his constituents. It saddens me that after 30 years of public service rooted in hard work and service to the people of this area, I’m being succeeded by a con man.
snippet: Now we know that no one voted for the real George Santos.

headline: Sabbath and the Art of Rest
abstract: Judith Shulevitz shares the wisdom of the Sabbath and its offering to a modern world that struggles to unplug.
lead_paragraph: Do we know how to truly rest? Who would we be if we did?
snippet: Judith Shulevitz shares the wisdom of the Sabbath and its offering to a modern world that struggles to unplug.

Jews and Judaism

headline: ‘Entire Body Is Shaking’: Why Americans With Chronic Pain Are Dying
abstract: American medicine and law enforcement continue to fight the last opioid war.
lead_paragraph: Anne Fuqua keeps a list of suicide deaths. She’s chronicled hundreds of cases of chronic pain sufferers who have killed themselves after losing access to opioid medication since 2014. Recently, she almost became an entry.
snippet: American medicine and law enforcement continue to fight the last opioid war.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Judith Shulevitz
abstract: The Jan. 3, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Judith Shulevitz. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Jan. 3, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: The Football Game Theory of Inflation
abstract: Are rising prices about monetary policy or about power? Yes.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t think of economists as party animals, you’re right. Or at least that’s the conclusion one might draw from the fact that several prominent economists carried on a thoughtful, earnest online debate about inflation over the past weekend — that is, on New Year’s Eve and the day after, when I thought we were supposed to be drinking champagne and then nursing hangovers.
snippet: Are rising prices about monetary policy or about power? Yes.

headline: Why Saving Kids Is Bad Business in America
abstract: For hospitals, pediatrics isn’t as lucrative as adult health care — and we’ve been underinvesting in kids for decades.
lead_paragraph: It’s happening again. Hospital I.C.U.s are swamped with patients suffering from severe respiratory illnesses. Overworked doctors and nurses are scrambling to save lives. Another surge of infections, another national health crisis.
snippet: For hospitals, pediatrics isn’t as lucrative as adult health care — and we’ve been underinvesting in kids for decades.

author.Original: By Alexander Stockton and Lucy King

headline: As a Doctor, I See Aging Differently
abstract: Reflections on longevity.
lead_paragraph: When ‌‌doctors talk about patients in the hospital, we so often begin with age. A 75-year-old man with shortness of breath. A 30-year-old woman with joint swelling. Knowing our patients’ ages allows us to focus on the most likely diagnoses and to develop a mental image of the patient before we enter the room.
snippet: Reflections on longevity.

headline: Why Did George Santos Lie About Being Jewish?
abstract: The curious case of the philosemitic fabulist.
lead_paragraph: I know I should be horrified by the revelations about George Santos, the representative-elect from Queens who seems to have embellished or invented everything about himself except his name. But truth be told, I can’t get enough of this guy.
snippet: The curious case of the philosemitic fabulist.

headline: My Daughter Expects to Work. Will She Make Only $3.35 an Hour?
abstract: We need to consider how we can more effectively support people with disabilities in the mainstream work force.
lead_paragraph: My daughter expects to work. When she was about 5 years old, one of her favorite bath time activities was playing with a set of cups that she would fill up carefully and place on the edge of the tub. “Mo-ka-ma-KE!” she called out. She was imagining she was a barista, a job she had seen performed hundreds of times at the coffee shop.
snippet: We need to consider how we can more effectively support people with disabilities in the mainstream work force.

headline: The Hour Between Babe and Hag
abstract: If you’re a woman, you get about 10 years to be taken seriously at work.
lead_paragraph: I had never heard of Sam Bankman-Fried until his disheveled image began to dominate my news feeds in November — probably because whenever someone says “crypto” or “blockchain,” my eyes glaze over, and I enter a fugue state. Most photos I’ve seen of this 30-year-old man — accused of orchestrating a massive, yearslong fraud through his cryptocurrency exchange, FTX — depict him wearing ill-fitting T-shirts and shorts, sometimes with black sweat socks spilling out of his sneakers.
snippet: If you’re a woman, you get about 10 years to be taken seriously at work.

headline: 9 Pandemic Narratives We’re Getting Wrong
abstract: We’re replacing pandemic narratives of enormous complexity with just-so stories.
lead_paragraph: We are entering the fourth year of the pandemic, believe it or not: Freshmen are now seniors, toddlers now kindergartners and medical students now doctors. We’ve completed two American election cycles and one World Cup cycle. Army volunteers are nearing the end of their active-duty commitment. It’s been a long haul but in other ways a short jump: Three years is not so much time that it should be hard to clearly remember what happened. And yet it seems to me, on many important points our conventional pandemic history is already quite smudged.
snippet: We’re replacing pandemic narratives of enormous complexity with just-so stories.

headline: Workers Are Losing in the Inflation Battle
abstract: Pay increases in 2023 aren’t going to match the increase in prices over the past year.
lead_paragraph: Memo to staff: We highly value your work for us. However, we are not going to give you raises this year that are big enough to catch you up with inflation. We’re just doing what the Federal Reserve wants us to do.
snippet: Pay increases in 2023 aren’t going to match the increase in prices over the past year.

headline: Leopards Eat Kevin McCarthy’s Face
abstract: Selling his soul to Trump hasn’t worked out for the would-be speaker.
lead_paragraph: As we approach the anniversary of the Jan. 6 attack, it’s been grimly amusing to see that the party of insurrection can’t even manage the orderly transfer of power to itself. Rarely does karma play out so neatly.
snippet: Selling his soul to Trump hasn’t worked out for the would-be speaker.

headline: What Will Republicans Do With Their House Majority?
abstract: The Democratic Party’s federal trifecta is ending. What comes next?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
snippet: The Democratic Party’s federal trifecta is ending. What comes next?

headline: The Burn-It-All-Down Republican Caucus
abstract: The party fringe is getting what it wants: more headlines, more spectacle and therefore more power.
lead_paragraph: Republicans keep reaping what they’ve sown.
snippet: The party fringe is getting what it wants: more headlines, more spectacle and therefore more power.

headline: America’s Covid Test Requirement for Chinese Travelers Is a Farce
abstract: The policy for Chinese travelers relies on racial bias rather than science.
lead_paragraph: When the Chinese government abruptly eased its draconian Covid-19 policies in December, I felt an uncanny combination of abject horror and relief. After three years of endless PCR tests and lockdowns — “zero Covid,” which has gripped China like a vise, was finally brought to a close. Overseas Chinese people like me will finally be able to more easily reunite with family and try to make up for lost time.
snippet: The policy for Chinese travelers relies on racial bias rather than science.

headline: I Chose to Compete as My True, Trans Self. I Win Less, but I Live More.
abstract: Living in authenticity makes me a better man.
lead_paragraph: The first time I remember feeling different from the people around me was in fourth grade. I felt like I’d been thrust onstage for a show without having been given a script. Every interaction seemed wrong. Recognizing my bisexuality in seventh grade gave me a degree of comfort, like a candle held out against dark confusion, but even then, so much of myself still felt impossible to discern.
snippet: Living in authenticity makes me a better man.

headline: The Veteran Outing Domestic Extremists
abstract: Veterans are valuable recruits for far-right groups. Kris Goldsmith wants them to fight back.
lead_paragraph: With domestic extremism on the rise in the United States, much attention has been given to the military veterans who join extremist groups. And for good reason; many of the leaders behind the Capitol riot on Jan. 6 were veterans. Kris Goldsmith is a veteran who joined the military after the Sept. 11 attacks. After returning from Iraq, he fell down antigovernment rabbit holes on the internet. Now he is an activist and researcher who ferrets out right-wing extremists online. And he’s developed an understanding of how and why veterans are recruited by such groups.
snippet: Veterans are valuable recruits for far-right groups. Kris Goldsmith wants them to fight back.

author.Original: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Olivia Natt, Stephanie Joyce, Kaari Pitkin, Carole Sabouraud, Isaac Jones, Sonia Herrero and Pat McCusker

headline: A Ritual Returns: Supreme Court Justices Will Explain Their Decisions
abstract: By explaining their decisions in open court, the justices are owning their work.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s recent announcement that the justices will return to their prepandemic practice of announcing their decisions in open court has been met with a few yawns and a big dose of scorn.
snippet: By explaining their decisions in open court, the justices are owning their work.

headline: Why the Fringiest Fringe of the G.O.P. Now Has So Much Power Over the Party
abstract: Kevin McCarthy looks like the latest victim of the new forces of fragmentation in American politics.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in nearly a century, we have witnessed the stunning spectacle of a Republican Party so fractured, it has struggled in multiple rounds of balloting to choose a speaker of the House. This Washington drama reflects larger structural forces that are changing American democracy.
snippet: Kevin McCarthy looks like the latest victim of the new forces of fragmentation in American politics.

headline: Robert Caro, Robert Gottlieb and the Art of the Edit
abstract: A 50-year literary partnership is the subject of a new documentary.
lead_paragraph: Making movies about writers is notoriously difficult, though the temptation is clear. After all, filmmakers, like authors, are storytellers, and are drawn to other people who tell them. But as with any other kind of story, clichés often do those movies in: The poet laments via ponderous voice-over narration. Words clack across the screen letter by letter in Smith Corona font. The writer bangs ardently at the keyboard when the muse strikes and stares moodily into a landscape when she fails to show.
snippet: A 50-year literary partnership is the subject of a new documentary.

subject: Documentary Films and Programs
Writing and Writers
creative_works: Turn Every Page -- The Adventures of Robert Caro and Robert Gottlieb (Movie)

headline: Making America the Opposite of Great
abstract: Now the world really is laughing at us. And it’s terrified.
lead_paragraph: I admit it: Like many liberals, I’m feeling a fair bit of MAGAfreude — taking some pleasure in the self-destruction of the American right.
snippet: Now the world really is laughing at us. And it’s terrified.

headline: Kevin McCarthy Now Has a Place in the History Books
abstract: In 20 years, will people understand what this House speaker fight was really about?
lead_paragraph: This essay has been updated to reflect news developments.
snippet: In 20 years, will people understand what this House speaker fight was really about?

headline: ‘There’s Nothing for Me Here,’ My Mother Hears Again
abstract: The occupation ended, but the aftereffects of the long American war are still ravaging Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Last September, 13 months after the Taliban takeover, my family and I flew into Kabul one morning as many of our relatives were on the cusp of fleeing the city. We hoped to see them before they parted.
snippet: The occupation ended, but the aftereffects of the long American war are still ravaging Afghanistan.

headline: I Looked Behind the Curtain of American History, and This Is What I Found
abstract: The tension between myth and reality does not undermine the U.S. It defines it.
lead_paragraph: In the realm of folklore and ancient traditions, myths are tales forever retold for their wisdom and underlying truths. Their impossibility is part of their appeal; few would pause to debunk the physics of Icarus’s wings before warning against flying too close to the sun.
snippet: The tension between myth and reality does not undermine the U.S. It defines it.

headline: I Am the Last Barrier Between My Sister and New York City
abstract: My sister lost her job, her home, her life as she’d known it. And it could have been even worse.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before Mayor Eric Adams announced that New York would begin a big push to involuntarily hospitalize severely mentally ill homeless people even if they posed no risk of harm to others, my sister was involuntarily admitted to a psychiatric unit in a city hospital. My sister is not homeless; she had been living in a studio apartment in Queens. But she has a serious mental illness and in November a neighbor called 911 after seeing her on the street carrying a chef’s knife.
snippet: My sister lost her job, her home, her life as she’d known it. And it could have been even worse.

headline: A Skeptical Take on the A.I. Revolution
abstract: The A.I. expert Gary Marcus asks: What if ChatGPT isn’t as intelligent as it seems?
lead_paragraph: The year 2022 was jam-packed with advances in artificial intelligence, from the release of image generators like DALL-E 2 and text generators like Cicero to a flurry of developments in the self-driving car industry. And then, on November 30, OpenAI released ChatGPT, arguably the smartest, funniest, most humanlike chatbot to date.
snippet: The A.I. expert Gary Marcus asks: What if ChatGPT isn’t as intelligent as it seems?

headline: Pope Benedict Wasn’t Conservative. He Was Something Much More Surprising.
abstract: The heart of his message lay in what he said not to Catholics but to atheists.
lead_paragraph: “The words of a dead man,” W.H. Auden wrote in his elegy for a fellow poet, “are modified in the guts of the living.” In the case of Pope Benedict XVI, whose requiem Mass was celebrated on Thursday, this process of transformation began long before his death.
snippet: The heart of his message lay in what he said not to Catholics but to atheists.

headline: Want to Understand L.G.B.T.Q. Life in America? Go to Alabama.
abstract: I went to Alabama to understand what our country’s anti-gay backlash looks like on the ground — and what it really means to fight back.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — It was an unusually chilly Thursday night in December, and a drag queen named Miss Majesty Divine was putting the final touches on her show makeup. She was about to go onstage for her regular gig at a basement tiki bar, one of the last performances before Christmas.
snippet: I went to Alabama to understand what our country’s anti-gay backlash looks like on the ground — and what it really means to fight back.

author.Original: By Lydia Polgreen and D'Angelo Lovell Williams

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Gary Marcus
abstract: The Jan. 6, 2023 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Gary Marcus. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Jan. 6, 2023 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: ‘The Vow’ Is Gripping TV That Doesn’t Solve Its Central Mysteries
abstract: Keith Raniere, Nxivm and the riddle of charisma.
lead_paragraph: Over Christmas, my wife and I finished watching Season 2 of “The Vow,” an HBO documentary about the unraveling of the Nxivm organization — better known to tabloid readers as the “sex slave cult,” after its inner circle, whose members were branded and participated in self-described master-slave relationships — and the trial of its leader, Keith Raniere. It’s a striking piece of filmmaking and a deeply frustrating exercise: A mystery story that offers copious evidence, endless evidence, evidence enough to make Hercule Poirot envious, without coming close to answering the key questions raised by its fascinating subject.
snippet: Keith Raniere, Nxivm and the riddle of charisma.

headline: Tales of Families and the Great Depression
abstract: Readers share their stories of resilience, community and suffering.
lead_paragraph: Many readers responded to my newsletter last Friday about my great-grandfather’s life during the Depression in Vermont. I heard from neighbors, relatives and readers as far away as Australia. While some wrote glowingly about the resilience and camaraderie fostered by the Depression, others focused on the suffering. Here are edited excerpts from some of your emails.
snippet: Readers share their stories of resilience, community and suffering.

headline: What Ukraine Teaches Us About Power
abstract: Acting tough doesn’t make you strong, even militarily.
lead_paragraph: Credit where credit is due: Make America Great Again was a brilliant slogan, precisely because nobody knew what it meant. Was it about bringing back jobs in manufacturing? Was it about restoring straight, white, Christian men to what some of them thought was their natural position of social dominance? MAGA became all-purpose code for reversing whatever was bugging you about 21st-century America.
snippet: Acting tough doesn’t make you strong, even militarily.

headline: I’m One of the Last Holdouts Against Kevin McCarthy — and I Won’t Back Down
abstract: We already know what a House under his leadership looks like.
lead_paragraph: Back in the summer, a group of conservatives put together a proposal with extensive changes to the rules and processes that govern how Republicans run the House of Representatives. For example, we wanted regular, rank-and-file members to have more power to amend bills on the House floor. We wanted at least three days to read and consider bills before we were asked to vote on them. And we wanted to limit the scope of bills to a single subject, so we wouldn’t be asked to vote on legislative “Christmas trees” passed on a tight deadline. We made those demands because the people we represent have told us time and again that Washington is broken, and we knew they wanted to see a change in the status quo.
snippet: We already know what a House under his leadership looks like.

headline: It’s Tempting to Laugh at McCarthy’s Struggles, but History Shows That This Type of Chaos Is Not a Joke
abstract: Kevin McCarthy’s House speakership battle is a sign of rupture for the G.O.P. — and trouble for the country.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, we’ve watched congressional Republicans reap the whirlwind. In campaigning for the 2022 midterm elections, the G.O.P. rode a wave of extremism, saying little about the politics of hate and denial practiced by some of its candidates in an effort to capture votes.
snippet: Kevin McCarthy’s House speakership battle is a sign of rupture for the G.O.P. — and trouble for the country.

headline: Damar Hamlin and What CPR Can and Cannot Do
abstract: A doctor considers the different ways CPR is used.
lead_paragraph: Days after his heart stopped and he collapsed motionless on a football field, Damar Hamlin is reportedly awake, moving his hands and feet and communicating. This young man could have died, but he is alive and appears to be recovering — a testament to the power of high-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR.
snippet: A doctor considers the different ways CPR is used.

headline: Prince Harry and the Value of Silence
abstract: Sometimes the best thing to say about your family is nothing, a lesson I learned the hard way.
lead_paragraph: During the early stages of my father’s Alzheimer’s, when he still had lucid moments, I apologized to him for writing an autobiography many years earlier in which I flung open the gates of our troubled family life. He was already talking less at that point, but his eyes told me he understood.
snippet: Sometimes the best thing to say about your family is nothing, a lesson I learned the hard way.

Books and Literature

headline: New York Voters Put Democrats on Notice. Was the Message Received?
abstract: If Kathy Hochul is listening to New Yorkers, she will act boldly on housing and public safety.
lead_paragraph: For politicians in some places in the United States, election losses tend to prompt a kind of soul-searching.
snippet: If Kathy Hochul is listening to New Yorkers, she will act boldly on housing and public safety.

headline: What Went Unsaid in the Chief Justice’s Report on the Judiciary
abstract: Chief Justice John Roberts did not mention any of the many issues that swirled around the court last year.
lead_paragraph: John Roberts, the chief justice of the United States, recently filed his 2022 “year-end report on the federal judiciary.” It’s more interesting for what it didn’t say than for what it did.
snippet: Chief Justice John Roberts did not mention any of the many issues that swirled around the court last year.

headline: California Could Capture Its Destructive Floodwaters to Fight Drought
abstract: There’s a great opportunity to return some land to water, working with natural systems.
lead_paragraph: After a long, dry summer, winter has brought the gift of water to California, via a series of atmospheric river storms. Unfortunately, as these sprawling rivers in the sky have met developed areas covered with concrete and rivers locked in by levees, they have brought destruction: floods, mudslides, washed-out roads, blackouts, uprooted trees and at least six deaths.
snippet: There’s a great opportunity to return some land to water, working with natural systems.

headline: Kevin McCarthy and the Return of the Pre-Trump G.O.P.
abstract: In the struggles over the speakership, the old G.O.P. world, with all its dysfunctions, stalemates and futility, has come again.
lead_paragraph: Did you miss the Republican Party that existed before Donald Trump came along? ‌Are you nostalgic for the days of John Boehner battling Tea Party rebels over the debt ceiling or the fiscal cliff, or Ted Cruz’s “plan” to defund Obamacare? Do you pine for the years when the crucial test of conservative purity was a commitment to an implausible deficit reduction plan, the good old days when empty suits and aspiring lobbyists battled libertarian ideologues and aspiring cable-news personalities for the chance to advance an agenda of mild austerity and business-friendly tax cuts?
snippet: In the struggles over the speakership, the old G.O.P. world, with all its dysfunctions, stalemates and futility, has come again.

headline: Biden’s Visit to the Border Is Bound to Be Awkward
abstract: But at least he is arriving with a plan.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have been hounding President Biden for more than a year to travel to the southern border and see the situation there with his own eyes. “I guess I should go down,” he conceded in a town hall meeting with CNN in October 2021, but he explained that he had been too busy to make the trip. Last month, when Mr. Biden went to tour the site for a computer chip manufacturing plant in Arizona but not the southern border, Fox News blasted him.
snippet: But at least he is arriving with a plan.

headline: Why Has America Fallen So Hard for Harry and Meghan?
abstract: Inside a vast, and somewhat peculiar, celebrity obsession.
lead_paragraph: Whether out of Anglophilia, nostalgia, masochism, traditionalism or just a particular strain of fealty to the rich and famous, America’s quixotic devotion to the British monarchy remains strong.
snippet: Inside a vast, and somewhat peculiar, celebrity obsession.

headline: The Dystopia We Fear Is Keeping Us From the Utopia We Deserve
abstract: We’ve lost sight of the world that abundant, clean energy could make possible.
lead_paragraph: In December, scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory announced that they had achieved on Earth what is commonplace within stars: They had fused hydrogen isotopes, releasing more energy in the reaction than was used in the ignition. The announcement came with enough caveats to make it clear that usable nuclear fusion remains, optimistically, decades away. But the fact that nuclear fusion will not change our energy system over the next year doesn’t mean it shouldn’t change our energy ambitions for the coming years.
snippet: We’ve lost sight of the world that abundant, clean energy could make possible.

headline: This Sport Has Devastated the Lives of Players. What Do Fans Owe Them?
abstract: Footballers are taking part in a beautiful, brutal sport for our entertainment.
lead_paragraph: I have been a football fan for practically my entire life. I’ve watched hundreds, maybe thousands, of college and N.F.L. games, and I will watch football this weekend.
snippet: Footballers are taking part in a beautiful, brutal sport for our entertainment.

headline: Grant Wahl Was a Loving Husband. I Will Always Protect His Legacy.
abstract: Anti-vaccine harassment cannot stand.
lead_paragraph: It was the end of the workday on Friday, Dec. 9, 2022. I was wrapping up a Zoom call when my phone started to vibrate with calls, text messages and emails. Gabriele Marcotti, an ESPN journalist, was trying to reach me from Qatar, where he was covering the World Cup alongside my husband, Grant Wahl.
snippet: Anti-vaccine harassment cannot stand.

headline: ‘She Comes Back to Where She Belongs’
abstract: Why the return of colonial art is a powerful and necessary statement.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1995, Russia’s two major art museums, in St. Petersburg and Moscow, mounted exhibitions a month apart that attracted considerable attention. Not so much because of the art, although much of it was spectacular, but because Russia openly identified it as art looted from Nazi Germany at the end of World War II.
snippet: Why the return of colonial art is a powerful and necessary statement.

headline: This Year, Try Organizing Your Life Like a Monk
abstract: An ancient Christian concept to structure your days.
lead_paragraph: Last week, when we looked at suggested resolutions from thinkers and writers, I mentioned that I often feel ambivalent about the beginning-of-the-year thrust toward disciplines, goals and habits. I tend more toward variety and chaos rather than order and routine. But over the last decade, I’ve found a strange source of inspiration. The lives of monks and nuns have taught me, a non-Catholic mother who sleeps late whenever possible and binges Netflix, how to better live. Because of their example, I’ve adopted a rule of life. A rule of life is an overarching plan governing your daily practices, habits and routines. It is not a resolution, but rather a comprehensive way to take stock of how you spend your time so that you can be the person you want to be.
snippet: An ancient Christian concept to structure your days.

headline: The Republicans Are Putting Trump Out to Pasture
abstract: The former president had a moment, but now the sun is setting on that moment.
lead_paragraph: Many families have a grandfather or an uncle who, in his prime, was the patriarch, the family’s force and compass. His counsel was sought and heeded. He was treated with the utmost respect and deference.
snippet: The former president had a moment, but now the sun is setting on that moment.

headline: Ron DeSantis Could Decide Republicans’ Foreign Policy
abstract: The Florida governor is viewed as a top Republican presidential contender — at a time when the party is at a crossroads on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is widely considered the strongest potential primary challenger to former President Donald Trump’s third campaign in 2024. His national profile, developed during the Covid-19 pandemic and in battles over public education, is by definition domestic, and yet his experience as governor is an obvious precursor to the highest office. Especially if Mr. DeSantis runs in 2024, there is the real possibility that he will emerge as the new leader of the G.O.P.
snippet: The Florida governor is viewed as a top Republican presidential contender — at a time when the party is at a crossroads on foreign policy.

headline: Temple Grandin: Society Is Failing Visual Thinkers, and That Hurts Us All
abstract: American schools are screening out too many of our visual and spatial thinkers.
lead_paragraph: When I was younger, I believed that everybody thought in photo-realistic pictures the same way I did, with images clicking through my mind a little bit like PowerPoint slides or TikTok videos.
snippet: American schools are screening out too many of our visual and spatial thinkers.

headline: Speaker, Speaker, What Do You See? I See MAGA Looking at Me.
abstract: Kevin McCarthy gets his chance to bang the gavel.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, remember “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” the unforgettable Lionel Shriver novel about a woman whose son murders his classmates? Maybe someone should write the sequel: “We Need to Talk About What They Did to Kevin.”
snippet: Kevin McCarthy gets his chance to bang the gavel.

Elections

Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: Lina Khan: Noncompetes Depress Wages and Kill Innovation
abstract: The chairwoman of the F.T.C. argues in favor of a proposal to eliminate noncompete clauses from employee contracts.
lead_paragraph: Economic liberty, not just political liberty, is at the heart of the American experiment. You’re not really free if you don’t have the right to switch jobs or choose what to do with your labor. But millions of American workers can’t fully exercise that choice because of a provision that bosses put into their contracts: a noncompete clause.
snippet: The chairwoman of the F.T.C. argues in favor of a proposal to eliminate noncompete clauses from employee contracts.

headline: Football Is Deadly, but Not for the Reasons You Think
abstract: While the risks do not end on the field, the medical care often does.
lead_paragraph: When Damar Hamlin suffered a cardiac arrest during the N.F.L. “Monday Night Football” game last week, it felt like the world stopped — both on the field, where emergency medical teams rushed into action and fellow players looked on in shock, and on televisions in millions of homes, where fans tried to make sense of what they had just witnessed in real time.
snippet: While the risks do not end on the field, the medical care often does.

headline: Lula Has No Easy Choices
abstract: Brazil’s newly elected president is stuck between protesters on one side and financial markets on the other.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s new president is hemmed in by protesters on one side and financial markets on the other. He needs to spend money to please the public, but he needs to demonstrate fiscal responsibility to keep investors from abandoning Brazilian assets, which could cause interest rates to soar and cripple the economy. Unfortunately, it will be extremely difficult to do both at once.
snippet: Brazil’s newly elected president is stuck between protesters on one side and financial markets on the other.

headline: The ‘Trump of the Tropics’ Goes Bust
abstract: The definitive challenge for Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva: to be president for all the people.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — As a shocked nation watched live on television and social media, thousands of radical supporters of a defeated president marched on the seat of the federal government, convinced that an election had been stolen. The mob ransacked the Congress, the Supreme Court and the presidential palace. It took the authorities several hours to arrest hundreds of people and finally restore order.
snippet: The definitive challenge for Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva: to be president for all the people.

headline: Election Deniers Are Also Economy Deniers
abstract: There’s no recession yet, and inflation is falling.
lead_paragraph: The people who will be running the House of Representatives for the next two years — a group that does not, as far as anyone can tell, include Kevin McCarthy, who seems set to be speaker in name only — believe a number of untrue things.
snippet: There’s no recession yet, and inflation is falling.

headline: DeSantis Allies Plot the Hostile Takeover of a Liberal College
abstract: Chris Rufo’s “long march through the institutions” starts in Florida.
lead_paragraph: New College of Florida has a reputation for being the most progressive public college in the state. X González — a survivor of the Parkland school shooting who, as Emma González, became a prominent gun control activist — recently wrote of their alma mater, “In the queer space of New College, changing your pronouns, name or presentation is a nonevent.” In The Princeton Review’s ranking of the best public colleges and universities for “making an impact” — measured by things like student engagement, community service and sustainability efforts — New College comes in third.
snippet: Chris Rufo’s “long march through the institutions” starts in Florida.

headline: A Trans Man in Mexico Forges His Own Path
abstract: In a traditional Catholic town, Alex develops his identity and defends his dreams.
lead_paragraph: I first met Alex Reyes de Anda, the subject of this short documentary, when I was in a period of questioning and self-reflection after my 41st birthday: Am I the person I want to be? What makes us who we are? Getting to know Mr. Reyes de Anda led me to confront my own fears of the wider world and what freedom means in our own lives.
snippet: In a traditional Catholic town, Alex develops his identity and defends his dreams.

headline: Dan Savage on Polyamory, Chosen Family and Better Sex
abstract: The advice columnist discusses how dating, sex and relationships have changed over the past 30 years — and where they should go next.
lead_paragraph: Even if you don’t recognize the advice columnist Dan Savage by name, it’s possible that his ideas have influenced how you think about sex and relationships. For decades now, Savage has been arguing that our expectations for long-term partnerships are way too high; that healthy relationships are about acknowledging our vast spectrum of desires, not repressing them; and that monogamy is not the ideal setup for every partnership. Through over 30 years of writing “Savage Love,” one of the most widely read sex advice columns in the country, and more than 17 years of hosting the podcast “Savage Lovecast,” he has been one of America’s most subtly influential public intellectuals on the topic of how humans conduct our most intimate — and important — relationships.
snippet: The advice columnist discusses how dating, sex and relationships have changed over the past 30 years — and where they should go next.

headline: A Smirk, a Smile, a Clenched Fist: What the Movies Taught Me to See
abstract: For someone like me, those flickering images were more than just a story. They were a whole world.
lead_paragraph: I was seduced by Cate Blanchett in “Tár.” The 1980s ecological disaster in “White Noise” felt eerily familiar to me in our time of climate change. I was struck by how dark Guillermo del Toro’s “Pinocchio” was compared with the Disney animated version I saw as a child in South Jersey in the early 1960s.
snippet: For someone like me, those flickering images were more than just a story. They were a whole world.

headline: The Less Talked About Part of Kevin McCarthy’s Deal With Republican Radicals
abstract: Extreme opposition to social insurance and the safety net is a natural fit for an authoritarian movement that tried to overturn the constitutional order.
lead_paragraph: The most talked about part of the deal Kevin McCarthy made with Republican radicals to become speaker of the House involved concessions to those members on rules, powerful committee assignments for members of the House Freedom Caucus and the creation of a new select committee on the “weaponization” of government that would give Republicans like Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio an official platform from which they could undermine the investigations into former President Donald Trump and the Jan. 6 insurrection.
snippet: Extreme opposition to social insurance and the safety net is a natural fit for an authoritarian movement that tried to overturn the constitutional order.

headline: Some Good Can Come Out of the Kevin McCarthy Fiasco
abstract: The embarrassment in the House could point the way to a stronger institution.
lead_paragraph: Kevin McCarthy’s grueling struggle to become speaker of the House of Representatives was mostly an embarrassment for him and his new Republican majority. Yet among the fumbling and chaos, you could catch glimpses of how the House could improve itself — that is, if party factions advance structural reforms.
snippet: The embarrassment in the House could point the way to a stronger institution.

headline: I’m a Scientist Who Spoke Up About Climate Change. My Employer Fired Me.
abstract: I knew that I could face retaliation, but inaction during this critical time will have far greater consequences.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — Shortly after the New Year, I was fired from Oak Ridge National Laboratory after urging fellow scientists to take action on climate change. At the American Geophysical Union meeting in December, just before speakers took the stage for a plenary session, my fellow climate scientist Peter Kalmus and I unfurled a banner that read, “Out of the lab & into the streets.” In the few seconds before the banner was ripped from our hands, we implored our colleagues to use their leverage as scientists to wake the public up to the dying planet.
snippet: I knew that I could face retaliation, but inaction during this critical time will have far greater consequences.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Dan Savage
abstract: The Jan. 10, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Dan Savage. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Jan. 10, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: The Secret Lives of Words
abstract: Don’t let the dictionary fool you. Their meanings change all the time.
lead_paragraph: Some time ago, I fell into conversation with a colleague about what we had been reading lately, and the person suggested that I absolutely must give Henry James’s “The Ambassadors” a try.
snippet: Don’t let the dictionary fool you. Their meanings change all the time.

headline: The Chaos Caucus Is Now in Charge
abstract: Blame the next wave of House dysfunction on the antimajoritarian, anarchic lot.
lead_paragraph: Things are looking up for Kevin McCarthy! Last week it took 15 agonizing roll call votes spread over five days of public humiliation for him to get elected to his dream job as speaker of the House. This week it took him just one drama-free vote on Monday to pass a package of operating rules for the 118th Congress. Better still, no Republicans started shrieking threats at one another on the House floor or had to be manhandled into submission. This qualifies as a solid win for the newly, narrowly elected speaker. Alas, the same cannot be said for anyone interested in a sane, functional Congress.
snippet: Blame the next wave of House dysfunction on the antimajoritarian, anarchic lot.

headline: Can We Really Have a Soft Landing?
abstract: The news is good, but curb your enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: In August 1982 I arrived in Washington to begin a year working at the White House Council of Economic Advisers. Yes, it was the Reagan administration, and I was already a liberal. But it was a technocratic position rather than a political one, and the council’s new chair, Martin Feldstein — a moderate Republican of a type that has largely vanished since — wanted some whiz kids to crunch the data. I was supposed to focus on international issues; the new hire for domestic economics was a guy named Larry Summers. What ever happened to him?
snippet: The news is good, but curb your enthusiasm.

headline: Noma and the Fizzle of Too-Fine Dining
abstract: An elite establishment’s closing raises questions about what a restaurant should be.
lead_paragraph: It was at Noma that I ate the most unsettling meal of my life.
snippet: An elite establishment’s closing raises questions about what a restaurant should be.

headline: Brazil’s Homage to Jan. 6 Was an Act of Pure Performance
abstract: How Jan. 8 confirmed two tendencies of contemporary populism.
lead_paragraph: For two years we have debated whether the essential feature of the Jan. 6 riot, the mob stirred up to storm the Capitol in frustration over the 2020 election, was the ambition in the background or the futility and unreality up front.
snippet: How Jan. 8 confirmed two tendencies of contemporary populism.

headline: Was the Idaho Murder Suspect Studying Criminology to Learn How to Commit a Crime?
abstract: As a professor of criminology and a former F.B.I. special agent, I am frequently surprised by the misperceptions of what criminologists study.
lead_paragraph: Crime is a constant in American life. We see it portrayed on television and in films, see it debated in the media and by politicians, and unfortunately some of us experience it in our lives.
snippet: As a professor of criminology and a former F.B.I. special agent, I am frequently surprised by the misperceptions of what criminologists study.

headline: Meet the Republicans Who Are Facing Down the Hard Right
abstract: Republican legislators in South Carolina, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Alaska are pushing back against it much more forcefully than Kevin McCarthy.
lead_paragraph: While 20 hard-right members of the U.S. House of Representatives held the national Republican leadership hostage in Washington last week — forcing concession after concession — something very different was taking place in the Republican-controlled South Carolina House of Representatives.
snippet: Republican legislators in South Carolina, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Alaska are pushing back against it much more forcefully than Kevin McCarthy.

headline: The Party’s Over for Us. Where Do We Go Now?
abstract: Is the G.O.P. beyond hope for two conservatives?
lead_paragraph: For decades, conservative values have been central to Bret Stephens’s and David Brooks’s political beliefs, and the Republican Party was the vehicle to extend those beliefs into policy. But in recent years, both the party and a radicalized conservative movement have left them feeling alienated in various ways. Now, with an extremist fringe seemingly in control of the House, the G.O.P. bears little resemblance to the party that was once their home. Bret and David got together to suss out what happened and where the party can go.
snippet: Is the G.O.P. beyond hope for two conservatives?

author.Original: By Bret Stephens and David Brooks

headline: Kevin McCarthy Can’t Give Republican Rebels What They Really Want
abstract: The G.O.P. is afraid of demographic and social change. But Kevin McCarthy can’t do anything about that.
lead_paragraph: If last week’s 15 rounds of balloting for House speaker proved anything, it’s that Democrats like their congressional leaders a lot more than Republicans do.
snippet: The G.O.P. is afraid of demographic and social change. But Kevin McCarthy can’t do anything about that.

headline: Is a Grudging Apology Better Than No Apology?
abstract: From celebs to kids, we’re awash in insincere sorrys.
lead_paragraph: I eke an apology out of my younger daughter several times a week. She is generally a serene child, but when she loses her temper she can go from bleating lamb to aggressive honey badger in seconds. She only acts like this at home, and often her upset is focused on her older sister for some perceived injustice — “She only wants to watch ‘Friends’ and it’s boring!” Because she’s the younger sister and only 6, and doesn’t yet have the verbal dexterity to spar with words, she occasionally resorts to charging and tackling.
snippet: From celebs to kids, we’re awash in insincere sorrys.

headline: Electric Vehicles Keep Defying Almost Everyone’s Predictions
abstract: The revolution is also a case study in how much further we have to go.
lead_paragraph: It is striking that in the same year that Tesla’s stock price dropped by about two-thirds, destroying more than $700 billion in market value, the global market for electric vehicles — which for so long the company seemed almost to embody — actually boomed.
snippet: The revolution is also a case study in how much further we have to go.

headline: How the Coachella of Economics Can Survive Covid
abstract: Attendance at the world’s biggest conference of economists plummeted this year.
lead_paragraph: Attendance at the world’s biggest conference of economists was down by half this year, and that had some attendees worrying that the annual conclave was at risk of unraveling like a knitted sweater. People who were disappointed not to see their friends at this year’s Allied Social Science Associations conference in New Orleans would be less likely to attend next January’s conference in San Antonio, the theory went, leading to even lower attendance in San Francisco in 2025, and so on in a downward spiral with no obvious stopping point.
snippet: Attendance at the world’s biggest conference of economists plummeted this year.

headline: Should We Block the Sun to Counter Climate Change?
abstract: Once a taboo idea thought too dangerous to research, geoengineering is becoming more mainstream.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
snippet: Once a taboo idea thought too dangerous to research, geoengineering is becoming more mainstream.

headline: This Kenyan Slum Has Something to Teach the World
abstract: Against all odds, Kibera offers a lesson in bottom-up development.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Here in the Kibera slum, life sometimes seems a free-for-all. Residents steal electricity by tapping into overhead lines, children walk barefoot through alleys trickling with sewage, and people occasionally must dodge “flying toilets” — plastic bags that residents use as toilets and then dispose of by hurling them in one direction or another.
snippet: Against all odds, Kibera offers a lesson in bottom-up development.

headline: The Fraudulence of Investigating the Investigators
abstract: This new committee is no Church Committee; it’s a coven of conspiracy theorists.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have decided to hound the hounds.
snippet: This new committee is no Church Committee; it’s a coven of conspiracy theorists.

headline: Ukrainian Engineers, Historians and Housewives Are Keeping Putin on His Toes
abstract: With sewing machines and smartphones, Ukrainians are fighting against the Russian aggressors.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — With tourniquets, there is no way of doing things on the cheap. These lifesaving devices, used to stop blood loss from a wounded limb and prevent death from bleeding, need to be 100 percent reliable: a solid, wide Velcro band sufficiently long to be put around a thigh and a tough crank to pull it tight, with a sturdy locking mechanism. A good tourniquet costs $20 to $30 and the best ones are made in the United States. As with many other products, Chinese vendors sell a variety of fakes — something as simple as a rope on a rod is an invitation to counterfeit. Worse than useless, the Chinese knockoffs are a liability when they snap in the trembling, slippery hands of a bleeding person.
snippet: With sewing machines and smartphones, Ukrainians are fighting against the Russian aggressors.

headline: Why Does Big Tech Make It So Hard to Fix Your Devices?
abstract: The C.E.O. of iFixit is fighting for your right to stop shopping and start repairing.
lead_paragraph: Gadgets break. But for years, Big Tech’s business model has created barriers to consumers who want to repair those broken devices, incentivizing them to just buy new ones instead. Since 2003, Kyle Wiens has been fighting against that eternal treadmill as the founder and C.E.O. of iFixit, a site that allows people to write and share user manuals for gadgets, toys, appliances and more. Kyle’s work has made him a leader of the Right to Repair movement — a political cause that’s recently seen its first victory in New York State with the passage of a new bill, the Digital Fair Repair Act. It will require companies to make repairing electronics easier for consumers and independent repair shops, without needing to rely on manufacturers. And it’s bound to have major impacts — from strengthening local economies, reducing the scourge of e-waste and empowering consumers.
snippet: The C.E.O. of iFixit is fighting for your right to stop shopping and start repairing.

author.Original: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Wyatt Orme, Derek Arthur, Anabel Bacon, Kaari Pitkin, Carole Sabouraud, Isaac Jones, Sonia Herrero and Pat McCusker
author.People: Garcia-Navarro Lulu, Orme Wyatt, Arthur Derek, Bacon Anabel, Pitkin Kaari, Sabouraud Carole, Jones Isaac, Herrero Sonia, McCusker Pat

headline: Republicans Are Getting It Wrong About DeSantis and Florida
abstract: Why the governor may not be the savior the GOP is hoping for.
lead_paragraph: Engulfed in turmoil in Washington, D.C., and the humiliation and setbacks of their party leaders, Republicans can be forgiven for looking elsewhere for a savior. Former President Donald Trump was, until those final minutes, largely ineffective in getting his ideological offspring to make Kevin McCarthy speaker, and so hopeful eyes have turned yet again to that other Floridian.
snippet: Why the governor may not be the savior the GOP is hoping for.

headline: Cougars Are Heading East. We Should Welcome Them.
abstract: Over a dozen landscapes large enough to sustain cougars exist in states that border or are east of the Mississippi River.
lead_paragraph: Numerous cougar sightings were reported east of the Mississippi River last fall, encounters that have become more frequent in recent years. A trail camera glimpsed one in northern Minnesota, for instance, while authorities captured another in Springfield, Ill., after it had made its way there from Nebraska. Yet another was fatally struck by a car on I-88 west of Chicago.
snippet: Over a dozen landscapes large enough to sustain cougars exist in states that border or are east of the Mississippi River.

headline: She Made History as a Black Basketball Star. Why Won’t Her College Name Its Arena for Her?
abstract: Delta State University should do right by the “Queen of Basketball.”
lead_paragraph: The Walter Sillers Coliseum, a 3,000-seat brick arena, has been the basketball mecca of Delta State University since it was built in 1960. At that time, Delta State, today a public university with just over 2,500 students in Cleveland, Miss., was a white-only institution.
snippet: Delta State University should do right by the “Queen of Basketball.”

headline: Why Republican Politicians Still Hate Medicare
abstract: At this point, even their own voters support big social spending.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans who now control the House will soon try to slash Social Security and Medicare. They plan to achieve this by holding the economy hostage, threatening to create a financial crisis by refusing to raise the federal debt ceiling. The interesting questions are why they want to do this, given that it appears politically suicidal, and how Democrats will respond.
snippet: At this point, even their own voters support big social spending.

headline: A Guide to the ‘Legal Fictions’ That Create Wealth, Inequality and Economic Crises
abstract: The legal scholar Katharina Pistor examines the hidden legal layer propping up our modern economic system.
lead_paragraph: “Capitalism, it turns out, is more than just the exchange of goods in a market economy,” Katharina Pistor writes. “It is a market economy in which some assets are placed on legal steroids.”
snippet: The legal scholar Katharina Pistor examines the hidden legal layer propping up our modern economic system.

headline: It’s Time to Finally Fix Air Travel
abstract: The F.A.A. meltdown shows it’s time for a national discussion about the state of air travel.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, the Federal Aviation Administration was forced to reboot its system that alerts pilots to safety issues, grounding all air traffic in the United States. It was the first time since the Sept. 11 attacks that U.S. airspace has been entirely shut down.
snippet: The F.A.A. meltdown shows it’s time for a national discussion about the state of air travel.

headline: The Romance Novelist Who Faked Her Own Death
abstract: Now how’s that for a plot twist?
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to make yourself Twitter’s main character for a day, but faking your death might be the most reliable. As remote-work types struggled to awake from their holiday season hibernation last week, we were jolted by a particularly juicy tidbit: Susan Meachen, a prolific self-published romance novelist whose suicide — ostensibly a reaction to low book sales and bullying by fellow authors — had been announced two years ago, returned to the internet, very much alive. “Let the fun begin,” she concluded a social media post announcing her resurrection.
snippet: Now how’s that for a plot twist?

headline: Kellyanne Conway: The Cases for and Against Trump
abstract: Shrugging off Mr. Trump’s 2024 candidacy is a fool’s errand. But it would also be foolish to assume that his path to another presidency would be smooth.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump shocked the world in 2016 by winning the White House and becoming the first president in U.S. history with no prior military or government experience. He upended the fiction of electability pushed by pundits, the news media and many political consultants, which arrogantly projects who will or will not win long before votes are cast. He focused instead on capturing a majority in the Electoral College, which is how a candidate does or does not win. Not unlike Barack Obama eight years earlier, Mr. Trump exposed the limits of Hillary Clinton’s political inevitability and personal likability, connected directly with people, ran an outsider’s campaign taking on the establishment, and tapped into the frustrations and aspirations of millions of Americans.
snippet: Shrugging off Mr. Trump’s 2024 candidacy is a fool’s errand. But it would also be foolish to assume that his path to another presidency would be smooth.

headline: Your Gas Stove May Be Killing You. How Much Should You Worry?
abstract: Cooking with gas may be unhealthy and bad for the environment, but it’s not clear induction is worth the cost. And have you considered a heat pump?
lead_paragraph: The natural-gas-powered appliances in your home may be slowly killing you and everyone you love. That’s the bad news. The worse news is this: It’s not clear exactly what you should do about it — if anything at all.
snippet: Cooking with gas may be unhealthy and bad for the environment, but it’s not clear induction is worth the cost. And have you considered a heat pump?

headline: Why Must We Go About Our Lives With an Eye on the Nearest Exit?
abstract: An “armed society” may or may not be a “polite society,” but it is far from being a democratic one.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, in Atlanta, 22-year-old Rico Marley was arrested in a Publix supermarket. He was wearing body armor and carrying six loaded weapons, including a semiautomatic rifle and a 12-gauge shotgun. Prosecutors, as my newsroom colleague Richard Fausset reports in a recent story, charged Marley with 11 felonies, including “six counts of possession of a weapon ‘during commission of or attempt to commit certain felonies.’”
snippet: An “armed society” may or may not be a “polite society,” but it is far from being a democratic one.

headline: Pamela Anderson Doesn’t Need Your Redemption. She’s Just Fine.
abstract: She was the universal sex symbol. But there is more to her story, and she’s finally telling it herself.
lead_paragraph: LADYSMITH, British Columbia — I am sitting across from Pamela Anderson, at her kitchen table, trying to explain to her that I have an app on my phone that will make me look like Pamela Anderson.
snippet: She was the universal sex symbol. But there is more to her story, and she’s finally telling it herself.

author.Original: By Jessica Bennett and Sara Cwynar

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Show with Katharina Pistor
abstract: The Jan. 13, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Rogé Karma and featuring Katharina Pistor. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Jan. 13, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: Will Euthanasia Be Secular or Sacred?
abstract: Two ways of looking at assisted suicide.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I wrote a harsh column about the Canadian euthanasia system, which has expanded rapidly over the past few years, with over 10,000 people ending their lives under its auspices in 2021. This week, I want to recommend two very different analyses of the Canadian experience.
snippet: Two ways of looking at assisted suicide.

headline: The Not-So-Great News About Lower Inflation
abstract: The fact that consumer prices fell isn’t entirely a good thing for the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: The news that consumer prices fell in December from November — yes, monthly inflation was negative — was not as wonderful for the Federal Reserve as you might expect. Fed officials are trying to persuade the financial markets and the public that the fight against high inflation is far from over, and this data point doesn’t help make its case.
snippet: The fact that consumer prices fell isn’t entirely a good thing for the Federal Reserve.

headline: Wonking Out: It’s Getting Harder to Be a Pessimist on Inflation
abstract: Some of us on “Team Transitory” were too optimistic, but now others are making the opposite mistake.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s report on consumer prices was really good news. I mean, really, really good news. The overall Consumer Price Index actually fell slightly for the month of December. We can and should downplay that number, because it was driven in part by special factors like a plunge in gasoline prices and because monthly data are noisy. But even when you try to filter out the noise by excluding more volatile prices and looking at averages over several months, you get a picture of rapidly slowing inflation.
snippet: Some of us on “Team Transitory” were too optimistic, but now others are making the opposite mistake.

headline: Who Are the Real Babies in First Class?
abstract: The complaints about infants on airplanes say something about our culture of entitlement.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve been covering a topic for a while, you see the same story lines pop up over and over. On the parenting beat, the dilemma of babies crying on airplanes is evergreen and always divisive. In a few cases, harried parents have been so concerned about being shamed for the mundane act of taking a baby on a plane that they’ve resorted to handing out goody bags in the hopes of preemptively mollifying fellow passengers.
snippet: The complaints about infants on airplanes say something about our culture of entitlement.

headline: Harry’s Fractured Fairy Tale
abstract: A millennial Hamlet haunted by Mummy’s vengeful ghost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I am, faith and begorrah, no monarchist.
snippet: A millennial Hamlet haunted by Mummy’s vengeful ghost.

headline: The Trouble With Paradise
abstract: My search for the sublime led me to the last place I expected to find it.
lead_paragraph: One day in my 20s, several decades ago, I got on a plane in New York City and flew across the world. It was dark when I arrived in Bali, but when I awoke the next day, a young man with a beautiful smile brought me fresh mango and strong tea to enjoy on the terrace of my bungalow. All around, playing amid bright flowers, were little girls with the faces of angels. Within hours, midwinter gloom had been transformed, as if by magic, into tropical sunshine. I was paying two dollars a night for a cottage of my own with a golden beach 45 seconds away, down a fragrant, palm-shaded lane.
snippet: My search for the sublime led me to the last place I expected to find it.

headline: Why Do Documents Marked Secret Keep Showing Up in Strange Places?
abstract: America’s system for protecting classified documents has spun out of control.
lead_paragraph: There is much we still do not know about President Biden’s stash of secret documents, but one thing is painfully obvious: The system for protecting secrets vital to national security has spun out of control. The question is why.
snippet: America’s system for protecting classified documents has spun out of control.

headline: How to Help Girls Enduring the Unendurable
abstract: Some unfinished business from #MeToo: the global scourge of rape.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — She is impossibly young to have endured what she did, and what still haunts her is the job of the man responsible: a police officer.
snippet: Some unfinished business from #MeToo: the global scourge of rape.

headline: The Dangerous Decline of the Historical Profession
abstract: Is this actually the end of history?
lead_paragraph: When I received my Ph.D. in history in 2013, I didn’t expect that within a decade fights over history — and historiography, even if few people use that word — would become front-page news. But over the last few years that is precisely what has happened: Just look at the recent debates over America’s legacy of slavery, what can be taught in public schools about the nation’s founders and even the definition of what constitutes fascism. The interpretation of the American past has not in recent memory been as public or as contentious as it is now.
snippet: Is this actually the end of history?

headline: Martin Luther King Jr.’s Other Dreams
abstract: In 1967, he delivered a powerful sermon about the struggle for global peace.
lead_paragraph: The way most Americans talk about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., more than 50 years after his assassination, you might think that he gave exactly one speech — on Aug. 28, 1963, in Washington — and spoke exclusively about racial harmony and his oft-mentioned dream of integration.
snippet: In 1967, he delivered a powerful sermon about the struggle for global peace.

headline: Will There Be a Biden Comeback?
abstract: A number of events would have to go the president’s way, and even then age is an issue.
lead_paragraph: Something unusual happened to Joe Biden this week. A reputable poll, from The Economist and YouGov, showed him with a positive job approval rating — even hitting 50 percent approval among registered voters, against 47 percent disapproving.
snippet: A number of events would have to go the president’s way, and even then age is an issue.

headline: How ChatGPT Hijacks Democracy
abstract: The greatest threat A.I. may present is its ability to replace humans in lobbying.
lead_paragraph: Launched just weeks ago, ChatGPT is already threatening to upend how we draft everyday communications like emails, college essays and myriad other forms of writing.
snippet: The greatest threat A.I. may present is its ability to replace humans in lobbying.

author.Original: By Nathan E. Sanders and Bruce Schneier

headline: If New York Is So Great, Why Isn’t There Anywhere to Pee?
abstract: We need infrastructure that offers relief.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of Times Square in July 2021, I sipped the last of my iced coffee and realized I had to go. After being turned away from several businesses, I burst into a McDonald’s and was told the bathroom was for customers only. I paid $3 for a bottle of water and ran up a flight of stairs, only to find the door unlocked. I could have just gone in and used the toilet without having to buy that overpriced water.
snippet: We need infrastructure that offers relief.

headline: Will the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem Be Built on Confiscated Palestinian Land?
abstract: The Biden administration is doubling down on a reckless Trump policy.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is doubling down on its predecessor’s reckless decision to recognize Israel’s claims to Jerusalem as its capital, a break with nearly 70 years of policy. The State Department is advancing plans to erect an embassy building in Jerusalem partly on land stolen by Israel shortly after its establishment from Palestinian refugees, including American citizens.
snippet: The Biden administration is doubling down on a reckless Trump policy.

headline: Three Reasons the Republican Party Keeps Coming Apart at the Seams
abstract: Remember when it was ‘Democrats fall in love; Republicans fall in line'? Me neither.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the cliché in politics was that “Democrats fall in love and Republicans fall in line.” The Democratic Party was thought to be a loosely connected cluster of fractious interest groups often at war with itself. “I don’t belong to an organized political party,” Will Rogers famously said. “I’m a Democrat.” Republicans were considered the more cohesive political force.
snippet: Remember when it was ‘Democrats fall in love; Republicans fall in line'? Me neither.

headline: I Am Michelle Go’s Father. I Am Marking Her Death Where She Lived.
abstract: We pray that one day we see the New York that nurtured the love that Michelle had for life.
lead_paragraph: It has been exactly one year since the death of our daughter, Michelle Alyssa Go. On Saturday, Jan. 15, 2022, at around 9:30 a.m., Martial Simon viciously shoved Michelle in front of an oncoming subway train at the Times Square station. She was 40 years old.
snippet: We pray that one day we see the New York that nurtured the love that Michelle had for life.

headline: The Kind of Revolution That Martin Luther King Jr. Envisioned
abstract: His last Sunday sermon reminds us about the perils of not being woke.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, four days before he was shot on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his last Sunday sermon at the Washington National Cathedral in Washington, D.C. It was entitled, “Remaining Awake Through a Great Revolution,” and although King doesn’t say the word “woke,” he uses the concept as it was understood by many Black folks then, well before the term was co-opted by the political right to refer to any left-leaning policy that it wanted to condemn.
snippet: His last Sunday sermon reminds us about the perils of not being woke.

headline: A Revelatory Tour of Martin Luther King Jr.’s Forgotten Teachings
abstract: The political theorist Brandon Terry explores the nonviolent philosophy of Dr. King.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to think of a more celebrated figure of the 20th century than Martin Luther King Jr.
snippet: The political theorist Brandon Terry explores the nonviolent philosophy of Dr. King.

headline: America’s Must-Win Semiconductor War
abstract: One of the government’s largest forays into the private sector since World War II has its risks.
lead_paragraph: Intent on reversing America’s decline in the world’s production of cutting-edge semiconductors, the federal government has begun what is arguably the government’s largest foray into the private sector since World War II.
snippet: One of the government’s largest forays into the private sector since World War II has its risks.

subject: Computer Chips
Factories and Manufacturing
United States Economy

Public-Private Sector Cooperation

headline: The Crypto Collapse and the End of the Magical Thinking That Infected Capitalism
abstract: Dogecoin. WeWork. The Metaverse. It was an era of illusory and ridiculous promises.
lead_paragraph: At a guest lecture at a military academy when the price of a single Bitcoin neared $60,000, I was asked, as finance professors often are, what I thought about cryptocurrencies. Rather than respond with my usual skepticism, I polled the students. More than half of attendees had traded cryptocurrencies, often financed by loans.
snippet: Dogecoin. WeWork. The Metaverse. It was an era of illusory and ridiculous promises.

headline: And Now a Few Words About How Power Makes You Weird
abstract: From the royal family to the House of Representatives, it was a strange week.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I promise not to hold you accountable for everything the House Republicans try to do during the 118th Congress, but I do want to ask you about money.
snippet: From the royal family to the House of Representatives, it was a strange week.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: Will It Be Morning in Joe Biden’s America?
abstract: The economic “misery index” has fallen off a cliff.
lead_paragraph: If the midterm elections could be rerun this month, Democrats would probably end up in full control of Congress. President Biden’s approval ratings are rising. Inflation is down, and consumers are feeling more optimistic. And Americans are getting a better look at the G.O.P.’s actual policy agenda, which is deeply unpopular.
snippet: The economic “misery index” has fallen off a cliff.

headline: What if Diversity Training Is Doing More Harm Than Good?
abstract: It might even make things worse.
lead_paragraph: Diversity training has been around for decades, long before the country’s latest round of racial reckoning. But after George Floyd’s murder — as companies faced pressure to demonstrate a commitment to racial justice — interest in the diversity, equity and inclusion (D.E.I.) industry exploded. The American market reached an estimated $3.4 billion in 2020.
snippet: It might even make things worse.

headline: How Long Can Hakeem Jeffries Keep His Democratic Cats Herded?
abstract: How two things will test the comity Democrats enjoy today.
lead_paragraph: Kevin McCarthy, after 15 excruciating ballots, was finally elected speaker of the House, and if his path to leading a slim, ideologically volatile Republican majority is any indication, chaos will be in the offing for the next two years.
snippet: How two things will test the comity Democrats enjoy today.

headline: The Defenders of the Amazon Never Wanted to Be Martyrs
abstract: For too long, the fate of the rainforest has rested on the shoulders of environmental and human rights activists.
lead_paragraph: What I’d heard of a little Brazilian town on the eastern edge of the Amazon had prepared me for the worst. Criminality plagues many areas of Brazil, and the government’s presence remains feeble in the interior of the country. But even by that measure, the pace of homicides in the region is staggering. “It’s a risky town for a reporter,” said Danicley de Aguiar, a Greenpeace activist.
snippet: For too long, the fate of the rainforest has rested on the shoulders of environmental and human rights activists.
