headline: Russian Mercenaries Are Destabilizing Africa
abstract: Wagner’s reach extends far beyond the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: One of the groups that have risen to international prominence (or infamy) with the invasion of Ukraine is Wagner, a Kremlin-backed mercenary outfit that regularly employs former criminals. In Ukraine, they often fight when conventional Russian Army troops flee the battlefield, and they are noted for their brutality.
snippet: Wagner’s reach extends far beyond the war in Ukraine.

headline: What New Weight Loss Drugs Teach Us About Fat and Free Will
abstract: New weight loss drugs show us body size is not a choice.
lead_paragraph: In the girl’s home in Hertfordshire, England, you need a key code to enter the kitchen, where all the cupboards are under bolt and chain, and the garbage bin is locked shut. Without these measures, the child — whose name cannot be published because she’s currently in foster care — wouldn’t be able to stop eating, even scraps of raw meat or leftover pasta wasting away in the garbage.
snippet: New weight loss drugs show us body size is not a choice.

headline: Authorities Used a Taser on Him 7 Times in 15 Minutes. Then He Died. Justice Never Came.
abstract: For Jerod Draper, horrifying video footage wasn’t enough to force police accountability.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Jerod Draper, a 40-year-old father in southern Indiana high on methamphetamines, was arrested during a traffic stop and locked in a cell at a county jail. Several hours later, the man died.
snippet: For Jerod Draper, horrifying video footage wasn’t enough to force police accountability.

headline: The Police Cannot Be a Law Unto Themselves
abstract: Right now, the institution of American policing lies outside any meaningful democratic control.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, during the weeks of protest and civil unrest that followed the murder of George Floyd at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer, I argued that the problem of police violence and misconduct was a problem of democracy. And this week, in the wake of yet another police killing caught on camera, I think it’s worth saying, again, that the institution of American policing lies outside any meaningful democratic control.
snippet: Right now, the institution of American policing lies outside any meaningful democratic control.

headline: Ron DeSantis Wants to Erase Black History. Why?
abstract: This disturbing attempt to erase history is one of the most visible examples of performative white supremacy since the presidency of Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: An unrelenting assault on truth and freedom of expression in the form of laws that censor and suppress the viewpoints, histories and experiences of historically marginalized groups, especially Black and L.G.B.T.Q. communities, is underway throughout the country, most clearly in Florida. The state’s Department of Education recently rejected a pilot Advanced Placement African American studies course from being offered in Florida’s public high schools.
snippet: This disturbing attempt to erase history is one of the most visible examples of performative white supremacy since the presidency of Donald Trump.

headline: Stagflation or Soft Landing? It Depends Who You Ask.
abstract: Where the inflation debate stands now.
lead_paragraph: Let me start with a picture, which will help frame the debate I’m about to describe. Here’s official consumer price inflation, measured over the previous six months but converted to an annual rate, since the beginning of the Biden administration:
snippet: Where the inflation debate stands now.

headline: How Will Joe Biden Be Remembered in 50 Years?
abstract: He could be seen as the savior of the free world or as the man who came up short.
lead_paragraph: A half-century from now, Joe Biden’s presidency will be remembered, as most presidencies are, with a short summary sentence. It will read: “He defeated Donald Trump, and ____________.”
snippet: He could be seen as the savior of the free world or as the man who came up short.

headline: The Problem With Taking TikTok Away From Americans
abstract: A national ban on TikTok would not solve America’s data privacy problems.
lead_paragraph: A ban of TikTok throughout the United States, if it could actually be enacted, would immediately solve our national security concerns about the wildly popular Chinese-owned video app. But such a ban might ultimately put our national security at greater risk. Moreover, it would sidestep a broader problem — our nation’s overall failure to address concerns over the huge amount of personal data collected in our digital lives, especially when that data could be used by foreign adversaries.
snippet: A national ban on TikTok would not solve America’s data privacy problems.

headline: Be Open to Spiritual Experience. Also, Be Really Careful.
abstract: The reasonability and risks of metaphysical experimentation.
lead_paragraph: Pundits depend on categorizations, especially in periods of turbulence. We reach for labels like “populist” and “nationalist,” for instance, in order to generalize about the stirrings of millions of voters, even when many of them might better be described simply as experimenters — pulling different levers or swinging left to right without any certain goal except to conjure a new political experience.
snippet: The reasonability and risks of metaphysical experimentation.

headline: It’s as if Nothing Ever Happened Here in China
abstract: China left its vulnerable people to fend for themselves in a deadly Covid outbreak.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — I caught Covid for the first time in early December.
snippet: China left its vulnerable people to fend for themselves in a deadly Covid outbreak.

headline: How Much Longer Can ‘Vote Blue No Matter Who!’ Last?
abstract: “It’s important not to overstate the damage that some perceive liberalism as having done to the Democrats’ electoral fortunes,” one scholar says.
lead_paragraph: Over the past four decades, the percentage of white Democrats who identify themselves as liberal has more than doubled, growing at a much faster pace than Black or Hispanic Democrats.
snippet: “It’s important not to overstate the damage that some perceive liberalism as having done to the Democrats’ electoral fortunes,” one scholar says.

headline: Tired: Organized Fridges. Wired: Shoe Boxes in the Kitchen.
abstract: Julia Fox, Marie Kondo and a momfluencing vibe shift.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Julia Fox posted a TikTok tour of her New York City apartment that pretty quickly went viral. “I never thought in a million years I would do this, but I do believe in maximum transparency,” she says at the beginning of the video. “And I know I’m going to get roasted, and whatever, but hopefully maybe someone can watch this and be like, ‘OK, well, maybe I’m not doing so bad.’”
snippet: Julia Fox, Marie Kondo and a momfluencing vibe shift.

headline: Bon Voyage, Boeing 747. You Really Did Change Everything.
abstract: How the “Queen of the Skies” transformed air travel and our global community.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Some legends really are true, and indeed it is the case that two men on an Alaskan fishing trip in the mid-1960s struck a bargain that wound up starting the era of the jumbo jetliner, which democratized air travel in ways that are hard to appreciate today.
snippet: How the “Queen of the Skies” transformed air travel and our global community.

headline: The Dying Practice of Time and a Half
abstract: Employers inflate employee titles to dodge an important worker protection.
lead_paragraph: Time and a half for overtime is one of the best-known and most important protections for workers in the United States. Yet many employers routinely undermine the protection by misclassifying workers as managers and thereby making them ineligible for overtime pay.
snippet: Employers inflate employee titles to dodge an important worker protection.

headline: Israel’s Government Is Trying to Turn the Film Industry Into a Propaganda Arm
abstract: Documentary films have long been a way of holding the Israeli government to task. Some elected officials don’t want that to continue.
lead_paragraph: The West Bank city of Hebron, less than an hour’s drive from Jerusalem, is a unique place: the only Palestinian town in which Jewish settlers live among the local residents, and not in separate communities.
snippet: Documentary films have long been a way of holding the Israeli government to task. Some elected officials don’t want that to continue.

headline: Inclusive or Alienating? The Language Wars Go On
abstract: New vocabulary is supposed to be supportive. But terms like “bodies with vaginas” just antagonize voters and empower the right.
lead_paragraph: Before the millions of views, the subsequent ridicule and finally the earnest apology, The Associated Press Stylebook practically oozed good intentions in its tweet last week:
snippet: New vocabulary is supposed to be supportive. But terms like “bodies with vaginas” just antagonize voters and empower the right.

headline: This Is a Moral Crime
abstract: Grieving loved ones in public isn’t normal, yet families do it valiantly.
lead_paragraph: When RowVaughn Wells arrived at Mississippi Boulevard Christian Church on an icy, gray Wednesday in Memphis, she was there to say goodbye to her son Tyre Nichols. He was dead. Killed. Beaten to death by local police officers while he screamed for her less than 100 yards from her house.
snippet: Grieving loved ones in public isn’t normal, yet families do it valiantly.

headline: Go See What Happened to My City, Then You’ll Know How I Am
abstract: Homs was the capital of the Syrian revolution. Now it is a footnote, but not to me.
lead_paragraph: Homs is the name of my city.
snippet: Homs was the capital of the Syrian revolution. Now it is a footnote, but not to me.

headline: The Teenager Leading the Smartphone Liberation Movement
abstract: Logan Lane gave up her smartphone. That changed her life.
lead_paragraph: How many hours do you spend on your phone each day? Probably more than you’d like. In our technology-saturated world, we rely on our devices for what feels like an endless list of daily tasks — everything from staying up-to-date on Twitter to killing time at the post office. The idea of reclaiming any degree of independence from our smartphones can often feel impossible.
snippet: Logan Lane gave up her smartphone. That changed her life.

author.Original: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Rhiannon Corby, Anabel Bacon, Kaari Pitkin, Stephanie Joyce, Carole Sabouraud, Isaac Jones, Sonia Herrero and Pat McCusker
author.People: Garcia-Navarro Lulu, Corby Rhiannon, Bacon Anabel, Pitkin Kaari, Joyce Stephanie, Sabouraud Carole, Jones Isaac, Herrero Sonia, McCusker Pat

headline: A Century On, the Search for the Real Franz Kafka Continues
abstract: Translating Kafka’s diaries revealed a writer even more alive than English-language readers previously knew.
lead_paragraph: The first time Franz Kafka’s voice entered my head, I was 15. Two new friends I’d made through our shared interest in literature had introduced me to his fiction, and we took turns reading the Willa and Edwin Muir translations to each other in the high school library. I distinctly recall the three of us reading “The Judgment” aloud and bursting out laughing at the passage when the protagonist discovers his father’s underwear is unclean and again when his father stands up on the bed to berate him.
snippet: Translating Kafka’s diaries revealed a writer even more alive than English-language readers previously knew.

headline: Five Years Ago, I Wrote a Fictional Disaster That Is Now Playing Out in Real Time
abstract: The battle over South River Forest has turned violent.
lead_paragraph: What could make a person die for trees?
snippet: The battle over South River Forest has turned violent.

author.Original: By Richard Powers and Joshua Dudley Greer

headline: Over 75,000 Job Openings in Iowa Alone. Millions of Refugees Seeking Work. Make the Connection.
abstract: Immigration reform is hard. Here are three ideas that could help.
lead_paragraph: Across the globe, 32.5 million refugees are seeking safety, many of them adults in search of work. At the same time, severe labor shortages in the United States and many other high-income countries have left businesses clamoring for workers.
snippet: Immigration reform is hard. Here are three ideas that could help.

author.Original: By Kristie De Peña, Robert Leonard and David Oman
author.People: De Peña Kristie, Leonard Robert, Oman David

headline: Why Are So Many Americans Dying Right Now?
abstract: Where are the country’s quite large numbers of deaths actually coming from?
lead_paragraph: About 1.1 million Americans have officially died from Covid-19 since the start of the pandemic, a number that may be familiar by now. But here’s a less familiar one: According to one tabulation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than 300,000 additional Americans have died over the past three years whom we would not have expected to in more normal times.
snippet: Where are the country’s quite large numbers of deaths actually coming from?

headline: Republicans and Debt: Blackmailers Without a Cause
abstract: Why this debt ceiling crisis is different from the last one.
lead_paragraph: Stop me if you’ve heard this before: Two years after a Democratic president took office and pushed ambitious policies through Congress, Republicans have regained control of the House. They don’t have the votes required to repeal the president’s achievements, but a quirk of U.S. law — which requires that Congress vote a second time to authorize the borrowing that results from already enacted spending and tax legislation — seems to give them an opportunity to engage in blackmail, threatening to create a financial crisis unless their demands are met.
snippet: Why this debt ceiling crisis is different from the last one.

headline: In the Age of A.I., Major in Being Human
abstract: How to acquire the skills no machine can have.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, a piece of artwork generated with artificial intelligence took a first prize at the Colorado State Fair. To me, the image looks like a view from the back of the stage at an opera. You see the backs of three singers, then, past them, vague squiggles and forms that may or may not be an audience, and all around, dominating everything, the fantastical Lord of the Rings-style palace where they are performing.
snippet: How to acquire the skills no machine can have.

headline: The Decisive Test for Germany Is Still to Come
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s strategy of caution surely won’t hold.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — After months of indecision, hand-wringing and uncertainty, Germany last week committed to send Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine. The delay was a measure of the decision’s significance. For a country long wary of active military involvement in conflicts, the release of its most advanced war machine for battle with Russian troops is momentous. A taboo has been shed.
snippet: Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s strategy of caution surely won’t hold.

headline: ‘The Last of Us’ Is a Very Conservative Show. Really.
abstract: The right should love its view of masculinity, the government and what it takes to survive.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of the achingly poignant, much-discussed third episode of “The Last of Us,” HBO’s new zombie dystopia series, there’s an earnest ode to traditional masculinity. Bill, a taciturn survivalist, leaves a letter for the show’s hero, Joel, to open after his death. In it, Bill writes of his longtime love, Frank, “I saved him. Then I protected him. That’s why men like you and me are here. We have a job to do.”
snippet: The right should love its view of masculinity, the government and what it takes to survive.

headline: How to Turn a Boring Speech Into Something Americans Will Actually Want to Watch
abstract: Without an evolutionary leap to bring it into the modern era, it will become a relic.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will deliver his State of the Union address on Feb. 7, and two things are guaranteed: He’ll declare the state of the union strong, and that’s all you’ll remember on Feb. 8. This has nothing to do with Mr. Biden’s oratory. The State of the Union is the last great regular communication opportunity in American politics, but its power shrivels every year because the mode of presentation is obsolete. Where else in modern life does someone try to rally people around his or her ideas with a constantly interrupted, visually desolate, 60-minute rant? Fine, the Joe Rogan podcast, but you can’t name a second.
snippet: Without an evolutionary leap to bring it into the modern era, it will become a relic.

headline: There’s Already a Better Search Engine Than Google. It’s YouTube.
abstract: Silicon Valley is wondering whether ChatGPT will replace Google as the internet’s main source of information. For many topics, YouTube already has.
lead_paragraph: Will ChatGPT kill Google?
snippet: Silicon Valley is wondering whether ChatGPT will replace Google as the internet’s main source of information. For many topics, YouTube already has.

headline: ‘Hip Hip Hooray!’ Cheering News for Free Speech on Campus
abstract: Stanford University steps back from its list of “harmful” words and phrases.
lead_paragraph: The following is a celebration of the cancellation of the Elimination of Harmful Language Initiative, an attempt by a committee of I.T. leaders at Stanford University to ban 161 common words and phrases. Of those 161 phrases, I have taken pains to use 45 of them here. Read at your own risk.
snippet: Stanford University steps back from its list of “harmful” words and phrases.

headline: One Day They’ll Say This Was the Best (and Worst) Thing I Ever Made
abstract: It started with smirk and ended with a bang, and in between it changed the media universe.
lead_paragraph: “What’s one thing that’s true about you that no one else would believe?” is a recurring prompt on Twitter. I like to respond that I started a website that made a billionaire vampire so angry, he deployed about $10 million — and a professional wrestler — to destroy it. All of this is true, except Peter Thiel is not technically a vampire.
snippet: It started with smirk and ended with a bang, and in between it changed the media universe.

headline: Where American Democracy Isn’t Very Democratic
abstract: The problem of democracy and American law enforcement goes beyond questions of accountability.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I wrote that American policing lies largely outside of democratic control. In practice, despite the formal authority of mayors, city councilors and other elected officials, police departments can and do operate without meaningful accountability or public oversight.
snippet: The problem of democracy and American law enforcement goes beyond questions of accountability.

headline: An Even Deadlier Pandemic Could Soon Be Here
abstract: Bird flu has spread widely among animals. Unless we act now, it soon could do the same among humans.
lead_paragraph: As the world is just beginning to recover from the devastation of Covid-19, it is facing the possibility of a pandemic of a far more deadly pathogen.
snippet: Bird flu has spread widely among animals. Unless we act now, it soon could do the same among humans.

headline: Trump Needs a Confrontation. His G.O.P. Rivals Don’t Have to Give Him One.
abstract: For now, allowing the former president to fade is wiser than attacking him.
lead_paragraph: Just before Christmas, I wrote a column warning about the disappointment many may feel if Donald Trump exits the political stage with a relative whimper — by losing a Republican presidential primary to a figure like Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and then simply dimming, the way ex-presidents normally do, instead of going out with a supernova’s spectacle.
snippet: For now, allowing the former president to fade is wiser than attacking him.

headline: Wonking Out: Is the Dollar’s Dominance Under Threat?
abstract: And does it matter for anything real?
lead_paragraph: Is the U.S. dollar at risk of losing its position of international dominance? I’ve been seeing some breathless speculation to that effect over the past few weeks; I’ll talk about the sources of that speculation in a minute. But let me first note that this isn’t a new question. Indeed, I wrote about it at length a few years back.
snippet: And does it matter for anything real?

headline: Do Handouts Work?
abstract: A debate rages over how much the poor benefit from straight cash donations.
lead_paragraph: Josephy Amosi Kamanga, who lives in Malawi, couldn’t afford to pay the examination fee for his eldest child, so she dropped out of school two years ago. She later got pregnant and is living at home. The fee that changed his daughter’s life? Just $4.98.
snippet: A debate rages over how much the poor benefit from straight cash donations.

headline: Seeing Myself in the Work of an Artist I Never Met
abstract: I never met Kimowan Metchewais, but I feel a kinship with him and his work.
lead_paragraph: There’s a basic understanding that Native people who straddle life inside and outside the reservation share: We can carry our culture with us where ever we go, but also have perspective outside of it.
snippet: I never met Kimowan Metchewais, but I feel a kinship with him and his work.

headline: Just Often Enough, the Grammys Get It Right
abstract: It’s disappointing that the big awards show doesn’t reflect all of music’s immediacy and vibrancy and messiness. But the Grammys still function as a measure of change.
lead_paragraph: My teenage take on awards shows was informed by a punk rock worldview: The winners were losers. The Grammys? Isn’t that where everyone dresses like Liberace and glad-hands the press on a red carpet?
snippet: It’s disappointing that the big awards show doesn’t reflect all of music’s immediacy and vibrancy and messiness. But the Grammys still function as a measure of change.

headline: Maybe We Should Convince Men That Paid Leave Is Their Idea
abstract: The Family and Medical Leave Act turns 30 this year. Time for an upgrade.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Reisman spent her career pushing for a better system of child care in America. She was the executive director of the (now defunct) Child Care Action Campaign from 1986 to 1997. If you want to see her in action, you can watch her on C-SPAN speaking at hearings for the Act for Better Child Care Services of 1988 — if nothing else, the grainy footage is a powerful reminder that our foremothers were fighting the good fight on child care when I was, well, still a child.
snippet: The Family and Medical Leave Act turns 30 this year. Time for an upgrade.

headline: Erasing Black History Is Not the Role of the College Board
abstract: The way forward is confronting this history, not wishing it away.
lead_paragraph: In the nation’s capital, blocks from the White House, scores of sharply dressed Americans mingled Thursday night over cocktails and collard greens, a glittering coming-out party for the College Board’s first advanced placement course in African American studies.
snippet: The way forward is confronting this history, not wishing it away.

headline: George Santos Plays Hideout
abstract: How invisible can a congressman become?
snippet: How invisible can a congressman become?

headline: Spy Cams Show What the Pork Industry Tries to Hide
abstract: A California activist sneaked into a gas chamber for hogs and installed three cameras. See for yourself what they show.
lead_paragraph: The hog industry hails the gas chambers in which pigs are prepared for slaughter as “animal friendly,” “stress free” and “painless.” That would be a good thing, since on average, four pigs are slaughtered each second in the United States.
snippet: A California activist sneaked into a gas chamber for hogs and installed three cameras. See for yourself what they show.

headline: They Were Proud Houston Homeowners. Then It All Fell Apart.
abstract: Five years after Hurricane Harvey destroyed their home, Becca and Sergio Fuentes are still rebuilding their lives.
lead_paragraph: The house was supposed to last the Fuentes family for the rest of their lives. They barely got a few years with it.
snippet: Five years after Hurricane Harvey destroyed their home, Becca and Sergio Fuentes are still rebuilding their lives.

headline: How We Construct and Reconstruct Race
abstract: The ideology of race and its consequences change as we change.
lead_paragraph: I wrote both my columns this week on policing and democracy. My second column drew from a 2017 paper, “Police Are Our Government: Politics, Political Science, and the Policing of Race-Class Subjugated Communities” by the political scientists Joe Soss and Vesla Weaver. I tried, as much as I could, to summarize and explain the main beats of the article, but there was one important point I chose to omit and leave for the newsletter because it speaks to an idea I’ve tried to emphasize in my work at The Times, and I thought it deserved a little more time and attention than I would have been able to give in the column.
snippet: The ideology of race and its consequences change as we change.

headline: The Costs of a Long War in Ukraine
abstract: Why the Biden White House needs to push for peace in 2023.
lead_paragraph: The next phase of the Ukraine War, a new Russian offensive and a potential Ukrainian counteroffensive, seems all but inevitable for late winter or early spring. The logic of escalation is prevailing, the mutual belief that no peace deal is possible until the other side understands that it can’t win.
snippet: Why the Biden White House needs to push for peace in 2023.

headline: Doctors Aren’t Burned Out From Overwork. We’re Demoralized by Our Health System.
abstract: The end of medical ideology.
lead_paragraph: Doctors have long diagnosed many of our sickest patients with “demoralization syndrome,” a condition commonly associated with terminal illness that’s characterized by a sense of helplessness and loss of purpose. American physicians are now increasingly suffering from a similar condition, except our demoralization is not a reaction to a medical condition, but rather to the diseased systems for which we work.
snippet: The end of medical ideology.

headline: Don’t Let Republican ‘Judge Shoppers’ Thwart the Will of Voters
abstract: How some red-state lawsuits are undermining major features of President Biden’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: For the 26th time in two years, Ken Paxton, Texas’ attorney general, recently filed a lawsuit in federal court challenging a Biden administration policy. The suit, which seeks to wipe out a new Labor Department rule about the investment of pension trust assets, wasn’t filed in Austin, the state capital, or in Dallas, where the Labor Department’s regional offices are, or anywhere else with a logical connection to the dispute.
snippet: How some red-state lawsuits are undermining major features of President Biden’s agenda.

headline: ‘Bad Apples’ or Systemic Issues?
abstract: From the police to academia, we often see what we want to see.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the city of Memphis remembered the life of Tyre Nichols, a young man who was beaten by at least five Memphis police officers and died three days later. Stories like this are terrible, they’re relentless, and they renew one of the most contentious debates in the nation: Are there deep and systemic problems with the American police?
snippet: From the police to academia, we often see what we want to see.

headline: YouTube Gave Me Everything. Then I Grew Up.
abstract: I don’t want my life to be a product anymore.
lead_paragraph: My life so far has often been distilled to numbers: 1.7 million subscribers, 1.8 million total followers, 155 million views. At 12 years old, I started posting videos on YouTube. In November, at 24, I quit.
snippet: I don’t want my life to be a product anymore.

headline: The Story Construction Tells About America’s Economy Is Disturbing
abstract: Why was America — and not just America — better at building in the 1970s?
lead_paragraph: Here’s something odd: We’re getting worse at construction. Think of the technology we have today that we didn’t in the 1970s. The new generations of power tools and computer modeling and teleconferencing and advanced machinery and prefab materials and global shipping. You’d think we could build much more, much faster, for less money, than in the past. But we can’t. Or, at least, we don’t.
snippet: Why was America — and not just America — better at building in the 1970s?

headline: The Astonishing Moral Beauty of the Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth and the Black Church
abstract: Loving your enemies has always been a radical act.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, a pastor in Birmingham, Ala., in the 1950s, was called by the historian Andrew Manis “one of the least known but most impactful figures in the civil rights movement.” Shuttlesworth was a close friend and colleague of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., but nearly his opposite in personality — boisterous, direct and exuberant by nature. In his obituary, The Times contrasted the two men, saying: “Where Dr. King could deliver thunderous oratory and move audiences by his reasoned convictions and faith, Mr. Shuttlesworth was fiery.” He was, the author Diane McWhorter told The Times, “King’s most effective and insistent foil: blunt where King was soothing, driven where King was leisurely, and most important, confrontational where King was conciliatory.” The segregationist commissioner of public safety in Birmingham, Bull Connor, saw Shuttlesworth as his nemesis. When asked about chest injuries Shuttlesworth incurred from being sprayed by a fire hose at close range during a peaceful protest, Connor told The Times: “I wish they’d carried him away in a hearse.”
snippet: Loving your enemies has always been a radical act.

headline: Year Two of the Ukraine War Is Going to Get Scary
abstract: In the war’s first year, America and its allies have had it relatively easy. Will the West bear any burden to uphold a liberal world order?
lead_paragraph: As we approach the first anniversary of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine — and the ferocious Ukrainian response backed by a U.S.-led Western coalition — the following question urgently needs answering: How is it that on Feb. 23, 2022, virtually no one in America was arguing that it was in our core national interest to enter into an indirect war with Russia to stop it from overrunning Ukraine, a country most Americans couldn’t find on a map in 10 tries? And yet now, nearly a year later, polls show solid (though slightly shrinking) American majorities for backing Ukraine with arms and aid, even though this risks a direct conflict with Vladimir Putin’s Russia.
snippet: In the war’s first year, America and its allies have had it relatively easy. Will the West bear any burden to uphold a liberal world order?

headline: The Night of 1,000 Eye Rolls
abstract: Who will cause trouble? Who will surprise us? And who will come away liking what Joe Biden is selling?
lead_paragraph: Get that popcorn ready, people. It’s State of the Union week!
snippet: Who will cause trouble? Who will surprise us? And who will come away liking what Joe Biden is selling?

headline: What It’s Like to Learn You’re Going to Live Longer Than You Expected
abstract: Cystic fibrosis patients had early deaths. But a drug treatment has changed the prognosis.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if you knew, from your earliest awareness, that you were unlikely to live beyond your 20s. You would finish high school, but what about college? Would you allow yourself to fall in love? How much would you invest in a future that you might never see?
snippet: Cystic fibrosis patients had early deaths. But a drug treatment has changed the prognosis.

headline: Politicians Everywhere All at Once
abstract: It’s a big week in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. President Biden will give his State of the Union address on Tuesday. I’m going to watch it as a professional obligation. But to be honest, I’m about as excited about it as I am for the Oscars, at least in its more recent incarnation. I just hope Lauren Boebert doesn’t go after Biden the way Will Smith went for Chris Rock.
snippet: It’s a big week in Washington.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: If You Plan Well, Carrying Out the Task Should Be Swift
abstract: How certain principles can (almost) guarantee success.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s, the Boeing 747 was regarded as a huge risk that had the potential to bring down Boeing itself. “The airplane was so different that each component had to be designed from scratch,” according to a National Air and Space Museum video. It needed its own factory, which had to be built while design was still underway. It had to accommodate either passengers or freight, which would be loaded through a nose that swung upward on hinges. And time was of the essence.
snippet: How certain principles can (almost) guarantee success.

subject: AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES
Books and Literature
Factories and Manufacturing

headline: Revisiting the Summer of Stagflation
abstract: How about: Why have economic pessimists gotten it so wrong?
lead_paragraph: I don’t know whether there will be any surprises in the State of the Union address. I do know that the background to the speech will be very different from what a great majority of pundits expected just a few months ago.
snippet: How about: Why have economic pessimists gotten it so wrong?

headline: Biden’s a Great President. He Should Not Run Again.
abstract: Democratic voters are right to worry about 2024.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden gives his State of the Union address on Tuesday, he will have a lot to boast about.
snippet: Democratic voters are right to worry about 2024.

headline: The Memories I Ran From Found Me
abstract: A filmmaker revisits his time in Cuba to tell a story he left unfinished.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, I lived in San Antonio de los Baños, Cuba, and was pursuing my master’s in alternative cinema. I was struggling to find the story I wanted to tell for my thesis film. To distract myself, I played soccer every afternoon with a group of young locals. Inspired by those meet-ups and with no clear narrative direction, I set out to document them, trusting that eventually, those soccer games would inspire a film.
snippet: A filmmaker revisits his time in Cuba to tell a story he left unfinished.

headline: How Liberals — Yes, Liberals — Are Hobbling Government
abstract: The legal scholar Nicholas Bagley argues that the liberal “procedural fetish” makes it difficult for government to accomplish anything bold.
lead_paragraph: In my columns and on this show over the past few years, I’ve argued that to achieve the goals liberals hold most dear, we need a liberalism that builds. A liberalism that builds everything from multifamily housing and mass transit systems to transmission lines and solar farms. And we need a liberalism that can build it all quickly, cheaply and effectively. But even in the places where liberals have governing power, they are often failing to do exactly that. Why?
snippet: The legal scholar Nicholas Bagley argues that the liberal “procedural fetish” makes it difficult for government to accomplish anything bold.

headline: Our City Could Become One of the World’s Greenest, but It Won’t Be Easy
abstract: Cutting greenhouse gas emissions from big buildings will help the economy and make New York a nicer place to live.
lead_paragraph: Rules are being drafted to guide compliance with a 2019 New York City law that requires most of about 50,000 buildings, many over 25,000 square feet, to cut their greenhouse gas emissions by 40 percent by the end of this decade and to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.
snippet: Cutting greenhouse gas emissions from big buildings will help the economy and make New York a nicer place to live.

author.Original: By Paul Greenberg and Gernot Wagner

headline: Russia and Ukraine Have Incentives to Negotiate. The U.S. Has Other Plans.
abstract: The Biden administration is escalating the war.
lead_paragraph: The United States’ recent promise to ship advanced M1 Abrams battle tanks to Ukraine was a swift response to a serious problem. The problem is that Ukraine is losing the war. Not, as far as we can tell, because its soldiers are fighting poorly or its people have lost heart, but because the war has settled into a World War I-style battle of attrition, complete with carefully dug trenches and relatively stable fronts.
snippet: The Biden administration is escalating the war.

headline: Dancing With America Has Been a Curse for the Philippines
abstract: The news that the U.S. military is planning to expand its presence in the Philippines has been dizzying and wounding.
lead_paragraph: For Filipinos like me who grew up under the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos Sr., the news that the U.S. military would expand its presence in the Philippines has been dizzying and wounding.
snippet: The news that the U.S. military is planning to expand its presence in the Philippines has been dizzying and wounding.

subject: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States International Relations

headline: This Is Biden’s Chance to Tell Us Exactly What the Supreme Court Has Done
abstract: Why the president needs to use his bully pulpit.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has been conspicuously quiet on the topic of the Supreme Court. Even as there’s an active debate about what to do about a court that has too often exceeded the bounds of its authority, he has avoided regular criticism of it.
snippet: Why the president needs to use his bully pulpit.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Nicholas Bagley
abstract: The Feb. 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Nicholas Bagley. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Feb. 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the Queen of Having It Both Ways
abstract: The Arkansas governor perfectly reflects the moral compromises of her party.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.
snippet: The Arkansas governor perfectly reflects the moral compromises of her party.

headline: Police Brutality Is Not Always About Race
abstract: The killing of Tyre Nichols is a reminder that even the most horrific injustices are often complicated.
lead_paragraph: The brutal killing of Tyre Nichols by Memphis cops horrified and infuriated many Americans, not least because it was another in what has been an endless litany of Black men and boys killed by police officers in America: George Floyd, Eric Garner, Philando Castile, Tamir Rice, Michael Brown and literally thousands of names less well known. There is one confounding detail in Nichols’s death, however. The five policemen who mercilessly beat the life out of him were all Black.
snippet: The killing of Tyre Nichols is a reminder that even the most horrific injustices are often complicated.

headline: Regulation, Productivity and the Meaning of Life
abstract: Safety and environmental rules may reduce gross domestic product. But maybe that’s OK.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago The Times published a very interesting column by my colleague Ezra Klein about America’s peculiar lack of progress in the art of building things. Drawing on a recent paper by Austan Goolsbee and Chad Syverson, he noted that at least according to official statistics, we’ve gone a half century without any rise whatsoever, and maybe even a decline, in construction productivity — basically the number of person-hours it takes to build a house or other structure of a given size.
snippet: Safety and environmental rules may reduce gross domestic product. But maybe that’s OK.

headline: How Earthquakes Test Our Souls and Our Governments
abstract: What I lived through as a boy in Mexico City and what it could foretell for Turkey and Syria.
lead_paragraph: In every life there are a few indelible dates: the birth of a child, the death of a parent, a national tragedy such as 9/11.
snippet: What I lived through as a boy in Mexico City and what it could foretell for Turkey and Syria.

headline: Biden’s Message: What Trump Promised, I’m Delivering
abstract: But there were also reminders of the forces that can’t be mastered by infrastructure spending, China bashing and appropriations of populist themes.
lead_paragraph: In 2016 Donald Trump ran for president against his fellow Republicans and then against Hillary Clinton by promising economic nationalism: a break with the bipartisan enthusiasm for globalization, an end to outsourcing, a manufacturing revival, new infrastructure spending, frank competition with China instead of friendly integration.
snippet: But there were also reminders of the forces that can’t be mastered by infrastructure spending, China bashing and appropriations of populist themes.

headline: Germany Has a Problem
abstract: A reckoning with the far right is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the heat of debate about Germany sending tanks to Ukraine, it’s easy to forget that just two months ago, the authorities arrested 25 people for planning a radical right-wing coup to overthrow the German government.
snippet: A reckoning with the far right is long overdue.

headline: Madonna’s New Face Is a Brilliant Provocation
abstract: Some fans cheered, others scowled, but the queen of reinvention may have laughed last.
lead_paragraph: With blond braids looped over her ears, dressed in a long black skirt and black jacket accessorized with a riding crop, one of the best-selling female recording artists of all time stepped into the spotlight at the 65th annual Grammy Awards Sunday night. Madonna was there to introduce Sam Smith and Kim Petras, a nonbinary performer and a trans woman. She began by referring to her four decades in the music industry, and praised the rebels “forging a new path and taking the heat for all of it.”
snippet: Some fans cheered, others scowled, but the queen of reinvention may have laughed last.

headline: Would You Have Four Kids if It Meant Never Paying Taxes Again?
abstract: Countries around the world are trying to raise fertility rates. Will anything work?
lead_paragraph: Eagle-eyed readers may notice we’re dropping “On Parenting” from this newsletter’s title. Don’t worry: I’ll still be analyzing the health, economics and culture of the American family. I’m just expanding my coverage area to include adjacent topics about the way we live now that don’t always involve parenting, like health, wellness, celebrity and internet culture, evolving ideas about etiquette, shifting workplace norms and, as we approach a presidential election cycle, a few thoughts on politics. (As always, if you have questions, topics or ideas you want explored, drop me a line here.)
snippet: Countries around the world are trying to raise fertility rates. Will anything work?

headline: The World’s Biggest Democracy Is Jettisoning Freedom and Tolerance
abstract: The soul of a majestic nation is at stake.
lead_paragraph: When I moved to New Delhi in 2009 to work as a foreign correspondent, there was already a decade’s worth of magazine covers heralding the inevitable, just-around-the-corner but not-quite-yet-here rise of India to the top table of the global order and its role as a democratic counterweight to China. Usually they included an elephant or perhaps a tiger or a woman in a shimmering sari. The messy problems of multiethnic democracy, a tangled bureaucracy shot through with corruption, the great difficulty of dragging hundreds of millions of people out of poverty — these would all be overcome through ingenuity, technology and India’s relentless spirit of progress. The cyclical nature of these magazine covers brought to mind the famous quip about Brazil: India was the country of the future and always would be.
snippet: The soul of a majestic nation is at stake.

headline: Meet the People Working on Getting Us to Hate One Another Less
abstract: As the threat to democratic norms and procedures mounts, there has been an explosion of research aimed at lowering the political temperature.
lead_paragraph: Affective polarization — “a poisonous cocktail of othering, aversion and moralization” — has prompted an explosion of research as the threat to democratic norms and procedures mounts.
snippet: As the threat to democratic norms and procedures mounts, there has been an explosion of research aimed at lowering the political temperature.

headline: This Winter, More Than Ever, We’re Skiing Straight to Hell
abstract: Will I deny my child the pleasure of a winter sport in what could be its final seasons?
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When I saw news photos of the bare slopes of the Alps’ storied ski resorts a few weeks ago, I felt relief. The green and brown mountains of Garmisch-Partenkirchen in Bavaria, where my family has skied at the Garmisch Classic ski resort for years, were a dismal sight, yes. But the snowless scene also warmed my heart: I had an excuse not to take my 12-year-old son downhill skiing during his school break.
snippet: Will I deny my child the pleasure of a winter sport in what could be its final seasons?

headline: A ‘$10 Quintillion’ Asteroid
abstract: NASA plans to explore Psyche, an asteroid made of iron, nickel and we don’t know what else.
lead_paragraph: Lindy Elkins-Tanton is leading a NASA mission to explore an asteroid rich with metals  supposedly worth $10 quintillion that’s orbiting the sun between Mars and Jupiter. The asteroid’s name is Psyche, after the Greek goddess of the soul.
snippet: NASA plans to explore Psyche, an asteroid made of iron, nickel and we don’t know what else.

headline: Greta Thunberg: ‘The World Is Getting More Grim by the Day’
abstract: Why the world’s most prominent climate activist remains disappointed with people in power.
lead_paragraph: There is genuinely no precedent in the modern history of geopolitics for the climate activist Greta Thunberg.
snippet: Why the world’s most prominent climate activist remains disappointed with people in power.

headline: Biden’s Vision About How to Heal America
abstract: Standing up to China is about addressing domestic pathologies, not pulverizing a balloon.
lead_paragraph: Just a few days ago, the United States was in a national tizzy about a balloon.
snippet: Standing up to China is about addressing domestic pathologies, not pulverizing a balloon.

headline: Congress Is Investing in Alternatives to Police. Can They Work?
abstract: With both violent crime and police brutality on Americans’ minds, there is a hunger for alternative approaches to public safety.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
snippet: With both violent crime and police brutality on Americans’ minds, there is a hunger for alternative approaches to public safety.

headline: Dead Men at the State of the Union
abstract: The State of the Union commemorated Tyre Nichols, and attendees recalled Henry Truman, an early victim of police violence.
lead_paragraph: There were dead men at the State of the Union.
snippet: The State of the Union commemorated Tyre Nichols, and attendees recalled Henry Truman, an early victim of police violence.

headline: Your Height — and Your Children’s Height — Shouldn’t Matter
abstract: It’s time to end the tyranny of tallness.
lead_paragraph: Would you be a few inches taller if you could? The answer may depend on your gender and how much you’ve dreamed of being a professional athlete. But few people would say they want to be shorter — and Mara Altman wants to know why.
snippet: It’s time to end the tyranny of tallness.

author.Original: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Derek Arthur, Sophia Alvarez Boyd, Stephanie Joyce, Kaari Pitkin, Pat McCusker, Isaac Jones and Carole Sabouraud
author.People: Garcia-Navarro Lulu, Arthur Derek, Boyd Sophia, Joyce Stephanie, Pitkin Kaari, McCusker Pat, Jones Isaac, Sabouraud Carole

headline: What Liberals Can Learn From Ron DeSantis
abstract: Let’s not make the same mistake again.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything liberals can do about Ron DeSantis other than quietly seethe, loudly condemn him every time he makes headlines and hope that his political flaws — his distaste for glad-handing, his less-than-inspiring public speaking style, his conspicuous unlikability — will take him down before he gets anywhere close to the presidency? It would be tempting to write off DeSantis, the bombastic Republican governor of Florida, as another unelectable right-wing lunatic unfit for national office.
snippet: Let’s not make the same mistake again.

headline: How Do You Serve a Friend in Despair?
abstract: I learned hard lessons when my oldest friend, Pete, plunged into depression.
lead_paragraph: My friendship with Peter Marks was created around play. Starting at age 11, we played basketball, softball, capture the flag, rugby. We teased each other, pulled pranks, made fun of each other’s dance moves and pretty much everything else. We could turn eating a burger into a form of play, with elaborate smacking of lips and operatic exclamations about the excellence of the cheese. We kept it up for five decades.
snippet: I learned hard lessons when my oldest friend, Pete, plunged into depression.

headline: What I Know About Married Bliss I Learned From My Husband’s Twin
abstract: Togetherness didn’t come naturally to me. But it can be learned.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my family never had much patience for “we liked it” people, those couples who use the royal “we” as though their relationship were its own fief. For instance, the husband who, when asked, “What did you think of the show?” responds, “Oh, we liked it.” The rule was that when one of these couples came to dinner, we had to contain ourselves until they were on the front walk — then my siblings and I would start in.
snippet: Togetherness didn’t come naturally to me. But it can be learned.

headline: This Is What Happened When the Authorities Put Trump Under a Microscope
abstract: Read together, the three major investigations of his presidency tell a story.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, the Mueller report was a cry for help.
snippet: Read together, the three major investigations of his presidency tell a story.

headline: Sanctions Against Russia Ignore the Economic Challenges Facing Ukraine
abstract: Sanctions are a diversion from the economic struggle that truly matters in this conflict.
lead_paragraph: ​​In December 2021, President Biden warned President Vladimir Putin of Russia that any incursion into Ukrainian territory would entail “economic consequences like none he has ever seen.” America and its European allies followed through on this threat with the largest scale economic sanctions effort in recent history.
snippet: Sanctions are a diversion from the economic struggle that truly matters in this conflict.

headline: We’re Not Being Cruel, President Biden. Just Careful.
abstract: The risk of running for re-election at the age of 80 can’t be ignored.
lead_paragraph: Messages don’t come any more mixed.
snippet: The risk of running for re-election at the age of 80 can’t be ignored.

headline: How to Destroy (What’s Left of) the Mainstream Media’s Credibility
abstract: Objectivity is a hard standard, but good journalism can’t do without it.
lead_paragraph: It is hardly a secret within America’s newsrooms that our profession has lost much of the public’s trust. Gallup, which has polled “Confidence in Institutions” for decades, found that, as of last summer, just 16 percent of Americans had either a “great deal” or “quite a lot” of confidence in newspapers — down from 25 percent a decade earlier and 35 percent in 2002. For TV news, the latest results were even worse. Eleven percent of Americans trust it. Fifty-three percent don’t.
snippet: Objectivity is a hard standard, but good journalism can’t do without it.

headline: War Is Peace, Freedom Is Slavery, Democrats Are Radicals
abstract: Who’s obsessed with culture wars? Not the Dems.
lead_paragraph: Political speeches, very much including State of the Union addresses, rarely make much difference. They can, however, be useful guides to the political landscape.
snippet: Who’s obsessed with culture wars? Not the Dems.

headline: The Tao of Rick Rubin
abstract: The legendary music producer shares practices for cultivating creativity and a more open mind.
lead_paragraph: Reading Rick Rubin’s production discography is like taking a tour through the commanding heights of American music over the past few decades. Jay-Z. Run-DMC. Beastie Boys. Slayer. The Red Hot Chili Peppers. Johnny Cash. Kanye West. Neil Diamond. Brandi Carlile. Eminem. Adele. And it’s not just his production credits: Rubin co-founded Def Jam Recordings and was a co-chairman of Columbia Records. What’s allowed him to work with so many different kinds of artists, across such a stunning range of genres, so successfully?
snippet: The legendary music producer shares practices for cultivating creativity and a more open mind.

headline: My Chinese Generation Is Losing the Ability to Express Itself
abstract: How can China’s people demand freedom if we can’t even say it?
lead_paragraph: One morning last November, I woke up to a stirring sight: video clips of young protesters in several Chinese cities singing, shouting and chanting for an end to the oppressive “zero Covid” policy that China had adhered to during the pandemic. I’m 31. Never in my life had I seen my fellow Chinese citizens stand up to the government on such a scale and with such determination.
snippet: How can China’s people demand freedom if we can’t even say it?

headline: There Is Glory and God in Our Struggles
abstract: We don’t need the Black Hebrew Israelites to invent our story.
lead_paragraph: Every February, Black History Month, Americans engage in a futile attempt to squeeze into 28 days the history of a people whose tribulations, contributions and successes are on every page of the American narrative. For African Americans, at least, the struggle to tell our story and make sense of our place in the American saga never recedes from view.
snippet: We don’t need the Black Hebrew Israelites to invent our story.

headline: There Is No Dignity in This Kind of America
abstract: The relentless attack on trans people is an attack on us all.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, we have seen a sweeping and ferocious attack on the rights and dignity of transgender people across the country.
snippet: The relentless attack on trans people is an attack on us all.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Rick Rubin
abstract: The Feb. 10, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Rick Rubin. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Feb. 10, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: What ‘Tár’ Reveals About Wokeness in Hollywood
abstract: What movies define our political moment?
lead_paragraph: “Tár,” the best film of 2022 no matter which motion picture the Academy decides to honor, is a movie about contemporary culture wars that refuses to participate in them. It portrays the generation gap that yawns between liberal elders and progressive juniors in many cultural institutions, it illustrates the potent influence of cancel culture and #MeToo and it uses both forces in a believable (if hallucinatory or supernatural) way to propel the spiraling descent of its title character, Cate Blanchett’s fictional conductor, Lydia Tár. And it does all this in a spirit of controlled ambiguity, from a vantage point outside the forces it depicts — one that allows for varying judgments on the main character’s undoing, in the same way as comparable downfalls in real life.
snippet: What movies define our political moment?

headline: Don’t Buy Biden’s ‘Buy American’
abstract: A stringent requirement is either harmful to taxpayers or superfluous.
lead_paragraph: I can’t say for sure, but I’m guessing that “drywall” was never an applause line in a State of the Union address before this week. Democrats leaped to their feet, and a good number of Republicans joined them when President Biden said, “When we do these projects — and again, I get criticized for this, but I make no excuses for it — we’re going to buy American. We’re going to buy American.” As the applause energized him, he added, “I mean it! Lumber! Glass! Drywall! Fiber-optic cables!”
snippet: A stringent requirement is either harmful to taxpayers or superfluous.

headline: Wonking Out: From Stagflation to ‘Immaculate Disinflation’
abstract: Why are economists experiencing such big mood swings?
lead_paragraph: The other day, Bloomberg’s Tracy Alloway published an interesting article on the sudden popularity of a newish economics term: “immaculate disinflation,” meaning falling inflation without any rise in unemployment. She tried to trace down the origins of the term and found that many people credited … me.
snippet: Why are economists experiencing such big mood swings?

headline: Does China Have a Spy Balloon Strategy?
abstract: Military decision making doesn’t occur in a vacuum. Especially in a political system as opaque, and undemocratic, as China’s.
lead_paragraph: China’s spy balloons don’t make a lot of sense. At least not from a military perspective.
snippet: Military decision making doesn’t occur in a vacuum. Especially in a political system as opaque, and undemocratic, as China’s.

headline: Scranton Joe Is Ready to Go
abstract: No soothsayer needed. We know Biden’s future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Everyone is frantically hunting for clues about whether Joe Biden will run again.
snippet: No soothsayer needed. We know Biden’s future.

headline: Two-Thirds of Kids Struggle to Read, and We Know How to Fix It
abstract: Experts warn that most American children learn with ineffective reading curriculums.
lead_paragraph: A lovely aphorism holds that education isn’t the filling of a pail but the lighting of a fire.
snippet: Experts warn that most American children learn with ineffective reading curriculums.

headline: A Girl Trapped Under Fallen Concrete. A Man Unsure of What to Do.
abstract: Nobel Prize-winning author Orhan Pamuk on watching the devastation and pleas for help following the earthquake in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: The girl with sad eyes must be around 10 or 12 years old. She hardly moves as she stares into the camera phone. Whenever she does move, her gestures are slow and sluggish. The man who is filming the video spots her and cries out in astonished delight.
snippet: Nobel Prize-winning author Orhan Pamuk on watching the devastation and pleas for help following the earthquake in Turkey.

headline: For Sports Lovers, an Event Like the Super Bowl Is Not ‘Only’ a Game
abstract: When I was a child, sports were my refuge. They have continued to serve me well.
lead_paragraph: When I was a boy, starting in sixth grade I was a hypochondriac. I didn’t know then, and I don’t know now, why I was seized by that particular anxiety disorder, which lasted well into junior high.
snippet: When I was a child, sports were my refuge. They have continued to serve me well.

headline: Bad Bunny Is [Winning in Non-English]
abstract: The music industry may not be ready for his sazón, but the rest of us are.
lead_paragraph: The Puerto Rican reggaetonero Bad Bunny kicked off the Grammys earlier this month with a rich cultural performance that included a masterful blend of plena, reggaeton and Dominican merengue. As traditional dancers and the cabezudos of the Agua, Sol y Sereno collective, who wore papier-mâché heads that paid homage to Puerto Rican legends like Tego Calderón and Julia de Burgos, twirled around him, he sang in Spanish about how everyone wants to be Latino but they lack sazón, the distinct cultural flavor and connection to the past that defines our communities.
snippet: The music industry may not be ready for his sazón, but the rest of us are.

headline: ‘Ordinary Russians Want Us to Freeze to Death’
abstract: “My children left, but I don’t want to. I warm myself with an electric heater when there is power,” Alyona Kovalyova said.
lead_paragraph: How do you fight an enemy like the cold?
snippet: “My children left, but I don’t want to. I warm myself with an electric heater when there is power,” Alyona Kovalyova said.

headline: Ukrainian Refugees and Host Families: What Is Life Like After Being Uprooted?
abstract: Times Opinion wants to hear from Ukrainians who have left their country and the people who are helping them.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Ukrainians have left their country since Russia invaded in February 2022.
snippet: Times Opinion wants to hear from Ukrainians who have left their country and the people who are helping them.

headline: How Black Political Thought Shapes My Work
abstract: The experience of unfreedom matters when we consider American democracy.
lead_paragraph: One of the works I cited in my column this week is the volume “African American Political Thought: A Collected History,” edited by the political theorists Melvin L. Rogers and Jack Turner.
snippet: The experience of unfreedom matters when we consider American democracy.

headline: Will Trump and Biden Gang Up on DeSantis?
abstract: Why the non-Trump G.O.P. candidates can expect similar attacks from the Biden White House and the Trump campaign.
lead_paragraph: If President Biden sometimes sounded a lot like Donald Trump during his State of the Union address, boasting about a record of economic nationalism, the imitation may soon run the other way. Biden’s attacks on congressional Republicans for being allegedly eager to cut Medicare and Social Security were a clear preview of how he hopes to run against the G.O.P. in 2024. But they were also a possible preview of how Trump may try to reclaim his own party’s nomination — by reprising his 2016 campaign’s rejection of Tea Party austerity and attacking potential rivals (which means, primarily, Ron DeSantis) as libertarian dogmatists who don’t care about the middle class.
snippet: Why the non-Trump G.O.P. candidates can expect similar attacks from the Biden White House and the Trump campaign.

headline: In 46 Words, Biden Sends a Clear Message to Israel
abstract: The president’s statement could energize opposition to Netanhayu’s plan to weaken judicial independence.
lead_paragraph: I woke up on Saturday morning, read the news from Israel that at least 50,000 Israelis had just demonstrated once more against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s plans to strip the Israeli Supreme Court of its independence and put it instead under Netanyahu’s thumb — at a time when Netanyahu himself is facing corruption charges — and I asked myself a simple question: “What does President Biden think of this?”
snippet: The president’s statement could energize opposition to Netanhayu’s plan to weaken judicial independence.

headline: Men Need Purpose More Than ‘Respect’
abstract: Few goals are more rewarding than helping the people you love walk through life.
lead_paragraph: This month, the popular conservative podcaster Matt Walsh tweeted a thought that rapidly went viral, with approximately 18 million views. “All a man wants,” he wrote, “is to come home from a long day at work to a grateful wife and children who are glad to see him, and dinner cooking on the stove. This is literally all it takes to make a man happy. We are simple. Give us this and you will have given us nearly everything we need.”
snippet: Few goals are more rewarding than helping the people you love walk through life.

headline: Trump’s Supreme Court Picks Are Not Quite What You Think
abstract: We now have real data about Justices Gorsuch, Kavanaugh and Barrett. The court’s gone hard right, but the three are less unified than they might appear.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody has ever done more for right to life than Donald Trump,” the former president told the conservative commentator David Brody last month. “I put three Supreme Court justices, who all voted, and they got something that they’ve been fighting for 64 years, or many, many years.”
snippet: We now have real data about Justices Gorsuch, Kavanaugh and Barrett. The court’s gone hard right, but the three are less unified than they might appear.

author.Original: By David Lat and Zachary B. Shemtob

headline: This Super Bowl Is the Start of Something New
abstract: For decades, people expected N.F.L. quarterbacks to play a certain way. Now the old style is exploding — and the Chiefs-Eagles Super Bowl will show how.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday’s matchup between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Kansas City Chiefs is the first Super Bowl contest between two Black quarterbacks in N.F.L. history. It’s a game pitting the two teams with the most total touchdowns this season against each other (the Eagles have the most rushing touchdowns, the Chiefs the most passing touchdowns).
snippet: For decades, people expected N.F.L. quarterbacks to play a certain way. Now the old style is exploding — and the Chiefs-Eagles Super Bowl will show how.

headline: I Answer the Phone at a Mental Health Hotline. Here’s What I’ve Learned.
abstract: Callers need more than just a sympathetic ear. They need an informed listener.
lead_paragraph: “Oh my, you picked up the phone.”
snippet: Callers need more than just a sympathetic ear. They need an informed listener.

headline: A Huge, Uncharted Experiment on the U.S. Economy Is About to Begin
abstract: If it fails or misfires, then it will greatly limit the number of tools to fight climate change or a recession.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand the immense windfall the Biden administration is about to bestow on green industries, take a look at hydrogen. Engineers still aren’t exactly sure what role the gas will play in a climate-friendly economy, but they’re pretty sure that (contra the ridicule in “Glass Onion”) it will be useful for something. We might burn it to generate heat in factories, for instance, or use it to make high-tech chemicals.
snippet: If it fails or misfires, then it will greatly limit the number of tools to fight climate change or a recession.

headline: This Artist Has a Mission to Call White Americans to Truth
abstract: Gregory Thompson left his role as a pastor to work toward reparations.
lead_paragraph: This week and next, in acknowledgment of Black History Month, I’m profiling individuals who advocate in religious spaces for reparations to Black Americans.
snippet: Gregory Thompson left his role as a pastor to work toward reparations.

headline: I’m a Big Wave Surfer, and I’ve Never Seen Anything Like What I Saw This Year
abstract: Tyler Fox on what climate change is doing to his California coastal community.
lead_paragraph: SOQUEL, Calif. — Throughout my 20-plus years of surfing big waves, I’ve experienced some amazing moments in and around the ocean. I’ve witnessed carnage and chaos, joy and jubilation, events that have been seared into my subconscious and that I believe will stay with me until my dying day.
snippet: Tyler Fox on what climate change is doing to his California coastal community.

headline: Nikki Haley Threw It All Away
abstract: No political figure better illustrates the tragic collapse of the modern Republican Party than the former governor of South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I saw Nikki Haley. It was in a high school gym before the 2012 South Carolina Republican presidential primary. Tim Scott, who was then a congressman, was holding a raucous town hall, and Ms. Haley was there to cheer him on. The first woman to be governor of South Carolina, the first Indian American ever elected to statewide office there, the youngest governor in the country. Whatever that “thing” is that talented politicians possess, Ms. Haley had it. People liked her, and more important, she seemed to like people. She talked with you, not to you, and she made routine conversations feel special and important. She seemed to have unlimited potential.
snippet: No political figure better illustrates the tragic collapse of the modern Republican Party than the former governor of South Carolina.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Didn’t Like What She Saw
abstract: Biden may be 80, but the real danger is the prepubescent opposition.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: So Bret, Joe Biden’s been on a roll. Economy good, State of the Union speech good — made even better by those Republican boobirds.
snippet: Biden may be 80, but the real danger is the prepubescent opposition.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: Have More Sex, Please!
abstract: America is in the midst of a loneliness epidemic. One solution: People should have more sex — as often as they can, as pleasurably as they can.
lead_paragraph: Sex is good. Sex is healthy. Sex is an essential part of our social fabric. And you — specifically — should probably be having more of it.
snippet: America is in the midst of a loneliness epidemic. One solution: People should have more sex — as often as they can, as pleasurably as they can.

headline: Studies Show How Cupid Isn’t Fair
abstract: What the birds and the bees teach us about income inequality.
lead_paragraph: Birds do it. Bees do it. Even intertidal gonochoric prosobranchs do it. And human beings definitely do it. “It” is assortative mating, in which creatures tend to couple with those that are most like them. Case in point: One in four female physicians is married to another physician.
snippet: What the birds and the bees teach us about income inequality.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Long War Against Medicare and Social Security
abstract: Biden isn’t playing gotcha; there’s a lot of history here.
lead_paragraph: Politically, the most crucial moment in President Biden’s State of the Union address was his declaration that “some Republicans want Medicare and Social Security to sunset every five years.” Why did he say that? Maybe because Senator Rick Scott, when he was the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, released a fiscal plan last year with the bullet point “All federal legislation sunsets in five years.”
snippet: Biden isn’t playing gotcha; there’s a lot of history here.

headline: A Left-Leaning College Didn’t Want to Offend, So It Closed Down Her Art Show
abstract: How have we forgotten that art needn’t defer to religion?
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Minn. — The work of the Iranian American artist Taravat Talepasand is cheeky, erotic and defiantly anticlerical. One painting in her new midcareer survey, “Taravat,” incorporates Iranian bank notes whose images of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini have been dosed with LSD. A graphite drawing, titled “Blasphemy X,” depicts a veiled woman giving the finger while lifting her robe to reveal high heels and a flash of underwear. There are sculptures of women in niqab face coverings with enormous exposed breasts. On a gallery wall, “Woman, Life, Freedom,” the slogan of Iran’s recent nationwide protests against the morality police, is written in neon in English and Persian.
snippet: How have we forgotten that art needn’t defer to religion?

headline: What the World Can Learn From Gay-Straight Friendships
abstract: These relationships can help us be more free to be you and me.
lead_paragraph: At around midnight in a sweaty crowd at Crews & Tangos, one of Toronto’s popular L.G.B.T.Q. bars, I watched my friend hop onstage to rip a shot of tequila with Jada Shada Hudson, our favorite drag performer, as Nicki Minaj’s “Super Bass” pulsated through the venue.
snippet: These relationships can help us be more free to be you and me.

headline: How the $500 Billion Attention Industry Really Works
abstract: Your attention is constantly being bought, packaged and sold. Tim Hwang explains how.
lead_paragraph: For most of us, seeing an advertisement pop up while we’re scrolling on Instagram or reading an article or watching a video is the most banal experience possible. But in the background of those experiences is a $500 billion marketplace where our attention is being bought, packaged and sold at split-second speeds virtually every minute of every day. Online advertising is the economic engine of the internet, and that engine is fueled by our attention.
snippet: Your attention is constantly being bought, packaged and sold. Tim Hwang explains how.

headline: A Brief History of Hating My Face
abstract: “It’s really, really hard to live when you’re constantly focused on how you look.”
lead_paragraph: Shaina Feinberg feels horrible about how she looks. This anguish has consumed an incalculable amount of her life. She classifies her self-loathing as body dysmorphic disorder, a condition in which people fixate on perceived flaws in their appearance, causing significant emotional distress.
snippet: “It’s really, really hard to live when you’re constantly focused on how you look.”

headline: Let Us Eat Lungs
abstract: The Department of Agriculture’s ban on the organ makes no medical sense.
lead_paragraph: Federal policy in the United States allows butchers to sell virtually every part of an animal’s body as human food, with one notable exception: the lungs. In 1971 the Department of Agriculture declared animal lungs unfit “for use as human food” and banned them from the commercial food supply.
snippet: The Department of Agriculture’s ban on the organ makes no medical sense.

headline: Sarah Huckabee Sanders Has a Funny Idea of What the Republican Party Should Be
abstract: The G.O.P. does not seem to care much about winning over a majority of voters.
lead_paragraph: The most striking thing about the Republican response to President Biden’s State of the Union last week, delivered this year by Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas, was that it wasn’t actually pitched to the American public at large.
snippet: The G.O.P. does not seem to care much about winning over a majority of voters.

headline: Under Trump, Barr and Durham Made a Mockery of the Rules I Wrote
abstract: Merrick Garland needs to remind Americans what independent investigations and decision making look like.
lead_paragraph: The recent revelations about the special counsel John H. Durham’s investigation of the origins of Robert Mueller’s Russia inquiry paint a bleak picture — one that’s thoroughly at odds with governing law. Those rules, called the special counsel regulations, contemplate someone independent of the attorney general who can reassure the public that justice is being done.
snippet: Merrick Garland needs to remind Americans what independent investigations and decision making look like.
