headline: Rescuing Farm Animals From Cruelty Should Be Legal
abstract: Were two chickens stolen or saved from an inhumane slaughterhouse?
lead_paragraph: For about six weeks in the summer of 2021, an activist working with the animal rights group Direct Action Everywhere, or DxE, gained undercover access to one of the largest chicken slaughterhouses in California, a Foster Farms facility in the Central Valley city of Livingston.
snippet: Were two chickens stolen or saved from an inhumane slaughterhouse?

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Tim Hwang
abstract: The Feb. 14, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Tim Hwang. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Feb. 14, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: The Trouble With Sunsets
abstract: Why put time limits on legislation? Most of the reasons are bad.
lead_paragraph: My latest column was about President Biden’s remark that some Republicans want to sunset Social Security and Medicare (and, indeed, all federal legislation) after five years, and the howls of outrage this has provoked from the G.O.P. and, alas, some mainstream media figures — even though Biden was directly quoting the former chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
snippet: Why put time limits on legislation? Most of the reasons are bad.

headline: Is China ‘Probing With Bayonets’?
abstract: Balloons may seem unthreatening, but they can expose weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to let your imagination run wild when it comes to the unidentified flying objects now making frequent appearances over North America. At least one object was reported to be cylindrical, eerily suggestive of past imagined visitors. “The cylinder was artificial — hollow — with an end that screwed out!” wrote H.G. Wells in “The War of The Worlds.” “Something within the cylinder was unscrewing the top!”
snippet: Balloons may seem unthreatening, but they can expose weaknesses.

headline: Netanyahu’s Judicial Coup Could Destroy His Start-Up Nation
abstract: The greatest risk to Israel in the prime minister’s radical judicial plan is now coming into focus.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand the economic riskiness and moral fraudulence of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s headlong rush to ram through a total overhaul of Israel’s judicial system and put it under his thumb while he faces corruption charges, you just need to study two statistics and ask one question.
snippet: The greatest risk to Israel in the prime minister’s radical judicial plan is now coming into focus.

headline: Even in Death, Black Americans Have Been Denied the Right to Rest in Peace
abstract: A staggering number of America’s Black burial grounds have been erased from history.
lead_paragraph: At 106 years old, Benjamin Prine was the last living person born into slavery on Staten Island when he died in October 1900. He was laid to rest at the Second Asbury A.M.E. Cemetery on the borough’s North Shore, alongside the remains of an estimated 1,000 other people, many formerly enslaved and nearly all Black.
snippet: A staggering number of America’s Black burial grounds have been erased from history.

headline: ‘Nikki Haley Will Not Be the Next President’: Our Columnists Weigh In
abstract: A new scorecard looks at the strengths and weaknesses of Republican presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: With candidates entering the 2024 presidential race, Times columnists and Opinion writers are starting a scorecard assessing their strengths and weaknesses. We rate the candidates on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the candidate will probably drop out before any actual caucus or primary voting; 10 means the candidate has a very strong chance of accepting the party’s nomination next summer. We begin with Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina and United Nations ambassador in the Trump administration, who announced her bid for the Republican nomination on Tuesday.
snippet: A new scorecard looks at the strengths and weaknesses of Republican presidential candidates.

headline: Are Men the Overlooked Reason for the Fertility Decline?
abstract: Maybe it’s time to shift focus.
lead_paragraph: In the week since the publication of my first article in a series about declining global fertility rates in developed countries around the world, The Times ran at least two more articles on the subject: One asked whether it was possible for China to reverse its population decline. (TL;DR: Probably not.) Another was about what the statistics about declining fertility miss about the stressors of modern parenting.
snippet: Maybe it’s time to shift focus.

subject: Birth Rates
Population
Men and Boys
Education

headline: The Law Is Closing In on Trump
abstract: The decision whether to indict Trump should be based on the law, not on a fear of the consequences of indicting him.
lead_paragraph: There are now three clear indicators that criminal probes of Donald Trump are rapidly reaching a conclusion. First, in Georgia a special grand jury investigating his efforts to overturn the presidential election in the state has concluded its work. The Fulton County district attorney, Fani Willis, has indicated that charging decisions are imminent. Key parts of the grand jury report will be released this Thursday.
snippet: The decision whether to indict Trump should be based on the law, not on a fear of the consequences of indicting him.

headline: U.F.O.s and Other Unsolved Mysteries of Our Time
abstract: Sometimes a phenomenon goes from being the subject of crank theories to being more mainstream, but without being fully explained or figured out.
lead_paragraph: Sometime very soon, one hopes, the Biden administration will attempt to explain to the American people what they think our fighters shot down over Lake Huron and northern Canada and off Alaska, be they balloons or drones or something somewhat stranger. If that happens, we will take a meaningful step toward solving a longstanding, conspiracy-shadowed mystery: What, exactly, are all the unidentified flying objects — sorry, sorry — unidentified aerial phenomena that our military keeps encountering in the skyfields above planet Earth?
snippet: Sometimes a phenomenon goes from being the subject of crank theories to being more mainstream, but without being fully explained or figured out.

headline: Europe Turned an Energy Crisis Into a Green Energy Sprint
abstract: The brutal European winter that wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be a winter of energy crisis in Europe. Beginning last spring, not long after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the fear of gas shortages spread across the continent, along with fears of what might follow. The coming winter crunch was compared to wartime, with energy experts less focused on whether it would bring rationing than how much. Others suggested that spectacular price spikes would mean suspensions of energy markets and that the continent as a whole would experience not a “cost of living crisis” but a crisis of “molecules” — in which there wasn’t enough energy to be had, no matter the price. A recession was simply taken for granted among the commentariat — almost like a badge of honor demonstrating the moral valor of standing up to Vladimir Putin.
snippet: The brutal European winter that wasn’t.

headline: The Great Spy Balloon Freakout
abstract: Fear distorts our actual assessment of risk.
lead_paragraph: These are not safe times to be a weather balloon.
snippet: Fear distorts our actual assessment of risk.

headline: The Super Bowl Can Teach Us About Incompatible Incentives
abstract: Why Kansas City Chiefs running back Jerick McKinnon intentionally stopped short of a touchdown.
lead_paragraph: From an economic perspective, the most interesting play of Super Bowl LVII was near the end of the game, when the Kansas City Chiefs running back Jerick McKinnon sprinted toward the end zone but slid to a stop inches short of scoring a touchdown, like Moses not entering the Promised Land or me rejecting a slice of chocolate cake.
snippet: Why Kansas City Chiefs running back Jerick McKinnon intentionally stopped short of a touchdown.

headline: U.S.-China Relations Keep Getting Worse. Do They Have To?
abstract: The spy balloon affair is just the latest episode in the longer story of deteriorating relations between the world’s two great powers.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
snippet: The spy balloon affair is just the latest episode in the longer story of deteriorating relations between the world’s two great powers.

headline: The ‘Wicked Wisdom’ of Ron DeSantis
abstract: The Florida governor is turning marginalized groups against one another.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The marchers kept up a brisk pace, through streets lined by old oaks tinseled in Spanish moss that acknowledged even the slightest breeze.
snippet: The Florida governor is turning marginalized groups against one another.

headline: He Was ‘Losing His Mind Slowly, and I Watched It’
abstract: How do you help someone who doesn’t believe he is mentally ill?
lead_paragraph: Kimberly is a mom whose 22-year-old son has been cycling in and out of psychosis since he was a teenager. Her story is familiar to families across the country, with a national debate raging about when — if ever — it’s appropriate to treat severely mentally ill people against their will.
snippet: How do you help someone who doesn’t believe he is mentally ill?

headline: The Death of the Author (and the Estate Auction That Follows)
abstract: André Leon Talley, Joan Didion, Elizabeth Wurtzel and the rise of author’s auctions.
lead_paragraph: Preceded by a series of previews in Palm Beach, Paris and New York — the last of which included a performance by the Abyssinian Baptist Church choir — the estate auction of the legendary fashion editor André Leon Talley was a full-blown cultural event. The live action fetched $1.4 million, but fans around the world can continue to feast their eyes on his dazzling collection of haute couture, high-end furniture, art and other luxury items, many of them personalized or custom-made to fit Mr. Talley’s substantial frame and colossal personality.
snippet: André Leon Talley, Joan Didion, Elizabeth Wurtzel and the rise of author’s auctions.

headline: When the Horseshoe Crabs Are Gone, We’ll Be in Trouble
abstract: Their blood is used in a critical test to detect toxins in injectable medicines. We need a synthetic version of that test.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who gets a flu or Covid shot, childhood immunization, heart stent or hip replacement — and that’s almost everyone — is protected from exposure to potentially lethal contaminants known as endotoxins by a test that uses what might seem like an odd ingredient: the blue blood of the horseshoe crab.
snippet: Their blood is used in a critical test to detect toxins in injectable medicines. We need a synthetic version of that test.

headline: In Defense of J.K. Rowling
abstract: The charge that she’s a transphobe doesn’t square with her actual views.
lead_paragraph: “Trans people need and deserve protection.”
snippet: The charge that she’s a transphobe doesn’t square with her actual views.

headline: Dismiss Ron DeSantis at Your Peril
abstract: The Florida governor isn’t punching back at Donald Trump. That’s discipline, not weakness.
lead_paragraph: So now Ron DeSantis is wishy-washy. A bit of a wimp. Or at least runs the risk of looking like one.
snippet: The Florida governor isn’t punching back at Donald Trump. That’s discipline, not weakness.

headline: DeSantis May Have Been Right
abstract: The College Board amended its original plan for an A.P. African American studies course. It was probably for the best.
lead_paragraph: In January, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida announced he would ban a draft curriculum proposed by the College Board for a new Advanced Placement course in African American studies, criticizing the educational merit of the course. This month the College Board released an official curriculum that revised the course by designating some of the writers and ideas in the draft curriculum as optional topics of study rather than core lessons.
snippet: The College Board amended its original plan for an A.P. African American studies course. It was probably for the best.

headline: The Right Don’t Need No Education
abstract: Hey! Teachers! Leave our ignorance alone!
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis, who is currently governor of Florida and wants to become president, has been trying to position himself as America’s leading crusader against wokeness. And lately higher education has become his most visible target. He picked a very public fight with the College Board over its new advanced placement course in African American studies, and in the past few days has broadened that attack into a suggestion that Florida might stop offering A.P. classes in any field.
snippet: Hey! Teachers! Leave our ignorance alone!

headline: America Should Be in the Middle of a Schools Revolution
abstract: Covid disrupted education, and now the task is to build something new.
lead_paragraph: “The coronavirus caused by far the biggest disruption in the history of American education,” Meira Levinson and Daniel Markovits wrote in The Atlantic last year.
snippet: Covid disrupted education, and now the task is to build something new.

headline: My Child Is in an Impossible Place, and I Am There With Her
abstract: Three years into my daughter’s cancer treatments, my family has leaned into talking about hard things.
lead_paragraph: In my family, we talk about hard things.
snippet: Three years into my daughter’s cancer treatments, my family has leaned into talking about hard things.

headline: The Inflation Story Has Changed Significantly. Paul Krugman Breaks It Down.
abstract: The Nobel laureate economist discusses inflation’s slowdown, the G.O.P.’s incoherent economic agenda and A.I.’s impact on the labor market.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, the story of the U.S. economy has changed significantly. The January Consumer Price Index showed that annual inflation slowed for the seventh straight month. That month, the economy also added over half a million jobs, and unemployment reached 3.4 percent, its lowest level since 1969. In light of these trends, comparisons to the 1970s stagflation crisis have weakened, and the possibility of a “soft landing” looks increasingly likely.
snippet: The Nobel laureate economist discusses inflation’s slowdown, the G.O.P.’s incoherent economic agenda and A.I.’s impact on the labor market.

headline: It’s Time to Prepare for a Possible Trump Indictment
abstract: We need to prepare for a first in our history as a nation: the possible criminal prosecution of a former president.
lead_paragraph: “We find by unanimous vote that no widespread fraud took place in the Georgia 2020 presidential election that could result in overturning that election.” With those words, a Fulton County special grand jury’s report, part of which was released Thursday, repudiated Donald Trump’s assault on our democracy.
snippet: We need to prepare for a first in our history as a nation: the possible criminal prosecution of a former president.

author.Original: By Norman L. Eisen, E. Danya Perry and Amy Lee Copeland
author.People: Eisen Norman, Perry E., Copeland Amy

headline: Who’s Afraid of Black History?
abstract: Ron DeSantis should be careful of the company he keeps.
lead_paragraph: Lurking behind the concerns of Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, over the content of a proposed high school course in African American studies, is a long and complex series of debates about the role of slavery and race in American classrooms.
snippet: Ron DeSantis should be careful of the company he keeps.

headline: Our Age of Impunity
abstract: A new Atlas of Impunity shows a world where wrongdoing is too rarely punished.
lead_paragraph: This month marks a year since Russian tanks first crossed the border with Ukraine, signaling the start of the most extensive land war in Europe since the end of World War II. The invasion has left Ukrainians fighting for their nation and their democracy against a regime that is repressive at home and expansionist abroad.
snippet: A new Atlas of Impunity shows a world where wrongdoing is too rarely punished.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Paul Krugman
abstract: The Feb. 17, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Paul Krugman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Feb. 17, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: The Chatbot Experiment Just Got Weird
abstract: Will A.I. be our dutiful assistant or our unstable muse?
lead_paragraph: For months now, I’ve been slightly, well, bored by the proliferating examples of A.I.-generated writing produced by peers and friends and various Twitterers since the debut of ChatGPT in November. I can grasp intellectually the significance of the breakthrough, how it could demolish the college essay, change the nature of homework and remake or unmake all kinds of nonliterary knowledge work, setting aside minor questions like whether rogue A.I. might wipe out the human race. But the texts themselves I’ve found profoundly uninteresting — internet scrapings that at best equaled Wikipedia, notable mostly for what their political-cultural biases revealed about ChatGPT’s programming or the consensus of the safe information that it was programmed to distill.
snippet: Will A.I. be our dutiful assistant or our unstable muse?

headline: Wonking Out: Why Growth Can Be Green
abstract: Taking on a zombie environmental fallacy.
lead_paragraph: Heads up: I did a podcast with Ezra Klein earlier this week, mostly focused on inflation — which continues to be an interesting story, throwing curveballs at all who imagine they have it figured out. But for today’s newsletter I want to take a break and talk about environmental policy — specifically, the relationship between protecting the environment and economic growth.
snippet: Taking on a zombie environmental fallacy.

headline: The Perfect Retirement Investment Nobody Wants
abstract: Why the market has no interest in a better way to prepare financially for aging and illness.
lead_paragraph: Two of your biggest financial risks in retirement involve your health, but they’re almost opposed to each other. One is that you will require expensive long-term care early on. You will probably die young, but not before going broke from nursing home bills. Another is that you will stay healthy enough to live a very long life, but as a result you will run out of savings — even if you never require long-term care.
snippet: Why the market has no interest in a better way to prepare financially for aging and illness.

headline: What Fox News Says When You’re Not Listening
abstract: The extravagant cynicism behind the network’s conspiracy theorizing.
lead_paragraph: People who remember Fox News host Tucker Carlson as a bow-tied creature of establishment Washington often wonder what happened to him. Twenty years ago, he was a preppy Beltway habitué and impishly libertarian magazine writer; a wryly affectionate account of Al Sharpton in Liberia that he wrote for Esquire was nominated for a National Magazine Award. Now he’s the sneering, conspiracy-obsessed host of what The New York Times called possibly “the most racist show in the history of cable news.”
snippet: The extravagant cynicism behind the network’s conspiracy theorizing.

headline: George Washington Would Hate Presidents’ Day
abstract: Our ambivalence about Presidents’ Day says something essential about whether we think of the office as a symbol of democracy.
lead_paragraph: I have a confession to make: I’m a presidential historian who dislikes Presidents’ Day.
snippet: Our ambivalence about Presidents’ Day says something essential about whether we think of the office as a symbol of democracy.

headline: Bruce Willis, My Father and the Decision of a Lifetime
abstract: The story of a brave announcement and its unpredictable aftermath.
lead_paragraph: The letter from Bruce Willis’s family bore seven names — Emma, Demi, Rumer, Scout, Tallulah, Mabel and Evelyn —  and a picture of the actor smiling on the beach. You could almost mistake the letter for one of those holiday circulars some families send around, but for one detail: It appeared on Thursday on the website of the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration, a group devoted to a condition with which Mr. Willis had been diagnosed. His family said he would want to use his visibility to help bring attention to others suffering from the disease.
snippet: The story of a brave announcement and its unpredictable aftermath.

headline: Straight Talk on the Country’s War Addiction
abstract: America’s forever wars are making us weaker, and misreading history doesn’t help.
lead_paragraph: Without a fresh vision for America’s role in the world, many people in Washington link today’s geopolitical challenges with those of yesteryear.
snippet: America’s forever wars are making us weaker, and misreading history doesn’t help.

headline: Biden Should Give Ukraine What It Needs to Win
abstract: Yes, there are risks of escalation. But there are greater risks of letting this awful war drag on.
lead_paragraph: Russian Air Force pilots are scaredy-cats who have been surprisingly absent over Ukraine. Russian ground forces are being mowed down as cannon fodder, and one of the best known examples of Russian military discipline involves an officer using a sledgehammer to execute a fellow Russian.
snippet: Yes, there are risks of escalation. But there are greater risks of letting this awful war drag on.

headline: What Happens When an Artist Loses His Sight
abstract: Losing your sight forces you to go inward, to use your creativity to conjure a world you can no longer see.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I began having trouble with my vision. Shapes became indistinct, colors muted. The world started to look like a grainy 1940s movie mystery, and I was the detective — a clumsy one.
snippet: Losing your sight forces you to go inward, to use your creativity to conjure a world you can no longer see.

headline: Wooing a Latin Star, Kardashian-Style
abstract: Why did a Latinx put an X through The Times?
lead_paragraph: I heard Kim Kardashian give a talk once about techniques she uses to inspire loyalty in her fans. Sometimes, she would jump on her $150 million custom Gulfstream and surprise strangers by showing up at their birthday parties.
snippet: Why did a Latinx put an X through The Times?

headline: When Parents Hear That Their Child ‘Is Not Normal and Should Not Exist’
abstract: Anti-trans legislation in dozens of states is an attack on parental rights.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Russel Neiss glanced down at his Apple Watch. The screen glowed bright red, warning of something he already knew: Though he was sitting stock still, waiting to testify before state senators, his heart was hammering.
snippet: Anti-trans legislation in dozens of states is an attack on parental rights.

headline: Relentless Nostalgia Is Numbing Our Brains
abstract: True.
lead_paragraph: I never thought I’d be sentimental for Budweiser’s “Whassup?” commercials. But after this year’s woefully derivative slate of Super Bowl ads — including a “Clueless” revival to promote a shopping app and a home internet ad that took a page from “Grease” while rolling in the stars of “Scrubs” — I was downright wistful. On advertising’s biggest day, I longed for anything that would propel our popular culture or even create a new catch phrase rather than tepid nostalgia recycling random celebrities.
snippet: True.

headline: American Teens Are Really Miserable. Why?
abstract: Social media has added to a sense of isolation.
lead_paragraph: American teenagers, and especially American teenage girls, are increasingly miserable: more likely to entertain suicidal thoughts and act on them, more likely to experience depression, more likely to feel beset by “persistent feelings of sadness or hopelessness,” to quote a survey report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
snippet: Social media has added to a sense of isolation.

headline: We’re Not Asking the Right Question About Biden
abstract: The oldest president has an argument about the future.
lead_paragraph: There is no end of commentary gently — and not so gently — urging President Biden to act his age and step aside. And all else being equal, I share that sentiment. I don’t think we want a president ending his second term closer to 90 than he is to 80. But all else is never equal. And the commentaries that focus solely on Biden’s central weakness — his age — are missing his mounting strengths.
snippet: The oldest president has an argument about the future.

headline: America Can’t Go ‘Wobbly’ on Ukraine
abstract: This is a winnable war.
lead_paragraph: As we approach the first anniversary of Russia’s brutal and unprovoked invasion of Ukraine, two ominous trends are emerging at once. First, Russia is doubling down. It’s pouring fresh troops into Ukraine and launching new offensive operations.
snippet: This is a winnable war.

headline: This Deadly Chemical Should Be Banned
abstract: The cancer-causing chemical vinyl chloride was vented and burned after the Ohio train crash to avoid an explosion. The United States should phase it out.
lead_paragraph: Like a scene out of some postapocalyptic movie, Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio convened a news conference on Feb. 5 to deliver a stark warning. “We are ordering them to leave,” he said of residents of the small rural community of East Palestine, Ohio, and a neighboring part of Pennsylvania. “This is a matter of life and death.” To emphasize the point, he added: “Those in the red area are facing grave danger of death if they are still in that area.”
snippet: The cancer-causing chemical vinyl chloride was vented and burned after the Ohio train crash to avoid an explosion. The United States should phase it out.

author.Original: By Rebecca Fuoco, David Rosner and Gerald Markowitz
author.People: Fuoco Rebecca, Rosner David, Markowitz Gerald

headline: The Decolonization of Christianity Is Not Complete
abstract: The activist Ekemini Uwan believes that churches need to do more than repent for their historical crimes.
lead_paragraph: For Black History Month, I’m profiling individuals who work in religious arenas for reparations to Black Americans. Last week, I featured Gregory Thompson, a former pastor and the founder of Voices Underground, a nonprofit creative firm that helps communities recover, interpret and honor their African American histories. This week, we hear from Ekemini Uwan, a co-author of the book “Truth’s Table: Black Women’s Musings on Life, Love, and Liberation ” and co-host of the “Truth’s Table” podcast.
snippet: The activist Ekemini Uwan believes that churches need to do more than repent for their historical crimes.

headline: You Can’t Save Democracy in a Jewish State
abstract: Protesters against Netanyahu’s judicial changes say they are standing up for democracy. But democracy for whom?
lead_paragraph: The warnings come every day: Israeli democracy is in danger.
snippet: Protesters against Netanyahu’s judicial changes say they are standing up for democracy. But democracy for whom?

headline: The Problem With Russia Is Russia
abstract: Ukrainians will survive the Russian Federation, just as we survived the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: KRAKOW, Poland — One year ago this Tuesday, Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the Russian-backed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk — effectively the starting pistol for Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which began three days later. For us Ukrainians, the world would never be the same. Yet it was another act of recognition in 2022, one largely neglected, that made my heart beat faster. On Oct. 18, Ukraine’s Parliament declared the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria “temporarily occupied by the Russian Federation.”
snippet: Ukrainians will survive the Russian Federation, just as we survived the Soviet Union.

headline: Biology Is Dangerously Outpacing Policy
abstract: The U.S. government needs to embrace recommendations for safer research.
lead_paragraph: The original source of the coronavirus pandemic remains unconfirmed. While it was likely the result of a spillover from animals to humans, a lab origin cannot be ruled out. Given the uncertainty, additional scrutiny on research with pathogens that are engineered to be more transmissible or dangerous is warranted to prevent any future devastating pandemics.
snippet: The U.S. government needs to embrace recommendations for safer research.

headline: It’s Time to Tear Up Big Tech’s Get-Out-of-Jail-Free Card
abstract: Seven years ago, I showed that Facebook sold discriminatory ads. Its system is still broken.
lead_paragraph: I still remember the shock I felt when I was able to buy a Facebook ad aimed only at white house hunters — something the Fair Housing Act was designed to prevent — in just minutes. But even more shocking is that it took six years after my test for Meta, Facebook’s parent company, to comply with the act. As of today, the company still has not fully fixed its discriminatory ad system.
snippet: Seven years ago, I showed that Facebook sold discriminatory ads. Its system is still broken.

headline: Here’s What the Other Republican Candidates Should Say to Trump
abstract: And quick.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I know you’re keen to handicap — figuratively, but maybe also literally — the emerging field of Republican presidential hopefuls. First Donald Trump, now Nikki Haley and soon, possibly, a fellow Palmetto State Republican, Senator Tim Scott. That’s on top of probable runs by Ron DeSantis, Mike Pompeo and Mike Pence and possibly Brian Kemp of Georgia, Glenn Youngkin of Virginia, Kristi Noem of South Dakota and Chris Christie of … New Jersey.
snippet: And quick.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: What Ford’s Pardon of Nixon Means (and Doesn’t Mean) for Trump
abstract: A presidential prosecution could help restore national confidence in the judicial system.
lead_paragraph: The release on Thursday of parts of a report from a grand jury in Georgia that investigated election interference by Donald Trump and his allies offers the most recent evidence of his growing legal exposure.
snippet: A presidential prosecution could help restore national confidence in the judicial system.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Presidency Was Not What You Think
abstract: Jimmy Carter was probably the most intelligent, hard-working and decent man to have occupied the Oval Office in the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: The man was not what you think. He was tough. He was extremely intimidating. Jimmy Carter was probably the most intelligent, hard-working and decent man to have occupied the Oval Office in the 20th century.
snippet: Jimmy Carter was probably the most intelligent, hard-working and decent man to have occupied the Oval Office in the 20th century.

headline: Some of the Best Weapons in the World Are Now in Ukraine. They May Change the War.
abstract: What will Ukraine do with its new tanks?
lead_paragraph: Tens of billions of dollars of weapons have flowed from European and North American countries into Ukraine. Rifles. Bullets. Missiles. Artillery pieces.
snippet: What will Ukraine do with its new tanks?

subject: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022)
Defense and Military Forces
United States Defense and Military Forces

author.Original: By David Axe and Taylor Maggiacomo

headline: This Book Changed My Relationship to Pain
abstract: The pain psychologist Rachel Zoffness explains how pain is a “biopsychosocial phenomenon” — and how we can better treat it as such.
lead_paragraph: Physical pain is a universal human experience. And for many of us, it’s a constant one. Roughly 20 percent of American adults — some 50 million people — suffer from a form of chronic pain. For some, that means having terrible days from time to time. For others, it means a life of constant suffering. Either way, the depth and scale of pain in our society is a massive problem.
snippet: The pain psychologist Rachel Zoffness explains how pain is a “biopsychosocial phenomenon” — and how we can better treat it as such.

headline: ‘Don’t Lose Your Accent!’
abstract: Don’t give up your accent! Don’t lose your immigrant verbal heritage!
lead_paragraph: The immigration debate often centers on who should be welcomed into our country. Some even argue that multiculturalism dilutes our national character — that the very essence of the country is somehow vanishing. But far from undermining the American experiment, immigrants enhance our culture by introducing new ideas, cuisines and art. They also enrich the English language.
snippet: Don’t give up your accent! Don’t lose your immigrant verbal heritage!

headline: The Era of Shutting Others Out of New York’s Suburbs Is Ending
abstract: Zoning laws have shut out Black Americans and others considered undesirable from thriving suburbs for too long.
lead_paragraph: Across the New York City suburbs, a thicket of local zoning laws thwarts the building of all but the most expensive single-family homes.
snippet: Zoning laws have shut out Black Americans and others considered undesirable from thriving suburbs for too long.

headline: Biden’s Promises on Social Security and Medicare Have No Basis in Reality
abstract: President Biden’s pledges in his State of the Union speech are almost certainly economically impossible.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union speech this month, President Biden pledged to block any reductions in scheduled Social Security and Medicare benefits. He also promised that any tax increases would be limited to families that earn more than $400,000 — roughly the top-earning 2 percent of American families.
snippet: President Biden’s pledges in his State of the Union speech are almost certainly economically impossible.

headline: We Were Too Late, and the Rubble Was Quiet
abstract: When an earthquake hits at night, the usual approach is to try to reach the bedrooms first, but this building had folded like a book.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — We were late to the scene of the crime.
snippet: When an earthquake hits at night, the usual approach is to try to reach the bedrooms first, but this building had folded like a book.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Rachel Zoffness
abstract: A conversation with the pain psychologist Rachel Zoffness.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Rachel Zoffness. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: A conversation with the pain psychologist Rachel Zoffness.

headline: Why Medicare and Social Security Are Sustainable
abstract: Reports of their inevitable collapse are greatly exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: The G.O.P. response to President Biden’s truthful statement that some Republicans want to sunset Medicare and Social Security has been highly gratifying. In other words, the party has reacted with sheer panic — plus a startling lack of message discipline, with both Mike Pence and Nikki Haley saying that actually, yes, they do want to privatize or “reform” Social Security, which is code for gutting it.
snippet: Reports of their inevitable collapse are greatly exaggerated.

headline: The Mask Mandates Did Nothing. Will Any Lessons Be Learned?
abstract: “Do something” is not science, and it shouldn’t have been public policy.
lead_paragraph: The most rigorous and comprehensive analysis of scientific studies conducted on the efficacy of masks for reducing the spread of respiratory illnesses — including Covid-19 — was published late last month. Its conclusions, said Tom Jefferson, the Oxford epidemiologist who is its lead author, were unambiguous.
snippet: “Do something” is not science, and it shouldn’t have been public policy.

organizations: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
