Masks
Research
Respiratory Diseases

headline: The Fox Newsification of Nikki Haley
abstract: Imagine the start of her campaign if she weren’t pandering to the MAGA crowd.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what I think is one of the most intriguing questions in American politics today: How would Nikki Haley talk about the country and its challenges if Fox News didn’t exist?
snippet: Imagine the start of her campaign if she weren’t pandering to the MAGA crowd.

headline: Russian Troops Know How Little They Mean to Putin
abstract: Despite staggering losses, the Kremlin is still intent on fighting.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, its leaders expected a quick success. The Russian military, modernized in the past decade and emboldened by campaigns in Ukraine and Syria, was confident using force abroad. As Russia moved nearly 200,000 troops, missile launchers and combat aviation apparatus into place early last year, many feared the worst.
snippet: Despite staggering losses, the Kremlin is still intent on fighting.

headline: The Forces Tearing Us Apart Are Not Quite What They Seem
abstract: Educational polarization matters, but racial resentment matters more.
lead_paragraph: A toxic combination of racial resentment and the sharp regional disparity in economic growth between urban and rural America is driving the class upheaval in American partisanship, with the Republican Party dominant in working-class House districts and the Democratic Party winning a decisive majority of upscale House seats.
snippet: Educational polarization matters, but racial resentment matters more.

headline: A Warning From the Past: ‘You Haven’t Learned Anything From Our History’
abstract: It was 1970. Over 50 years later, these words serve as a dire warning.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, I was invited to delve into news archives from 1970 at Southern Methodist University’s G. William Jones Film and Video Collection in Dallas. I didn’t know what to expect.
snippet: It was 1970. Over 50 years later, these words serve as a dire warning.

headline: The Hottest Restaurants Should Be the Ones That Care About Their Workers
abstract: Restaurant diners should worry less about the ingredients in their meal and more about the people sourcing, cooking and serving it.
lead_paragraph: I’ve seen a rise in diners’ questions about food — whether ingredients are local, seasonal, organic, grass-fed, free-range or regeneratively farmed. At a restaurant where I used to work, a guest once asked me how many grams of sugar the cow that became her Wagyu beef dish was fed per day. Diners don’t hesitate to ask about the welfare conditions of the pig that became their pork chop.
snippet: Restaurant diners should worry less about the ingredients in their meal and more about the people sourcing, cooking and serving it.

headline: One Year Inside a Radical New Approach to America’s Overdose Crisis
abstract: The case for harm reduction.
lead_paragraph: It was late summer, and the sun was high over East Harlem. Terrell Jones stepped out of a large black van that advertised help with detox and free hepatitis C testing and scanned the homeless encampment beneath the elevated train tracks across the intersection from where he stood. He was looking for a specific inhabitant, a white woman in her late 20s or early 30s whom he and his colleagues had heard about for weeks but had yet to meet. Like many of the women Mr. Jones encountered in his work, this one was unhoused, was attached to a possibly abusive man and was using hard drugs (crack, in this case). Unlike the others, though, she was also about five months pregnant.
snippet: The case for harm reduction.

author.Original: By Jeneen Interlandi and Donavon Smallwood

headline: We’re Unprepared for the A.I. Gold Rush
abstract: Should we apply the brakes on this rapidly developing technology — or let it develop and deal with problems as they arise?
lead_paragraph: I think I know why artificial intelligence is breaking our all-too-human brains. It’s coming at us too fast. We don’t understand what’s happening inside the black boxes of A.I., and what we don’t understand, we understandably fear. Ordinarily we count on lawmakers and regulators to look out for our interests, but they can’t keep up with the rapid advances in A.I., either.
snippet: Should we apply the brakes on this rapidly developing technology — or let it develop and deal with problems as they arise?

headline: Is the United States Ready for Back-to-Back Pandemics?
abstract: America has failed to do all the things that might have secured lasting normalcy.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happened to our Roaring Twenties? In the first year of the pandemic, it was common to hear predictions that however brutal and harrowing the near future seemed, the world would find itself, at some point, celebrating the end of Covid-19 — perhaps in a grand bacchanal to recall the dizzying decade that followed the Spanish flu of 1918 and 1919, which killed 675,000 Americans.
snippet: America has failed to do all the things that might have secured lasting normalcy.

headline: America, Right-Wing Censors and the ‘Battle for the Next Century’
abstract: This is the New Right’s strategic plan: a relentless push to strengthen the white-supremacist power structure.
lead_paragraph: Chris Rufo, the man who orchestrated the attack on critical race theory, underscored a new focus this month.
snippet: This is the New Right’s strategic plan: a relentless push to strengthen the white-supremacist power structure.

headline: A Farewell to Readers
abstract: The debate continues.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s Note: The past few years have been a turbulent time. After a pandemic, the 2020 elections and fears of nuclear Armageddon, we’ve been through a lot. I want to thank you for sticking around and reading this newsletter through it all. That’s why it’s bittersweet to tell you that this is the last issue of this newsletter. But the news isn’t all bad: You will continue to receive sharp commentary and analysis on what’s happening in the world from fresh vantage points in our Opinion Today newsletter, sent Monday through Saturday. Sign up here to make sure it lands in your inbox.
snippet: The debate continues.

headline: What the War in Ukraine Has Truly Cost Us
abstract: War isn’t just tragic. It squanders our resources.
lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget the stories I heard on the Ukrainian-Polish border one year ago: Newlyweds who separated hours after saying their vows so the groom could return to the front. A tax preparer in Boston who quit her job to return to Ukraine with suitcases full of medical supplies. The wife of a border guard who made the three-hour round trip from Lviv to the Polish border almost daily to drop off fleeing women and children and pick up weapons and supplies.
snippet: War isn’t just tragic. It squanders our resources.

headline: Google Changed Work Culture. Its Former Hype Woman Has Regrets.
abstract: What the Big Tech meltdown can teach all workers.
lead_paragraph: The tech giants’ offices were once heralded as the workplaces of the future. Their employees enjoyed previously unheard-of perks, like free farm-to-table lunches, on-site laundry and weekly massages, all lavished on them as they set about designing the technologies transforming the world.
snippet: What the Big Tech meltdown can teach all workers.

author.Original: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Wyatt Orme, Derek Arthur, Anabel Bacon, Kaari Pitkin, Pat McCusker, Isaac Jones, Sonia Herrero and Carole Sabouraud
author.People: Garcia-Navarro Lulu, Orme Wyatt, Arthur Derek, Bacon Anabel, Pitkin Kaari, McCusker Pat, Jones Isaac, Herrero Sonia, Sabouraud Carole

headline: History May Wonder Why Microsoft Let Its Principles Go for a Creepy, Clingy Bot
abstract: By launching Bing, Microsoft is abandoning the ethical principles it had carefully crafted around A.I.
lead_paragraph: The celebration that greeted Microsoft’s release of its A.I.-boosted search engine, Bing, to testers two weeks ago has lurched to alarm.
snippet: By launching Bing, Microsoft is abandoning the ethical principles it had carefully crafted around A.I.

headline: Joe Biden’s Greatest Strength Is Also His Greatest Vulnerability
abstract: Joe Biden’s age has loomed over his presidency. He was right before about himself. Where stability and risk meet, he’s potentially asking people to again trust him.
lead_paragraph: In February 2020, just before the world shut down, I was waiting for Joe Biden to speak on a Friday night in Henderson, Nev. The next morning I watched Bernie Sanders rally a fairly young, largely Latino crowd in a packed Las Vegas high school cafeteria. The Biden event, held when it looked as if he would not win the nomination, was smaller and more subdued. On the other side of a rope separating the media from attendees, a few Biden supporters were talking about how stressful it would be to be president at their and Mr. Biden’s age. As I remember it, one of them said, “But he feels he has to do it.”
snippet: Joe Biden’s age has loomed over his presidency. He was right before about himself. Where stability and risk meet, he’s potentially asking people to again trust him.

headline: California Wants to Keep (Most of) the Colorado River for Itself
abstract: Six states that depend on the Colorado River want to share the burden of cuts in water use. But California refuses to play fair.
lead_paragraph: LAKE MEAD NATIONAL RECREATION AREA — If the Colorado River continues to dwindle from the same arid trend of the last two decades, it could take as little as two bad drought years to drive the reservoir here on the Arizona-Nevada border to dead pool. That’s the term for levels so low that water can barely flow out of Hoover Dam.
snippet: Six states that depend on the Colorado River want to share the burden of cuts in water use. But California refuses to play fair.

headline: Dianne Feinstein Is Old, Absolutely. She’s Also an Absolute Giant.
abstract: At 89, after more than 30 years in the Senate, a trailblazing woman has announced her retirement.
lead_paragraph: Beginning next week, I’ll be taking a monthlong break from the newsletter, which will be written by guest authors in my absence. I’ll return to the newsletter on Thursday, April 6.
snippet: At 89, after more than 30 years in the Senate, a trailblazing woman has announced her retirement.

headline: The Wisdom and Prophecy of Jimmy Carter’s ‘Malaise’ Speech
abstract: The irony is that it is better attuned to our time than to its own.
lead_paragraph: On July 15, 1979, President Jimmy Carter emerged from days of isolation to deliver the most important and memorable address of his life. Carter had canceled vacation plans and spent more than a week cloistered at Camp David, where he met with a “steady stream of visitors” who shared their hopes and fears about a nation in distress, most immediately thanks to another in a series of energy crises.
snippet: The irony is that it is better attuned to our time than to its own.

headline: Putin and the Right’s Tough-Guy Problem
abstract: What if wokeness doesn’t make you weak and swaggering does?
lead_paragraph: A democracy — imperfect, as all nations are, but aspiring to be part of the free world — is invaded by its much larger neighbor, a vicious dictatorship that commits mass atrocities. Defying the odds, the democracy beats back an attack most people expected to succeed in a matter of days, then holds the line and even regains ground over the months of brutal fighting that follow.
snippet: What if wokeness doesn’t make you weak and swaggering does?

headline: Let’s All Do the DeSantis Shimmy!
abstract: How to be a recovering globalist in a few easy lessons.
lead_paragraph: I suppose all contemporary young politicians dream of meeting their moment. At the enthusiastic dawn of their politico careers, they entertain a fantasy that some day, as a great historical challenge looms into view, their future selves will rise to the occasion — and masterfully dodge it!
snippet: How to be a recovering globalist in a few easy lessons.

headline: This War May Be Heading for a Cease-Fire
abstract: The Korean War shows that a frozen conflict can be preferable to the alternatives.
lead_paragraph: After a year of brutal fighting, in which thousands of lives have been lost, civilian infrastructure destroyed and untold damage caused, the war has reached a stalemate. Neither side will countenance a negotiated settlement. On the battlefield, battered armies contest small strips of territory, at a terrible cost. The threat of nuclear escalation hangs in the air.
snippet: The Korean War shows that a frozen conflict can be preferable to the alternatives.

headline: The Real Reason North Dakota Is Going After Books and Librarians
abstract: As a gay young person, I found refuge in libraries. Now in my state and others, they are under attack.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I was the keynote speaker at the North Dakota Library Association’s annual conference. The theme was “Libraries: The Place For Everyone.” There were rainbow flags, paper-link chains and multicolored glitter scattered across tables. It was the safest I have ever felt back home as an out, gay man. When I was a young person, libraries were where I went to find stories that made me feel I could fit in, not only in North Dakota, but in the wider world. But two pieces of legislation that may soon be signed into law in North Dakota would make it possible to restrict libraries and, in some cases, to imprison librarians.
snippet: As a gay young person, I found refuge in libraries. Now in my state and others, they are under attack.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Has a Dream
abstract: Her plans for a “national divorce” are very revealing.
lead_paragraph: Marjorie Taylor Greene, now one of the most influential Republicans in the House of Representatives, says it is time for Americans to consider a national divorce.
snippet: Her plans for a “national divorce” are very revealing.

headline: Inside the Minds of Spiders, Octopuses and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The science fiction writer Adrian Tchaikovsky explores what an explosion of A.I.-produced content would mean for human society and the human spirit.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Tchaikovsky’s “Children of Time” is about an advanced civilization built by sentient spiders. A sequel, “Children of Ruin,” is about a society run by superintelligent octopuses. I love these books. They’re remarkably serious about their premises, and by the end, it’s human civilization and our limited sensorium that come to seem strange.
snippet: The science fiction writer Adrian Tchaikovsky explores what an explosion of A.I.-produced content would mean for human society and the human spirit.

headline: Mike Pence’s Dangerous Ploy
abstract: The former vice president is injecting campaign-style politics into the special counsel’s inquiry and risks doing real damage to his reputation.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence recently announced he would challenge Special Counsel Jack Smith’s subpoena for him to appear before a grand jury in Washington as part of the investigation into former President Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election and the related Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. Mr. Pence claimed that “the Biden D.O.J. subpoena” was “unconstitutional” and “unprecedented.” He added, “For me, this is a moment where you have to decide where you stand, and I stand on the Constitution of the United States.” Mr. Pence vowed to take his fight all the way to the Supreme Court.
snippet: The former vice president is injecting campaign-style politics into the special counsel’s inquiry and risks doing real damage to his reputation.

headline: Don’t Let Politics Cloud Your View of What’s Going On With Teens and Depression
abstract: Josh Hawley may be right about this one thing.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a study came out showing that left-leaning adolescents were experiencing a greater increase in depression than their more conservative peers. Indeed, while girls are more likely to be depressed than boys, the study, by a group of epidemiologists at Columbia, showed that liberal boys had higher rates of depression than conservative girls.
snippet: Josh Hawley may be right about this one thing.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Adrian Tchaikovsky
abstract: A conversation with science-fiction writer Adrian Tchaikovsky.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Adrian Tchaikovsky. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: A conversation with science-fiction writer Adrian Tchaikovsky.

headline: The Perfect Retirement Investment Nobody Wants, Part 2
abstract: It doesn’t exist, but could it?
lead_paragraph: Readers were intrigued by my newsletter last Friday, “The Perfect Retirement Investment Nobody Wants.” It was about a concept, never realized, for a hybrid product combining long-term care insurance with an immediate annuity — a stream of monthly payments that begins right away and lasts as long as you live.
snippet: It doesn’t exist, but could it?

headline: Right Wing or Woke? The Complicated Politics of ‘Yellowstone.’
abstract: Patriarchy and pantheism in the American West.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a little bit about “Yellowstone” after my family’s cross-country road trip last summer, linking the hit soap opera to ongoing debates about land use and development and conservation in the American West. My column described the series as very “red state” and cited a very blue-state essay in which the author, Vulture’s Kathryn VanArendonk, described being drawn into the show almost in spite of herself. With its portrait of an embattled but sympathetic white male patriarch defending a cowboy way of life against coastal money and Californian transplants, it didn’t seem controversial to present the show as leaning rightward.
snippet: Patriarchy and pantheism in the American West.

headline: Wonking Out: Conservatives Face a Rude Fiscal Awokening
abstract: They can’t actually find much wasteful spending to cut.
lead_paragraph: The Republican response to President Biden’s suggestion that they want to cut Medicare and Social Security has been basically that of the Monty Python knights to the Killer Rabbit of Caerbannog: “Run away, run away!” But many in the party still appear to hope that they can make big spending cuts without hurting anyone they care about.
snippet: They can’t actually find much wasteful spending to cut.

headline: What the HBO Show ‘South Side’ Teaches Us
abstract: Black people are entirely comfortable with “details.”
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a very special sitcom that has nothing to do with school nonetheless gets you thinking about education and learning. In the case of HBO Max’s treasure “South Side,” it has also gotten me thinking about race, culture and even our current notions of alternative forms of objectivity.
snippet: Black people are entirely comfortable with “details.”

headline: The Price of Risk and the Reward of Joy Out in the Wild
abstract: The disappearance of the actor Julian Sands, the love of a dangerous pursuit, the humbling unpredictability of being out in nature, and me.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Jan. 13, the actor Julian Sands set off for a hike up Mount Baldy in California’s San Gabriel Mountains. He had done this kind of thing before: Mountain hiking was his passion. The 10,000-foot Mount Baldy is a difficult climb, but he had seen worse. In the Andes, he and three friends had reportedly been caught at 20,000 feet in a storm so violent, nearby climbers died. “We were lucky,” he later said.
snippet: The disappearance of the actor Julian Sands, the love of a dangerous pursuit, the humbling unpredictability of being out in nature, and me.

headline: The Promise and Peril of a ‘Normal’ Politician
abstract: In American politics, things have gotten pretty weird. Is a more normal kind of politics and politician possible without excluding people?
lead_paragraph: During his successful run for the presidency of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said that he was fighting for the rights of every Brazilian: the right to grill barbecue on weekends, to have picanha with a cold beer, “everything the people need,” he said.
snippet: In American politics, things have gotten pretty weird. Is a more normal kind of politics and politician possible without excluding people?

headline: From Carter to M.T.G.: What a Peach State Plummet
abstract: From Hope of the South to Dope of the South.
lead_paragraph: When Jimmy Carter was president, I was a lowly clerk at The Washington Star. I saw him mostly through the eyes of Pat Oliphant, our brilliant, biting cartoonist. As Carter came to be seen as uncool and fumbling, Oliphant drew the president smaller and smaller in relation to his tormentors — including that killer rabbit.
snippet: From Hope of the South to Dope of the South.

headline: America’s Increasingly Diverse Security State Is Changing Communities
abstract: Many Democrats expect demographic change to tilt the country leftward. That is not a given.
lead_paragraph: If Tyre Nichols’s violent death at the hands of the Memphis police felt tragically familiar, the revelation of the race of the five accused officers — five Black men — startled many. Perhaps it shouldn’t have. When it comes to law enforcement, the politics of race in the United States is becoming ever more complicated. Just ask migrants from Latin America who have suffered abuse at the hands of U.S. Border Patrol agents, over half of whom are Latino.
snippet: Many Democrats expect demographic change to tilt the country leftward. That is not a given.

headline: The Brave Man Whom Putin Wants to Kill
abstract: As the dissident Aleksei Navalny is tormented in a Russian prison cell, his daughter studies at Stanford and tries to keep her dad alive.
lead_paragraph: If Vladimir Putin has left you despising Russians as brutes, cowards or warmongers, consider a tall, ailing man locked in an isolation cell in Russia.
snippet: As the dissident Aleksei Navalny is tormented in a Russian prison cell, his daughter studies at Stanford and tries to keep her dad alive.

headline: The Founders Were More Creative Than You Think
abstract: We shouldn’t have a cramped view of how the Framers reasoned.
lead_paragraph: One of the articles I’m sharing this week is an essay on the Supreme Court’s gun rights jurisprudence by Heidi Li Feldman and Dahlia Lithwick at Slate. In particular, they look at the ways that the court’s decision in New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. Bruen has led lower court judges to invalidate longstanding gun regulations, on the argument that they are too unlike laws from the late 18th century to pass constitutional muster.
snippet: We shouldn’t have a cramped view of how the Framers reasoned.

headline: Why You Can’t Predict the Future of Religion
abstract: When it comes to the religious future, you should follow the social trends but also always expect the unexpected.
lead_paragraph: In an 1822 letter to the physician Benjamin Waterhouse, Thomas Jefferson expressed his confidence that traditional Christianity in the young United States was giving way to a more enlightened faith, much like Jefferson’s own in its rejection of the divinity of Jesus Christ. “I trust,” he wrote, “that there is not a young man now living in the U.S. who will not die an Unitarian.”
snippet: When it comes to the religious future, you should follow the social trends but also always expect the unexpected.

headline: The Imminent Danger of A.I. Is One We’re Not Talking About
abstract: We are so stuck on asking what the technology can do that we are missing the more important questions.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, I interviewed Ted Chiang, one of the great living sci-fi writers. Something he said to me then keeps coming to mind now.
snippet: We are so stuck on asking what the technology can do that we are missing the more important questions.

headline: Even Democrats Like Me Are Fed Up With San Francisco
abstract: San Francisco’s problems are largely attributable to a small coterie that knows how to bend government to its will.
lead_paragraph: Few subjects please Tucker Carlson more than sticking a shiv into the city of his birth — San Francisco. Sadly, Mr. Carlson has plenty of reasons for portraying San Francisco as a crippled city, hence his fondness for broadcasting clips of homeless encampments and drug addicts. But Mr. Carlson and his ilk have less interest in understanding why these problems exist.
snippet: San Francisco’s problems are largely attributable to a small coterie that knows how to bend government to its will.

headline: The Best Way to Explain the G.O.P. Is Found in the W.W.E.
abstract: Kayfabe — the knowledge that pro wrestling is fake — has a long and rich history in American entertainment. It also explains something deep about G.O.P. politics now.
lead_paragraph: What shall we call contemporary Republican ideology? Is it conservatism? Libertarianism? Authoritarianism? Trumpism? Fascism?
snippet: Kayfabe — the knowledge that pro wrestling is fake — has a long and rich history in American entertainment. It also explains something deep about G.O.P. politics now.

headline: Why Fox News Lied to the Viewers It ‘Respects’
abstract: It’s about representation.
lead_paragraph: There are some stories that are important enough to pause the news cycle and linger on them, to explore not just what happened but why. And so it is with Fox News’s role in the events leading up to Jan. 6, 2021. Thanks to a recent filing by Dominion Voting Systems in its defamation lawsuit against Fox, there is now compelling evidence that America’s most-watched cable news network presented information it knew to be false as part of an effort to placate an angry audience. It knowingly sacrificed its integrity to maintain its market share.
snippet: It’s about representation.

headline: The Wages of Idolatry
abstract: Worthy goals like freedom and autonomy can harm others if we hold them above all else.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Ash Wednesday marked the beginning of Lent, a 40-day period (not counting Sundays) in the Christian calendar that is focused on repentance and preparation for Easter. During Lent, Christians talk a lot about sin, an idea that for many bears the mothball scent of a religious relic long packed away and best left forgotten. For some, the terms “sin” and “sinner” seem self-hating or judgmental. For others, they sound silly, associated with things like lingerie and decadent chocolate cake, what the English writer Francis Spufford deemed “enjoyable naughtiness.” Even those of us comfortable with these terms often think of sin as individual bad choices, like stealing and committing adultery. All of these notions seem inadequate to describe the source of so much oppression, violence, chaos and heartbreak in our world and our lives.
snippet: Worthy goals like freedom and autonomy can harm others if we hold them above all else.

headline: A War With China Would Be Unlike Anything Americans Faced Before
abstract: A Chinese invasion of Taiwan may include a multipronged war strategy that causes havoc in American society.
lead_paragraph: A major war in the Indo-Pacific is probably more likely now than at any other time since World War II.
snippet: A Chinese invasion of Taiwan may include a multipronged war strategy that causes havoc in American society.

subject: Defense and Military Forces
United States Defense and Military Forces
Cyberwarfare and Defense
Supply Chain

headline: Biden’s Succession Problem
abstract: Giving voters a chance to participate in selecting Joe Biden’s running mate in 2024 would address the issues of age and succession.
lead_paragraph: Since the 2020 campaign, Republicans have tried to portray Joe Biden as being too old to be president, as mentally deficient, as one small step away from death or disability. Democrats do themselves no favors when they let it be known, as they have in recent polling, that they too think he is too old to run again.
snippet: Giving voters a chance to participate in selecting Joe Biden’s running mate in 2024 would address the issues of age and succession.

headline: This Is Not How Pete Buttigieg Wanted to Visit Ohio
abstract: There are many different ways to be lonely.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, Democratic strategists are worried about hanging on to support in the working class. The good news, from my perspective, is that it looks like the big problem is economic concerns, not cultural ones.
snippet: There are many different ways to be lonely.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: My Fellow Liberals Are Exaggerating the Dangers of Ron DeSantis
abstract: DeSantis would be bad. But he would not be worse than Trump.
lead_paragraph: To judge by several early polls, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has a decent shot of beating former President Donald Trump in the race to win the Republican presidential nomination in 2024. Some liberals have pronounced this terrible news — because, they say, a DeSantis presidency would be just as awful as, and perhaps even worse than, a second Trump term.
snippet: DeSantis would be bad. But he would not be worse than Trump.

headline: I Went to Syria, the Country That Remade Our World, and This Is What I Saw
abstract: We have abandoned the Syrian people to biblical devastation.
lead_paragraph: JINDIRES, Syria — She has no memory of the earthquake that broke her back and swallowed her daughters. Khaira Al Halbouni only knows what her husband told her afterward. In the middle of the night the building shook. He grabbed one daughter, Bisan, and their son, Ali. Take Mayas, their younger daughter, and run, he shouted.
snippet: We have abandoned the Syrian people to biblical devastation.

headline: Janet L. Yellen in Kyiv: Economic Aid to Ukraine Is Vital
abstract: Our commitment to support a brave people defending their country is unwavering.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A year ago, the capital where I am now was under siege by Russian forces. Sounds of gunfire and explosions filled the streets; missiles rained down on this and other cities across Ukraine. Many people, including Vladimir Putin, expected that Ukraine would quickly collapse.
snippet: Our commitment to support a brave people defending their country is unwavering.

headline: A Gold Mine of Clean Energy May Be Hiding Under Our Feet
abstract: The experts have ignored signs that free hydrogen occurs in nature — until now.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes we miss things in front of our faces. We don’t see what we aren’t looking for. “We can be blind to the obvious, and we are also blind to our blindness,” Daniel Kahneman, a psychologist who shared a Nobel in economic science, wrote in his 2011 book, “Thinking, Fast and Slow.” A flower, for instance. “Nobody sees a flower — really — it is so small — we haven’t time — and to see takes time, like to have a friend takes time,” the artist Georgia O’Keeffe once wrote.
snippet: The experts have ignored signs that free hydrogen occurs in nature — until now.

headline: Choosing Love and Community Over Shame and Jail
abstract: A note from the editor on a special Sunday Opinion section.
lead_paragraph: The United States is in the midst of a crisis. More than 100,000 people a year are dying from drug overdoses. In New York City about seven people lose their lives to opioids each day, according to recent reporting in The Times. And this is after more than half a century of America’s so-called war on drugs.
snippet: A note from the editor on a special Sunday Opinion section.

headline: Florida Could Start Looking a Lot Like Hungary
abstract: Ron DeSantis borrows from Viktor Orban’s playbook.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, the government of Hungarian prime minister Viktor Orban passed a law intended to drive Central European University, a prestigious school founded by a Hungarian refugee, George Soros, out of the country. At the time, this was shocking; as many as 80,000 protesters rallied in Budapest and intellectuals worldwide rushed to declare their solidarity with the demonstrators. “The fate of the university was a test of whether liberalism had the tactical savvy and emotional fortitude to beat back its new ideological foe,” wrote Franklin Foer in The Atlantic.
snippet: Ron DeSantis borrows from Viktor Orban’s playbook.

headline: Conspiracy Theorizing Goes Off the Rails
abstract: Did woke progressives cause the East Palestine disaster?
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 3 a train carrying hazardous materials derailed in East Palestine, Ohio. Some of the contents immediately caught fire. Three days later authorities released and burned off additional material from five tankers. These fires caused elevated levels of harmful chemicals in the local air, although the Environmental Protection Agency says that the pollution wasn’t severe enough to cause long-term health damage.
snippet: Did woke progressives cause the East Palestine disaster?

headline: Netanyahu Is Shattering Israeli Society
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s attack on the judiciary is throwing Israel into chaos.
lead_paragraph: Israel today is a boiler with way, way too much steam building up inside, and the bolts are about to fly off in all directions.
snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s attack on the judiciary is throwing Israel into chaos.

headline: Meet the World’s Most Honorable Bank Robbers
abstract: In Lebanon the economic collapse is forcing citizens to take extreme measures to get their savings.
lead_paragraph: A wave of armed bank robberies has been sweeping Lebanon amid its economic meltdown. But the heists have followed a highly unusual pattern: The robbers are the banks’ clients, and the money they have been demanding is the contents of their own accounts.
snippet: In Lebanon the economic collapse is forcing citizens to take extreme measures to get their savings.

author.Original: By Zach Goldbaum and Todd Bieber

headline: Our Brains Weren’t Designed for This Kind of Food
abstract: The neurobiologist Stephan Guyenet explains the fundamental mismatch between our bodies and the modern food system.
lead_paragraph: Our society’s dominant narrative is that body size is a product of individual willpower. We are skinny or fat because of the choices we make: the kinds of food we buy, the amounts we eat, the exercise regimens we follow.
snippet: The neurobiologist Stephan Guyenet explains the fundamental mismatch between our bodies and the modern food system.

headline: Hunter Biden Has Some Explaining to Do
abstract: There is a way for Joe Biden to let his son stand on his own without giving in to the Republican circus on the Hill.
lead_paragraph: Name a recurring Fox News segment, and there is a Republican congressional investigation for it: the origin of the coronavirus, the threat to our capital markets, supposed collaboration between social media companies and the Democratic Party. Some representatives have launched an investigation into whether the Department of Justice targeted parents who protested vaccine and mask mandates at school board meetings. No bit of pique is too tangential to escape their notice; Lauren Boebert recently demanded during one of these investigations that former Twitter representatives answer for her perceived shortage of likes: “Did either of you approve the shadow banning of my account @LaurenBoebert? Yes or no?”
snippet: There is a way for Joe Biden to let his son stand on his own without giving in to the Republican circus on the Hill.

headline: I Am Mourning the Loss of Something I Loved: McNuggets
abstract: I still love processed foods. But now that I “know better,” it’s harder for me to enjoy them.
lead_paragraph: Have you experienced the magic of McDonald’s Sprite? With its electric spice, its zhush, its je ne sais quoi, it is, of course, supreme among all sugary drinks, a star in the great firmament of processed foods.
snippet: I still love processed foods. But now that I “know better,” it’s harder for me to enjoy them.

headline: 1776 Is Not Just What Ron DeSantis Wants It to Be
abstract: The question is not which allies he hopes to empower or which elections he hopes to win, but what order he hopes to create and usher into being.
lead_paragraph: As part of his ongoing war on public education and so-called wokeness, Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, wants to put the state’s colleges and universities under strict political control.
snippet: The question is not which allies he hopes to empower or which elections he hopes to win, but what order he hopes to create and usher into being.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Stephan J. Guyenet
abstract: The Feb. 28, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Stephan J. Guyenet. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Feb. 28, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: How Not to Panic About Social Security
abstract: No, it’s not going to go bankrupt.
lead_paragraph: “The days of our years are threescore and ten,” says Psalm 90 in the King James Bible. So right now I’m about to [keels over].
snippet: No, it’s not going to go bankrupt.

headline: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: My Country Is in a Fragile Place
abstract: The Biden administration needs to stand behind the Nigerian people now and make a firm commitment to support election transparency.
lead_paragraph: Imagine standing patiently in line, waiting to vote, and suddenly men with guns arrive on motorcycles and start shooting. Imagine men dashing into your polling unit, violently seizing ballot boxes and taking them away. Imagine other ballot boxes being destroyed. Imagine being beaten to keep you from voting for a particular candidate. Imagine a crowd of people chanting “We must vote! We must vote!” when polling workers failed to arrive as expected. Imagine the police doing very little. All these things happened during the Nigerian presidential elections on Saturday. Through it all, there was a chilling lack of transparency from the Independent National Electoral Commission, or I.N.E.C., which oversees elections.
snippet: The Biden administration needs to stand behind the Nigerian people now and make a firm commitment to support election transparency.

headline: We’ve Been Talking About the Lab-Leak Hypothesis All Wrong
abstract: When are we going to get more serious about the highest-security labs?
lead_paragraph: Imagine yourself, if you can, in the months before the Covid-19 pandemic. Imagine being told then that a novel virus would emerge in China that would then spread around the world, infecting much of the global population, by some estimates killing more than 20 million people, and upending much of humanity’s social, political and economic life along the way.
snippet: When are we going to get more serious about the highest-security labs?

headline: The ‘Dilbert’ Cartoonist and the Durability of White-Flight Thinking
abstract: What Scott Adams said really wasn’t anything new.
lead_paragraph: When Scott Adams, the Donald Trump-revering creator of the “Dilbert” cartoon strip, last week quoted stats from the right-leaning polling operation Rasmussen Reports to justify a racist rant in which he admonished white people to “just get the hell away” from Black people, whom he labeled “a hate group,” the condemnations were swift.
snippet: What Scott Adams said really wasn’t anything new.

headline: On Ukraine, Biden Outshines Macron, Scholz — and DeSantis
abstract: Now we need to help Kyiv win decisively in 2023.
lead_paragraph: To President Emmanuel Macron of France, a suggestion:
snippet: Now we need to help Kyiv win decisively in 2023.

headline: This Is Trump’s ‘Magic Trick’
abstract: Trump is trapped by his own strategy. That doesn’t mean it won’t work.
lead_paragraph: In his effort to outflank Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida — his most potent challenger-in-waiting for the Republican presidential nomination — Donald Trump goes only in one direction: hard right.
snippet: Trump is trapped by his own strategy. That doesn’t mean it won’t work.

headline: My Liberal Campus Is Pushing Freethinkers to the Right
abstract: No longer moderating influences, universities have become breeding grounds for conservative firebrands.
lead_paragraph: In the not-so-distant past, the Typical College Republican idolized Ronald Reagan, fretted about the national debt and read Edmund Burke. Political sophistication, to that person, implied belief in the status quo.
snippet: No longer moderating influences, universities have become breeding grounds for conservative firebrands.

headline: Why Are Ketamine Ads Following Me Around the Internet?
abstract: The rules around pharmaceutical advertising need a 21st-century update.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago I started noticing that I couldn’t open Instagram or TikTok without getting an ad for ketamine. I previously knew ketamine only as an illegal drug that could cause dissociation, taken by acquaintances in the dank basements of my misspent youth, or as the sedative given to my older daughter when her broken arm needed to be reset in the hospital.
snippet: The rules around pharmaceutical advertising need a 21st-century update.

headline: The Spectacular Fall of Lori Lightfoot
abstract: Are Black mayors too quickly and easily blamed for rising crime?
lead_paragraph: It was a stunning rebuke. On Tuesday, Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago, the first Black woman and first openly L.G.B.T.Q. person to lead the city, failed to advance to a runoff, earning just 17 percent of the vote and becoming the first incumbent mayor in 40 years to lose a re-election bid.
snippet: Are Black mayors too quickly and easily blamed for rising crime?

headline: Four Experts on Tech Hiring Talk About Where the Jobs Are
abstract: Their answers gave me hope for the future of our species.
lead_paragraph: If artificial intelligence were going to cause mass unemployment, you would expect to see it happen first in the tech sector, where A.I. excels. To take just one example, ChatGPT is pretty good (not perfect) at generating code, fixing bugs and even building a website — doing in a few seconds what might take hours for a human programmer. Why bother hiring a person who has learned to think like a computer when you can employ a computer that thinks like a computer?
snippet: Their answers gave me hope for the future of our species.

headline: America Is In Over Its Head
abstract: The only way Ukraine can achieve total victory is with NATO troops on the ground. Is anyone ready for that?
lead_paragraph: The greatest blunder President Vladimir Putin may have made so far in Ukraine is giving the West the impression that Russia could lose the war. The early Russian strike on Kyiv stumbled and failed. The Russian behemoth seemed not nearly as formidable as it had been made out to be. The war suddenly appeared as a face-off between a mass of disenchanted Russian incompetents and supercharged, savvy Ukrainian patriots.
snippet: The only way Ukraine can achieve total victory is with NATO troops on the ground. Is anyone ready for that?

headline: Why the G.O.P.’s Attack on Trans Rights Could Backfire on the Party
abstract: A Republican state senator on what his party gets wrong about trans kids — and why he’s broken ranks to vote to protect them.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Thatcher was sworn in to the Utah State Senate in 2011, he had no plans to get involved in L.G.B.T.Q. advocacy. He’s a Republican, and he believed that your sexuality and gender identity are none of the government’s business.
snippet: A Republican state senator on what his party gets wrong about trans kids — and why he’s broken ranks to vote to protect them.

author.Original: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Sophia Alvarez Boyd, Derek Arthur, Anabel Bacon, Kaari Pitkin, Carole Sabouraud, Isaac Jones, Sonia Herrero and Pat McCusker
author.People: Garcia-Navarro Lulu, Boyd Sophia, Arthur Derek, Bacon Anabel, Pitkin Kaari, Sabouraud Carole, Jones Isaac, Herrero Sonia, McCusker Pat

headline: The Serene Hypocrisy of Nikki Haley
abstract: She makes sense if you listen to only half of what she says.
lead_paragraph: Astonishingly, some people still see Nikki Haley as one of the “good” Trump cabinet members, the future of a more tolerant and accepting Republican Party. Like those anti-Trumpers who willfully interpreted each casual flick of Melania’s wrist as a prospect of rebellion, Haley hopefuls want to believe that a conscience might yet emerge from Trump’s Team of Liars, that the G.O.P’s latest showcasing of a Can-Do Immigrant Success Story can somehow undo years of xenophobia.
snippet: She makes sense if you listen to only half of what she says.

headline: The Return of the Magicians
abstract: Why we are seeing so many attempts to link magic to science.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, I’ve found myself writing columns that touch on the rapid advance of artificial intelligence, the mystery of unidentified flying objects haunting American skies and the enthusiasm in certain circles for taking mind-altering substances that yield a feeling, illusory or not, of contact with supernatural-seeming entities.
snippet: Why we are seeing so many attempts to link magic to science.

headline: The Excellence of Kamala Harris Is Hiding in Plain Sight
abstract: Has she solved every problem? No, but name one vice president who has.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris occupies an office that can be the butt of jokes and criticism. The only duties of the vice president spelled out in the Constitution are to cast tiebreaking votes in the Senate and to become president if the office becomes vacant.
snippet: Has she solved every problem? No, but name one vice president who has.

headline: The Dictionary I Read for Fun
abstract: With many Native American languages facing extinction, we need to preserve them.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a book that is truly a gorgeous thing, in all senses of the word, was published. It is a third and expanded edition of a full-length dictionary of the Native American language Lakota. And I mean full-length. The New Lakota Dictionary, compiled by the Lakota Language Consortium under the supervision of the linguist Jan Ullrich, is of the physical heft most commonly associated with brands like Webster and American Heritage. (There is also an online version.)
snippet: With many Native American languages facing extinction, we need to preserve them.

headline: Two Different Versions of ‘Cancel Culture’
abstract: Scott Adams and the lab-leak theory of Covid.
lead_paragraph: I want to start this newsletter with two radically different stories. At first glance they have nothing in common, but they’re both directly relevant to the debate over cancel culture. Two very different kinds of speech faced private sanction, but only one was truly beyond the pale. Understanding the distinctions can help us achieve a greater degree of tolerance, one rooted in truth and grace rather than concerned about mistakes or poor judgment.
snippet: Scott Adams and the lab-leak theory of Covid.

headline: The Power of Art in a Political Age
abstract: Searching for beauty as the world turns ugly.
lead_paragraph: I sometimes feel I’m in a daily struggle not to become a shallower version of myself. The first driver of shallowization is technology, the way it shrinks attention span, fills the day with tempting distractions. The second driver is the politicization of everything. Like a lot of people, I spend too much of my time enmeshed in politics — the predictable partisan outrages, the campaign horse race analysis, the Trump scandal du jour.
snippet: Searching for beauty as the world turns ugly.

headline: The Promise and Peril of Biden’s Climate Policy
abstract: It’s a really big deal — but will the grid be able to handle it?
lead_paragraph: In 2010, at the signing ceremony for the Affordable Care Act, Joe Biden, the vice president at the time, could be overheard telling President Barack Obama that “this is a big something deal.” OK, that’s almost what he said. And he was right.
snippet: It’s a really big deal — but will the grid be able to handle it?

headline: What a Poetic Mind Can Teach Us About How to Live
abstract: The poet Jane Hirshfield invites us to embrace habits of deep noticing and attention — and observe the beauty that unfolds.
lead_paragraph: “Poetry is the attempt to understand fully what is real, what is present, what is imaginable, what is feelable, and how can I loosen the grip of what I already know to find some new, changed relationship,” the poet Jane Hirshfield tells me. Through poetry, she says, “I know something new and I have been changed.”
snippet: The poet Jane Hirshfield invites us to embrace habits of deep noticing and attention — and observe the beauty that unfolds.

headline: The Truth About the ‘Censorship’ of Roald Dahl
abstract: The corporate context in which the changes were made is what should really worry us.
lead_paragraph: When it was reported last month that hundreds of words had been changed or removed in the most recent British editions of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” “Matilda” and other books by Roald Dahl in an effort to make them less offensive, everyone from the queen consort and the British prime minister to the head of PEN America expressed outrage. Salman Rushdie referred to the edits as “censorship.”
snippet: The corporate context in which the changes were made is what should really worry us.

headline: Why Alex Murdaugh’s Quick Conviction Worries Me
abstract: The case was built on a trove of digital data. Could the jury have given it due consideration in just three hours?
lead_paragraph: As I watched the gripping murder trial of the prominent South Carolina attorney Alex Murdaugh over the last few weeks, I found myself wrestling with difficult questions about how data from smartphones and other digital technologies should be relied upon in the criminal justice system. We are all being constantly and intimately tracked by our gadgets, but the voluminous records produced by these devices are not always easy to interpret.
snippet: The case was built on a trove of digital data. Could the jury have given it due consideration in just three hours?

headline: A Warning for the Newest Victims of Federal Neglect and Corporate Greed in Ohio
abstract: I grew up near a toxic disaster. The years ahead in East Palestine could be tough.
lead_paragraph: Dead birds still fall from the sky near my hometown. Their bodies hit the ground as part of the fallout of an environmental disaster that dates back to the 1970s, the result of corporate pollution that made the county I grew up in the home of one of Michigan’s most notorious Superfund sites.
snippet: I grew up near a toxic disaster. The years ahead in East Palestine could be tough.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jane Hirshfield
abstract: The Mar. 3, 2023 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jane Hirshfield. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Mar. 3, 2023 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: Wonking Out: Peering Through the Fog of Inflation
abstract: If you aren’t feeling a bit lost, you aren’t paying attention.
lead_paragraph: Economists have been arguing fiercely about inflation for around two years now, and that’s fine.
snippet: If you aren’t feeling a bit lost, you aren’t paying attention.

headline: What a Visit to Disney World Reveals About America
abstract: Politics, decadence and pantheism in the Magic Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Walt Disney World is back in the culture-war news this week, thanks to Gov. Ron DeSantis’s appointment of a new board, filled with his ideological allies, to oversee infrastructure in Disney’s Florida real estate empire. As it happens, I’m now a certified expert on Disney World, as my wife and I recently took our children there for the first time, and let me tell you, there’s a lot to say about the place. Our several days there were intense enough that I could probably get multiple newsletters out of the experience, but I’ll just try to cram a bunch of ideas into this one, much the way I packed my kids into roller coaster cars and sent them hurtling away.
snippet: Politics, decadence and pantheism in the Magic Kingdom.

organizations: Disney, Walt, World (Lake Buena Vista, Fla)

headline: Why the Student Debt Pause Became a Political Trap
abstract: Debtors have gotten out of the habit of making monthly payments.
lead_paragraph: You lend a friend $1,000 and tell him to pay you back when he gets back on his feet. Of course, he says. A year goes by, then two, then three. He seems to be back on his feet, but the money isn’t back in your pocket. And now if you ask what happened to your thousand bucks, you seem like the bad guy.
snippet: Debtors have gotten out of the habit of making monthly payments.

headline: Have a Question About Preparing for the Next Pandemic? Ask the Experts.
abstract: Times Opinion wants to address your questions about pandemic preparedness.
lead_paragraph: Three years after our lives were upturned by the Covid-19 pandemic, questions remain. What have we learned? What about our leaders and policymakers? What happens next time?
snippet: Times Opinion wants to address your questions about pandemic preparedness.

headline: ‘My Love, You Can Do This’: A Dangerous Journey in a Quest for a Better Life
abstract: It doesn’t have to be this way.
lead_paragraph: On a cold night in late February, a group of Venezuelan migrants huddled for warmth near a dumpster in the middle of nowhere, just a few hours outside Mexico City. They were waiting for “La Bestia,” the freight train migrants use to get from southern Mexico to the United States border.
snippet: It doesn’t have to be this way.

headline: A 120-Year-Old Company Is Leaving Tesla in the Dust
abstract: Boring old Ford is proving to be a very modern company.
lead_paragraph: Tesla had me convinced, for a while, that it was a cool company.
snippet: Boring old Ford is proving to be a very modern company.

headline: Does Gene Editing Have a Future in Reproductive Medicine?
abstract: The desire for profit is colliding with fundamental values related to human health, equity and diversity.
lead_paragraph: Since James Watson and Francis Crick first described the structure of the DNA double helix, scientists have debated the potential for creating genetically modified babies. In 2018, a Chinese scientist named He Jiankui announced he had actually done it: He used a gene editing tool called CRISPR to edit the embryos of twin girls in hopes of making them resistant to H.I.V.
snippet: The desire for profit is colliding with fundamental values related to human health, equity and diversity.

headline: The Dirty Little Secret of Credit Card Rewards Programs
abstract: When you book a free hotel room using credit card rewards, poor consumers are ultimately footing the bill.
lead_paragraph: There’s an undeniable feeling of excitement when you turn your daily credit card swipes at Starbucks into first-class airfare or a weekend jaunt to Costa Rica. Thanks to mobile banking and the ease of autopay, you can scrupulously avoid any additional costs by paying your monthly bill in full. Free flights and exclusive discounts abound.
snippet: When you book a free hotel room using credit card rewards, poor consumers are ultimately footing the bill.

author.Original: By Chenzi Xu and Jeffrey Reppucci

headline: Imagine What These Women Could’ve Done if They’d Had Wives
abstract: What “Lives of the Wives” tells us about modern marriage.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, I edited a story by the historian Alexis Coe about the different ways literary husbands and wives publicly acknowledge each other in their books. To summarize and perhaps oversimplify: Husbands tend to thank their wives for their actual labor, like editing and research help, while wives tended to thank their husbands for their emotional support, possibly suggesting that men were less likely to offer practical assistance.
snippet: What “Lives of the Wives” tells us about modern marriage.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Lydia Tár?
abstract: We conductors in general delight in denigrating one another — that is, until one of us is dead. In other words, we are human.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Awards are still a week away, but at least one verdict is in: “Tár” is a hit, having already won some 60 international awards and six Oscar nominations, including for best picture, best directing and best actress in a leading role. It has also engendered passionate conversations, articles and interpretations.
snippet: We conductors in general delight in denigrating one another — that is, until one of us is dead. In other words, we are human.

headline: A New Battle in the War on Abortion Pills
abstract: A federal judge could soon issue a ruling that threatens access to one of two drugs commonly used in a medication abortion.
lead_paragraph: A ruling expected soon from a Trump-appointed federal judge in Texas could halt the provision of a drug called mifepristone for use in abortions. This would potentially make the drug very difficult to come by in all states — including those where abortion is legal.
snippet: A federal judge could soon issue a ruling that threatens access to one of two drugs commonly used in a medication abortion.

headline: Take Threats of ‘National Divorce’ Seriously
abstract: Animosity is the enemy of American unity.
lead_paragraph: About two weeks ago, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia kicked off a conversation about a “national divorce,” and it hasn’t really stopped. Greene says she doesn’t mean a true national division but rather an extreme form of federalism, in which red and blue states essentially live under completely different economic and constitutional structures while maintaining a nominal national union.
snippet: Animosity is the enemy of American unity.

headline: Utah Wants to Disable the Law That Led to the Creation of Four of Its Magnificent National Parks
abstract: A lawsuit all but invited by the country’s chief justice threatens one the most consequential authorities granted to presidents by Congress.
lead_paragraph: As the 20th century dawned, Manifest Destiny was encroaching on one of America’s marvels, the Grand Canyon. Miners and livestock herders had invaded it, and unscrupulous promoters were cashing in on tourists who wanted to see one of the wonders of the world.
snippet: A lawsuit all but invited by the country’s chief justice threatens one the most consequential authorities granted to presidents by Congress.

headline: Michael Bloomberg: Israel Is Courting Disaster
abstract: Netanyahu’s new government plan to overhaul the judiciary will harm Israel’s security, democracy and economy.
lead_paragraph: In more than 20 years of public life, I have steadfastly supported Israel and its people in both word and deed, including by building medical facilities there, co-founding a leadership center, supporting its innovative local programs and funding other good causes. I have never gotten involved in its domestic politics or criticized its government initiatives. But my love for Israel, my respect for its people and my concern about its future are now leading me to speak out against the current government’s attempt to effectively abolish the nation’s independent judiciary.
snippet: Netanyahu’s new government plan to overhaul the judiciary will harm Israel’s security, democracy and economy.

headline: Larry Hogan: I’m Not Seeking the Republican Nomination for President
abstract: I care more about ensuring a future for the Republican Party than securing my future in the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: I truly appreciate all those around the nation who have for many years encouraged me to run for president. After eight years of pouring my heart and soul into serving the people of Maryland, I have no desire to put my family through another grueling campaign just for the experience.
snippet: I care more about ensuring a future for the Republican Party than securing my future in the Republican Party.

headline: It Would Be Foolish to Ignore What Just Happened in Chicago
abstract: Democratic candidates everywhere should be paying attention to the miserable showing of Lori Lightfoot in the mayoral primary.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, the biggest political news from last week was the resounding defeat of the mayor of Chicago, Lori Lightfoot, in the primary. Your thoughts on her political downfall?
snippet: Democratic candidates everywhere should be paying attention to the miserable showing of Lori Lightfoot in the mayoral primary.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: What Republican Parents Really Want
abstract: How the party of family values can truly value families.
lead_paragraph: There has recently been a lot of chatter in Washington about family policy, and surprisingly to many people, a lot of it has happened among Republicans. Senators like Mitt Romney and Marco Rubio have released proposals that offer financial benefits to many American households for children, while other conservatives have talked about becoming a “parents’ party.” The overturning of Roe v. Wade has accelerated this trend.
snippet: How the party of family values can truly value families.

headline: It Was Donald Trump’s CPAC. (No One Else Came.)
abstract: At the four-day conclave of MAGA conservatives, only the former president provided a jolt of excitement.
lead_paragraph: The Conservative Political Action Conference is a festival disguised as a political meeting, a sales convention doubling as a revival, an annual celebration of a particular kind of conservatism and its red-hat-wearing, pin-collecting enthusiasts. It’s like the parking lot outside a concert: Everyone’s got something to sell or something to say.
snippet: At the four-day conclave of MAGA conservatives, only the former president provided a jolt of excitement.

author.Original: By Damon Winter and Jane Coaston

headline: There’s a Menace Hanging Over Brazil
abstract: And it’s not Jair Bolsonaro.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It reads like science fiction. In 93 pages, the text sketches out a strange future. In 2027, there’s a new pandemic, caused by the “Xvirus.” A year later, war breaks out between the United States and both China and Russia over bauxite deposits in Guyana. By the year 2035, Brazilians openly admit their innate conservatism and embrace a future where the word “Indigenous” barely exists.
snippet: And it’s not Jair Bolsonaro.

Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

headline: The Case Against (Some) Buybacks
abstract: Not in every instance, but in this one.
lead_paragraph: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo is determined not to let America’s tech giants play her for a fool. If they want taxpayer money under the CHIPS and Science Act, they will need to promise not to turn around and give the money to their shareholders through dividends or share repurchases.
snippet: Not in every instance, but in this one.

headline: City Life, Culture Wars and Conspiracy Theories
abstract: When walkability meets grievance and paranoia.
lead_paragraph: I have an apartment on New York’s Upper West Side. It’s a very densely populated area — according to census data the area within a one-mile radius of my place has around 100 residents per acre, or more than 60,000 per square mile. This dense (and, to be honest, affluent) population supports a huge variety of businesses: restaurants, groceries, hardware stores, specialty shops of all kinds. Most of what you might want to do or buy is within easy walking distance.
snippet: When walkability meets grievance and paranoia.

headline: Tennessee and the Anti-Drag Race
abstract: The right has found a more vulnerable subset of the L.G.B.T.Q. community to attack.
lead_paragraph: “The point of the law is to terrorize people.”
snippet: The right has found a more vulnerable subset of the L.G.B.T.Q. community to attack.

headline: From the Trenches in Ukraine, We Know Our Enemy Is in Shock
abstract: In the trenches near the front line, a soldier reveals his full potential.
lead_paragraph: An infantryman’s least favorite weather is a temperature of 35 degrees Fahrenheit and pouring rain, when the trench floods with knee-deep, near freezing water. Surviving in such conditions is truly an art, and it’s at these moments in particular that a trench has a special energy. Here people fight for their lives, for every manifestation of it. Here communion with God is sincere and more frequent than in any church.
snippet: In the trenches near the front line, a soldier reveals his full potential.

headline: Joe Biden: My Plan to Extend Medicare for Another Generation
abstract: Medicare is the rock-solid guarantee that Americans count on. My budget will make the Medicare trust fund solvent beyond 2050.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans work their whole lives, paying into Medicare with every working day — starting with their first jobs, even as teenagers. Medicare is more than a government program. It’s the rock-solid guarantee that Americans have counted on to be there for them when they retire.
snippet: Medicare is the rock-solid guarantee that Americans count on. My budget will make the Medicare trust fund solvent beyond 2050.

headline: If You Read the G.O.P.’s Anti-Trans Policies, You’ll See What It Really Wants
abstract: Gillian Branstetter of the A.C.L.U. explains the Republican Party’s aggressive, wide-ranging push to restrict transgender freedoms.
lead_paragraph: In the 2023 legislative session alone, Republican state legislators have introduced more than a hundred bills seeking to restrict transgender people’s freedoms, rights and health care access. To put that in perspective, in the 2018 legislative session, fewer than 20 such bills restricting transgender rights were proposed.
snippet: Gillian Branstetter of the A.C.L.U. explains the Republican Party’s aggressive, wide-ranging push to restrict transgender freedoms.

headline: The Overdose That Changed My 20s
abstract: When a director gets hold of an action movie he and his best friend made two decades ago, he reconsiders the risks they took as young men.
lead_paragraph: After the birth of my first daughter, I wanted to protect her at any cost. As I worried about what could happen to her, I started to think about the person she would be as a teenager. Would she be as limitless as I was as a young adult, pushing at the boundaries of her life?
snippet: When a director gets hold of an action movie he and his best friend made two decades ago, he reconsiders the risks they took as young men.

headline: Rikers Is Already Awful, and It’s Worse if You’re Trans
abstract: New York City has the chance to oppose the national rollback of trans rights.
lead_paragraph: Jails and prisons are rarely designed to be humane for anyone, but for trans, nonbinary and intersex people these institutions can be especially dangerous. Beyond the loss of community and freedom, these gender-expansive detainees frequently are denied a piece of themselves.
snippet: New York City has the chance to oppose the national rollback of trans rights.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Gillian Branstetter
abstract: The Mar. 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Gillian Branstetter. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Mar. 7, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: Guns, Ships and Chips: On Economic Inflexibility
abstract: Some hard lessons from a hard three years.
lead_paragraph: What do shipping containers and artillery shells have in common? This isn’t a trick question. The answer is that both have been in very short supply at some point over the past three years. And these shortages tell us something disturbing about modern economies: They aren’t nearly as flexible as many people, myself included, had thought.
snippet: Some hard lessons from a hard three years.

headline: American Jews, You Have to Choose Sides on Israel
abstract: The effect of Netanyahu’s policies can’t be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Israel’s founding in 1948, supporting the country’s security and its economic development and cementing its diplomatic ties to the U.S. have been the “religion” of many nonobservant American Jews — rather than studying Torah or keeping kosher. That mission drove fund-raising and forged solidarity among Jewish communities across America.
snippet: The effect of Netanyahu’s policies can’t be dismissed.

headline: I’m What’s Wrong With the Humanities
abstract: How 21st-century digital culture makes it impossible to read a 19th-century novel.
lead_paragraph: In the responses to a recent death-of-the-humanities dirge, a long reported piece by Nathan Heller for The New Yorker on the decline of the English major, you could see an illustration of its thesis: The story’s most depressing anecdotes were plucked out and swapped around on social media by people who probably did not even begin to make their way through the lengthy text itself.
snippet: How 21st-century digital culture makes it impossible to read a 19th-century novel.

headline: ‘The Death Knell for Higher Education in Florida’
abstract: When “freedom from indoctrination” is anything but.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, a liberal faction within America’s colleges and universities, corporate America and the media has promoted goals of diversity, equity and inclusion, endorsed regulations restricting “harmful speech,” encouraged the ostracization of dissenters and sought to grant enhanced status to the previously marginalized.
snippet: When “freedom from indoctrination” is anything but.

headline: Modi’s Final Assault on India’s Press Freedom Has Begun
abstract: The prime minister is killing journalism in Kashmir and intends to do the same for the rest of the ountry.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Oct. 19, 2020, as reporters and photographers for The Kashmir Times rushed to meet deadlines, government officials and the police swept into the newspaper’s offices in the city of Srinagar, chased out the staff and put a lock on the door that remains to this day.
snippet: The prime minister is killing journalism in Kashmir and intends to do the same for the rest of the ountry.

headline: Noam Chomsky: The False Promise of ChatGPT
abstract: The most prominent strain of A.I. encodes a flawed conception of language and knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Jorge Luis Borges once wrote that to live in a time of great peril and promise is to experience both tragedy and comedy, with “the imminence of a revelation” in understanding ourselves and the world. Today our supposedly revolutionary advancements in artificial intelligence are indeed cause for both concern and optimism. Optimism because intelligence is the means by which we solve problems. Concern because we fear that the most popular and fashionable strain of A.I. — machine learning — will degrade our science and debase our ethics by incorporating into our technology a fundamentally flawed conception of language and knowledge.
snippet: The most prominent strain of A.I. encodes a flawed conception of language and knowledge.

author.Original: By Noam Chomsky, Ian Roberts and Jeffrey Watumull
author.People: Chomsky Noam, Roberts Ian, Watumull Jeffrey

headline: Why Has the E.P.A. Allowed the Horrific Situation in Ohio to Continue?
abstract: By acting as a reluctant regulator, the E.P.A. has left people at the site of the derailment desperate for answers.
lead_paragraph: When a Norfolk Southern train carrying nearly 116,000 gallons of vinyl chloride derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, last month, local officials made a pivotal decision: to drain the highly toxic chemical into a ditch and set it on fire in a “controlled burn” to avoid a catastrophic explosion.
snippet: By acting as a reluctant regulator, the E.P.A. has left people at the site of the derailment desperate for answers.

headline: If We Want More Babies, Our ‘Profoundly Anti-Family’ System Needs an Overhaul
abstract: Readers weigh in on what might persuade them to expand their families.
lead_paragraph: For the third and final installment in my newsletter series on the declining fertility rates in developed nations, I wanted to highlight reader responses to a question I asked a couple of weeks ago: What potential policy change or benefit would encourage you to have a child or, if you’re already a parent, more children?
snippet: Readers weigh in on what might persuade them to expand their families.

headline: Why Racial Discussions Should Also Focus on Progress
abstract: Is that progress slow, uneven and often dispiriting? Of course. But that doesn’t make it any less real.
lead_paragraph: I have argued recently that a useful and inspiring history of modern Black America need not be dominated by discussions of white racism. And having done so, it seems reasonable for me to explain, to at least a limited degree, what I would envision as a potentially better approach.
snippet: Is that progress slow, uneven and often dispiriting? Of course. But that doesn’t make it any less real.

lead_paragraph: Lots of fun stuff going on in the Cayman Islands this spring, according to its tourist bureau. A fishing tournament, a music festival, a carnival named after “the tracks left in the sand by sea turtles as they crawl onto the beach to nest.”

headline: In America, We Trust the Wrong People
abstract: Why scammers get believed and asylum seekers don’t.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to day-to-day decisions about whether strangers are telling the truth, most of us rely on shortcuts: a person’s educational background, a job at a trusted institution, a recommendation from a mutual friend. But those shortcuts are far from foolproof, and they can be exploited by those who intend to mislead. They can also make us less inclined to believe the most vulnerable, the people who have the most to lose, as Dina Nayeri argues in her new book, “Who Gets Believed: When the Truth Isn’t Enough.” Nayeri is a refugee from Iran whose own journey in America illuminates the flaws in our system and how our ability to tell truth from lies is broken by bias.
snippet: Why scammers get believed and asylum seekers don’t.

abstract: How a Georgia peanut farmer helped me see what my country could be.
lead_paragraph: When the Carter presidency began, I was an 18-year-old Rockefeller Republican. By the time it ended, I was so liberal, my own grandmother called me a Communist.
snippet: How a Georgia peanut farmer helped me see what my country could be.
