headline: Can We Put an End to America’s Most Dangerous Myth?
abstract: Americans are taught that they have to go it alone. But what if we also valued the art of dependence?
lead_paragraph: From a child's earliest age, independence is extolled as a virtue, with “doing things on your own” as proof of maturity. I celebrated my daughter when she was little for picking out her books herself. She always wanted to go on the monkey bars without help and swung and did tricks until her hands were blistered. Now that she’s 12, I cheer her for taking herself home from school on the train and for climbing by herself at a gym for hours.
snippet: Americans are taught that they have to go it alone. But what if we also valued the art of dependence?

headline: Americans Are Getting Too Used to This Form of Rule
abstract: Executive latitude is necessary in a democracy, but emergency government shouldn’t be a permanent system.
lead_paragraph: When Solicitor General Elizabeth Prelogar appeared before the Supreme Court last week to defend the Biden administration’s ambitious plan to waive federal student loan debt, she had some explaining to do. The policy she’s defending belongs to Mr. Biden. But the system of governance it relies on is a product of the George W. Bush administration, a form of emergency rule meant to manage the post-Sept. 11 world. Abused in its day, it has, alas, been found useful by every administration since.
snippet: Executive latitude is necessary in a democracy, but emergency government shouldn’t be a permanent system.

headline: How to Get Kids to Hate English
abstract: It’s as if schools teach them to read and then make them dread doing so.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a world without English majors. In the last decade, the study of English and history in college has fallen by a third. At Columbia University, the share of English majors fell from 10 percent to 5 percent between 2002 and 2020. According to a recent story in The New Yorker, “The End of the English Major,” this decline is largely a result of economic factors — which departments get funded, what students earn after graduation, etc. Fields once wide open to English majors — teaching, academia, publishing, the arts, nonprofits, the media — have collapsed or become less desirable. Facing astronomical debt and an uncertain job market, students may find majors like communication arts and digital storytelling more pragmatic.
snippet: It’s as if schools teach them to read and then make them dread doing so.

headline: A New Voice for Winning Back Lost Democratic Voters
abstract: Marie Gluesenkamp Perez has a few tips and proven experience on how to win over disaffected Trump voters and defeat MAGA Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez chose her guest for last month’s State of the Union address in order to make one of her favorite points. She invited Cory Torppa, who teaches construction and manufacturing at Kalama High School in her district in southwest Washington State, and also directs the school district’s career and technical education program. President Biden did briefly mention career training that night in his very long list of plans; still, Ms. Gluesenkamp Perez wasn’t thrilled with the speech.
snippet: Marie Gluesenkamp Perez has a few tips and proven experience on how to win over disaffected Trump voters and defeat MAGA Republicans.

headline: Budget Wars: This Time Is Different
abstract: Biden is making sense. Republicans aren’t.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday the White House released its latest budget; Republicans haven’t offered a specific counterproposal, but they seem to be coalescing around a plan released by Russell Vought, Donald Trump’s last budget director. Neither plan will become law. Instead, they’re intended to position the two sides for the looming confrontation over the federal debt ceiling.
snippet: Biden is making sense. Republicans aren’t.

headline: The Self-Destructive Effects of Progressive Sadness
abstract: The recent emotional storm did nobody any good.
lead_paragraph: One well-established finding of social science research is that conservatives report being happier than liberals. Over the years, researchers have come up with a bunch of theories to explain this phenomenon.
snippet: The recent emotional storm did nobody any good.

headline: What Tucker Carlson Really Thinks
abstract: It is not what he says when he’s on the air.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, two news reports caught my attention. The first was an Emerson College poll of Republican primary voters in New Hampshire. Donald Trump holds an incredible 41-point lead over Ron DeSantis in the state that rescued Trump’s primary campaign after a second-place finish in Iowa in 2016. This result is in line with a series of national polls that also show Trump with a large lead over DeSantis. Trump is still the favorite to win the G.O.P. nomination. Any other conclusion at this early date is wishful thinking.
snippet: It is not what he says when he’s on the air.

headline: The Men — and Boys — Are Not Alright
abstract: Richard Reeves breaks down the evidence that many American males are falling behind in education, employment and health.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, when Congress passed Title IX to tackle gender equity in education, men were 13 percentage points more likely to hold bachelor’s degrees than women; today women are 15 points more likely to do so than men. The median real hourly wage for working men is lower today than it was in the 1970s. And men account for almost three out of four “deaths of despair,” from overdose or suicide.
snippet: Richard Reeves breaks down the evidence that many American males are falling behind in education, employment and health.

headline: ‘I Don’t Know Why He’s Not More Famous.’ Meet the Man Republicans Can’t Get Enough Of.
abstract: A cult hero to young conservatives, hippie back-to-the-landers and marginalized environmentalists alike, Thomas Massie could shape the future of the GOP.
lead_paragraph: The self-proclaimed “greenest member” of Congress is a Republican from rural Kentucky. He lives in an off-the-grid home he built himself, using timbers cut and rock quarried from his family cattle farm. He pipes in water from a nearby pond, and powers the home with solar panels and a battery from a wrecked Tesla that he salvaged and retrofitted.
snippet: A cult hero to young conservatives, hippie back-to-the-landers and marginalized environmentalists alike, Thomas Massie could shape the future of the GOP.

headline: The Right’s Obsession With Wokeness Is a Sign of Weakness
abstract: Without a clear purpose, conservatives are desperate for a unifying enemy.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Leo, a leader of the right-wing Federalist Society, an extraordinarily effective legal organization, is broadening his ambitions. Leo is hoping to transform American culture the way he transformed the judiciary. In the words of an investigative report produced by ProPublica and Documented, he aims to build a sort of “Federalist Society for everything,” devoted to helping reactionaries consolidate power in realms like Wall Street, Silicon Valley, journalism, Hollywood and academia.
snippet: Without a clear purpose, conservatives are desperate for a unifying enemy.

headline: Here’s Why the Science Is Clear That Masks Work
abstract: A respected science organization says its review of studies about respiratory viruses was misinterpreted to incorrectly claim masks were useless.
lead_paragraph: The debate over masks’ effectiveness in fighting the spread of the coronavirus intensified recently when a respected scientific nonprofit said its review of studies assessing measures to impede the spread of viral illnesses found it was “uncertain whether wearing masks or N95/P2 respirators helps to slow the spread of respiratory viruses.”
snippet: A respected science organization says its review of studies about respiratory viruses was misinterpreted to incorrectly claim masks were useless.

abstract: This year the Oscars are celebrating an unprecedented number of Asian artists. The recognition is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: As a mixed Asian kid growing up in the suburbs of Southern California in the 1990s, I was always searching television and movies for people who looked like me. Every glimpse of, say, Margaret Cho doing stand-up or BD Wong on “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” felt like an all-too-rare cause for celebration.
snippet: This year the Oscars are celebrating an unprecedented number of Asian artists. The recognition is long overdue.

Incendiary bombs soon crashed through tile rooftops, igniting fires in the surrounding thicket of tinderbox homes.
snippet: As survivors of the Tokyo firebombing fade away, Japan reassesses its longstanding pacifism.

headline: My Life With Tom Cruise

lead_paragraph: The other night, after the dishes were washed, the coffee machine set, the dog let out and the kids asleep, I planted myself on the couch with the TV remote in one hand, scrolling, and my phone in the other, scrolling. Settling on the bigger screen, I clicked on “Mission: Impossible — Rogue Nation” to find Tom Cruise dangling by his fingertips from a Russian cargo plane while sporting a business casual suit.
snippet: How the ageless actor has held my — and our — unbroken attention for a lifetime.

headline: This Changes Everything
abstract: I have tried to spend time regularly with the people working on A.I. I don’t know that I can convey just how weird that culture is.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google — and not one of the tech executives known for overstatement — said, “A.I. is probably the most important thing humanity has ever worked on. I think of it as something more profound than electricity or fire.”
snippet: I have tried to spend time regularly with the people working on A.I. I don’t know that I can convey just how weird that culture is.

headline: Don’t Let the Culture War Degrade the Constitution
abstract: Our right to free expression should not be contingent on our ability to gain political control.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution of the United States, properly interpreted, provides a marvelous method for handling social conflict. It empowers an elected government to enact even contentious new rules while protecting the most fundamental human rights of dissenting citizens. Political defeat is never total defeat. Losers of a given election still possess their basic civil liberties, and the combination of the right to speak and the right to vote provides them concrete hope for their preferred political outcomes.
snippet: Our right to free expression should not be contingent on our ability to gain political control.

headline: A Chinese Commonwealth? An Unpopular Idea Resurfaces in Taiwan.
abstract: The war in Ukraine is causing many Taiwanese to rethink their relationship with China.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Three months after Russia invaded Ukraine, Annette Lu, a former vice president of Taiwan, stood before reporters to promote a wildly unpopular idea. China and Taiwan, she said, should form a commonwealth that would be integrated economically, like the European Union, but remain separate politically. She called it One Zhonghua — a word that means “Chinese” in a cultural, ethnic or literary sense but is distinct from the word that refers to China in a political sense. It was a wink at the Chinese Communist Party’s insistence that there is only one China and that Taiwan is an inextricable part of it.
snippet: The war in Ukraine is causing many Taiwanese to rethink their relationship with China.

lead_paragraph: In June 1962, I graduated from high school, purchased my first airline ticket and set off for Alaska. I had talked myself into a summer job with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. My job included weekly flights with a bush pilot delivering supplies to points all over the Alaska Peninsula.
snippet: A federal court will rule soon on whether the Interior secretary can swap government land so a road can be built through a wilderness wildlife refuge.

headline: Something Is Missing From Americans’ Greatest Fears. It’s the Bomb.
abstract: Arms control began at a low point during the Cold War. Are we there again?
lead_paragraph: The announcement last month by President Vladimir Putin of Russia that his country would suspend participation in the last remaining nuclear arms control pact with the United States set off long-dormant alarm bells. American nuclear forces went on red alert, people rushed to restock nuclear shelters, toilet paper and powdered milk vanished from grocery shelves … at least in Mr. Putin’s dreams, given his fantasy of restoring Russia to the salad days of Cold War brinkmanship.
snippet: Arms control began at a low point during the Cold War. Are we there again?

headline: Just How Hypocritical Are the Supreme Court’s Conservative Justices Willing to Be?
abstract: Why critics are saying that the conservative justices are exercising political, not judicial, power.
lead_paragraph: Much of the public debate after the recent oral arguments before the Supreme Court in a pair of challenges to President Biden’s student loan debt forgiveness program has focused on the legal merits of the policy. headline: And the Best Acting Oscar Goes to … a Man and a Woman. Why?
abstract: Categories split between actors and actresses need to evolve. But we also need to ditch our gendered notions of what constitutes great acting.
lead_paragraph: For over three hours on Sunday night, we watched beautiful people pass golden statuettes back and forth while bestowing awards on worthy winners. As usual, four of the Oscar categories — best actor, supporting actor, actress and supporting actress — were divided by gender. None of the others were. There is no award for “best sound editing by a female” or “best screenplay by a gentleman.” So why are acting awards split up this way?
snippet: Categories split between actors and actresses need to evolve. But we also need to ditch our gendered notions of what constitutes great acting.

headline: Abortion Opponents Want to Make Women Afraid to Get Help From Their Friends
abstract: A wrongful-death lawsuit in Texas is an act of intimidation.
lead_paragraph: The month after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, a mother of two in Texas who had filed for divorce from her husband discovered she was pregnant. Determined not to have another child and worried that her husband would try to use the pregnancy to make her stay with him, she did what many of us would do and turned to two friends for help.
snippet: A wrongful-death lawsuit in Texas is an act of intimidation.

headline: How China Went From Economic Superstar to Faltering Giant
abstract: The analyst Dan Wang takes stock of how the country’s growth trajectory has changed.
lead_paragraph: In just a few years, the narrative on China has almost completely flipped. The dominant sentiments in America had been awe, envy and a kind of fear. China’s growth seemed relentless. Its manufacturing prowess was lapping ours. It weathered the pandemic without the mass death seen in the West. It could build housing and transit and infrastructure at a speed we could no longer even imagine.
snippet: The analyst Dan Wang takes stock of how the country’s growth trajectory has changed.

headline: The Government Is This Close to Reining in Some of the Worst Air Pollution
abstract: Stricter limits on oil and gas industry practices like venting and flaring will provide immediate health and climate benefits.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — For one 73-year-old patient in our hospital system, the simple act of breathing has become so difficult that a short walk during a medical appointment caused his blood oxygen levels to dangerously plummet. A retired Marine, he has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and uses supplemental oxygen but can no longer walk to his pickup truck without a struggle.
snippet: Stricter limits on oil and gas industry practices like venting and flaring will provide immediate health and climate benefits.

headline: We Should Give Up the Fantasy of Solving the Border Crisis
abstract: There are other, better ways to evaluate the health of our immigration system and to improve it.
lead_paragraph: How did President Biden go from denouncing the immigration policies of his predecessor to following in his footsteps by proposing a regulation that would make the vast majority of current asylum seekers ineligible? How did he go from decrying the detention of immigrant families to contemplating the mass use of it?
snippet: There are other, better ways to evaluate the health of our immigration system and to improve it.

headline: Working From Home Is Less Healthy Than You Think
abstract: Those who have the luxury of working from home might end up realizing that remote work is disadvantageous to their mental and physical well-being.
lead_paragraph: As companies struggle to find the right balance between in-person and remote work and workers fight for autonomy, the debate about returning to in-person work has largely focused on productivity. If employees are equally productive in remote settings, why ask them to return to the office? All things being equal, remote work is cheaper and more convenient than commuting.
snippet: Those who have the luxury of working from home might end up realizing that remote work is disadvantageous to their mental and physical well-being.

headline: The Debate Hugh Hefner Won and William Buckley Lost
abstract: There’s an unbridgeable divide between Barstool conservatives and social conservatives — and it’s warping the conservative movement.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, William F. Buckley Jr., the founder of National Review, hosted Hugh Hefner, the founder of the wildly successful Playboy magazine, on Mr. Buckley’s weekly public affairs show, “Firing Line,” for a discussion of sexual ethics.
snippet: There’s an unbridgeable divide between Barstool conservatives and social conservatives — and it’s warping the conservative movement.

headline: The Boys Who Cried ‘Woke!’
abstract: There’s a reason Republicans want to distract our attention from what’s really going on.
lead_paragraph: As soon as it was clear that Silicon Valley Bank would not survive the weekend, conservative influencers and Republican politicians had a culprit in sight.
snippet: There’s a reason Republicans want to distract our attention from what’s really going on.

headline: How Bad Was the Silicon Valley Bank Bailout?
abstract: It may not have been necessary, but it won’t do much harm, either.
lead_paragraph: So the feds stepped in to protect all deposits at Silicon Valley Bank, even though the law says that deposits only up to $250,000 are insured and even though there was a pretty good case that allowing big depositors to take a haircut wouldn’t have created a systemic crisis. S.V.B. was pretty sui generis, far more exposed both to interest risk and to potential runs than any other significant bank, so even some losses for larger depositors may not have caused much contagion.
snippet: It may not have been necessary, but it won’t do much harm, either.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Dan Wang
abstract: The Mar. 14, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Dan Wang. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Mar. 14, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: The High Art of Musical Theater
abstract: We assume that musicals lack sophistication, but that makes no sense.
lead_paragraph: A part of me has always felt guilty about loving musical theater.
snippet: We assume that musicals lack sophistication, but that makes no sense.

headline: Putin and Netanyahu Show Why Bad Things Happen to Bad Leaders
abstract: The two leaders have gotten an awful lot wrong.
lead_paragraph: It is shocking to me how much Vladimir Putin and Benjamin Netanyahu have in common these days: Both see themselves as great strategic chess players in a world where, they think, everyone else knows only how to play checkers. And yet both completely misread the world in which they were operating.
snippet: The two leaders have gotten an awful lot wrong.

headline: It’s a Spectacular Scandal, and a Warning to Europe
abstract: The bloc’s vulnerability to corruption has been dramatically exposed.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — It’s like something out of a crime novel. On an early December morning last year, after months spent staking out residences and tapping phones, Belgian police officers raided dozens of places across Brussels. Over the next three days, in apartments and hotel rooms and offices, they seized laptops, cellphones and approximately 1.5 million euros, or $1.6 million, in cash.
snippet: The bloc’s vulnerability to corruption has been dramatically exposed.

headline: The Silicon Valley Bank Rescue Just Changed Capitalism
abstract: Having bailed out depositors of a failing institution in full, how will the government refuse others?
lead_paragraph: After a career of writing about bank failures, I wound up in the middle of one when my bank, Silicon Valley Bank, was seized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. On Saturday, when I tried to pay a bill online, I was greeted by this not very reassuring missive:
snippet: Having bailed out depositors of a failing institution in full, how will the government refuse others?

headline: Pope Francis’ Decade of Division
abstract: How a reforming pope became Catholicism’s great polarizer.
lead_paragraph: Lent is with us, and so is the 10th anniversary of Pope Francis’ ascent to the papal throne — an appropriate conjunction, since these are days of tribulation for his papacy.
snippet: How a reforming pope became Catholicism’s great polarizer.

Popes
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

headline: Iraq Veterans, 20 Years Later: ‘I Don’t Know How to Explain the War to Myself’
abstract: Nearly 20 years after their deployment to Iraq, veterans grapple with their younger selves and try to make sense of the war.
lead_paragraph: Months after the United States invaded Iraq in 2003, I began filming the U.S. Army’s 2nd Battalion, 3rd Field Artillery Regiment (known as the Gunners) in Baghdad. The unit was housed in a bombed-out palace on the banks of the Tigris that they named Gunner Palace.
snippet: Nearly 20 years after their deployment to Iraq, veterans grapple with their younger selves and try to make sense of the war.

subject: Iraq War (2003-11)
Documentary Films and Programs
Veterans
United States Defense and Military Forces

headline: Fire, Then Ice: Are the Mountains Around My California Town Going to Collapse?
abstract: Now that extreme weather is our constant companion, everyone will have to find better ways to help one another.
lead_paragraph: Since I had to leave home a few days ago, my husband has been sleeping on the living room couch, under the strongest support beams in the house. Our roof has seen more than 40 feet of snow since November, and we’re not confident it can handle yet another storm. Already, meltwater behind an ice dam on the roof is leaking into our bedroom.
snippet: Now that extreme weather is our constant companion, everyone will have to find better ways to help one another.

headline: ‘The Era of Urban Supremacy Is Over’
abstract: Many of the nation’s major cities face a daunting future.
lead_paragraph: On the last day of February, Glen Lee, the chief financial officer of Washington, D.C., issued a warning to the mayor and members of the District of Columbia Council, who are undertaking such costly ventures as free bus service and expanded affordable housing.
snippet: Many of the nation’s major cities face a daunting future.

headline: A Rush to Mine the Deep Sea Is Underway. It Must Be Stopped.
abstract: A scramble to mine the deep sea could soon commence. And once it begins, there will be little hope of reining it in.
lead_paragraph: Descending to the depths of the ocean is part of my job as a deep-sea biologist. Traveling three miles below the sea surface never ceases to uplift me. I’ve seen strange and wonderful creatures, from anemones with seven-foot tentacles that billow across the seafloor, to sharks that glow in the dark, 1,000-year-old corals and blind white crabs sustained by bacteria they cultivate on their claws.
snippet: A scramble to mine the deep sea could soon commence. And once it begins, there will be little hope of reining it in.

headline: What We Can All Learn From a Prehistoric Fish
abstract: Economists often portray societal aging as a financial burden, but it isn’t just that.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, during a New York Financial Writers’ Association event at The New York Times Building in Manhattan, the veteran journalist Myron Kandel stood up and said, “When I started working here 71 years ago …”
snippet: Economists often portray societal aging as a financial burden, but it isn’t just that.

headline: Donald Trump Must Be Prosecuted
abstract: Prosecuting the former president would be a step toward mending the country.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump may finally be indicted. Finally!
snippet: Prosecuting the former president would be a step toward mending the country.

headline: The Kamala Removal Fantasy
abstract: Biden-Harris is here to stay.
lead_paragraph: So … it’s pretty clear Joe Biden is going to announce he’s running for re-election. What do you think he should do about Kamala Harris?
snippet: Biden-Harris is here to stay.

headline: Why Silicon Valley Bank Collapsed — And What Comes Next
abstract: The economic writer Noah Smith breaks down the recent bank failure and the questions emerging in its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, in the largest bank failure since 2008, Silicon Valley Bank failed.
snippet: The economic writer Noah Smith breaks down the recent bank failure and the questions emerging in its aftermath.

headline: I Was an S.V.B. Client. I Blame the Venture Capitalists.
abstract: It started with a culture of insular self-congratulation. It ended in an avalanche.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, I started a New York-based creative agency that specialized in branded content. Among creative agencies, the trend at the time was for names that sounded like punk bands, and I unfortunately chose the Insurrection. As of last week, the only thing that aged worse than the name was my choice of bank: Silicon Valley Bank, which has now become the most spectacular example of a bank failure since the 2008 financial crisis. (I briefly lost access to our company’s funds, but I’m fine; my deposits were low enough to be covered by F.D.I.C. guarantees.)
snippet: It started with a culture of insular self-congratulation. It ended in an avalanche.

headline: This Conversation Changed the Way I Think About Dementia
abstract: When cognitive decline strikes, caregivers often resist the changes. Anne Basting says there’s another way.
lead_paragraph: I’ve seen and experienced the toll dementia takes on a loved one. And I’m far from alone: One in three seniors dies with Alzheimer’s or other forms of dementia. But the symptoms and decline usually happen in private, which can make figuring out a way to live with the illness isolating and frustrating — both for people with dementia and the people who care for them.
snippet: When cognitive decline strikes, caregivers often resist the changes. Anne Basting says there’s another way.

headline: The Aftermath of a Pandemic Requires as Much Focus as the Start
abstract: The pandemic diverted resources from essential health needs of all kinds. Now America must rally the world to invest in recovery.
lead_paragraph: By the end of 2021, Americans were dying three years sooner, on average, than they were before Covid-19, with life expectancy falling from 79 years to 76 years, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s most recent statistics.
snippet: The pandemic diverted resources from essential health needs of all kinds. Now America must rally the world to invest in recovery.

headline: I Pledge Allegiance to … My Conscience
abstract: There are many ways to express patriotism.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 29, 2022, Marissa Barnwell, an honor student at River Bluff High School in Lexington, S.C., was walking to class when the Pledge of Allegiance came on over the loudspeaker. It was Marissa’s 15th birthday and, as she told me recently, “I started off that day very happy, just living life.” Though other students passed in the hallway without incident, school camera footage shows a confrontation between Marissa and a teacher. According to Marissa, the teacher yelled at her to stop walking, grabbed her by the arm and pushed her against a hallway wall. She was then escorted to the principal’s office.
snippet: There are many ways to express patriotism.

headline: All-or-Nothing Abortion Politics Will Leave Women With Nothing
abstract: I’m afraid pregnant women will die if we don’t change Tennessee’s abortion law.
lead_paragraph: Before the Supreme Court’s ruling in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, I did not consider myself an abortion provider. Ninety-five percent of my work as a high-risk obstetrician was helping women through complex pregnancies to achieve healthy outcomes for both them and their babies.
snippet: I’m afraid pregnant women will die if we don’t change Tennessee’s abortion law.

subject: Abortion

headline: America Is in a Disgraced Class of Its Own
abstract: This rich country has the means to abolish poverty.
lead_paragraph: The United States has a poverty problem.
snippet: This rich country has the means to abolish poverty.

headline: 20 Years On From That Hotel Roof in Baghdad, I Know the Limits of My Trade
abstract: I learned that there is no such thing as an objective narrator in human conflict.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago this week, I witnessed the opening salvos of the United States invasion of Iraq from the rooftop of the Palestine Hotel in Baghdad. I was among the few foreign journalists not embedded with the American military who remained to cover the start of the war from the capital. It was not my first war as a photographer, but it was the first time I had experienced bombardment in a densely populated urban center.
snippet: I learned that there is no such thing as an objective narrator in human conflict.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Noah Smith
abstract: The Mar. 16, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Noah Smith. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Mar. 16, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: Three and a Half Myths About the Bank Bailouts
abstract: There were good reasons to act, despite uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, U.S. policymakers went all in on bailing out two medium-size banks: Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.
snippet: There were good reasons to act, despite uncertainty.

headline: How Big of a Climate Betrayal Is the Willow Oil Project?
abstract: The world wants to have it both ways on fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, when President Biden approved ConocoPhillips’s $8 billion plan to extract 600 million barrels of oil from federal lands in Alaska, the announcement landed simultaneously with the thud of betrayal and the air of inevitability. On the campaign trail, Biden had promised “no more drilling on federal lands, period. Period, period, period.” But for all the talk about the renewables boom and the green transition, and all the money pouring into them as well, there has been little concerted effort, in the United States at least, to really draw down our profligate use of the stuff that is actually poisoning the climate: fossil fuels.
snippet: The world wants to have it both ways on fossil fuels.

headline: The Cynical Reason College Applications Are Surging
abstract: For colleges, admissions is a business, and business is booming.
lead_paragraph: Frank is on leave this month and will return on Thursday, April 6. In the meantime, this newsletter is being written by a series of guest authors with some personal connection to him or a thematic connection to his work. Today’s contributor is Jeffrey Selingo, a former editor of the Chronicle of Higher Education and the author of “Who Gets In and Why: A Year Inside College Admissions.”
snippet: For colleges, admissions is a business, and business is booming.

headline: There Was Ronald Reagan, Calling Out Russia. And Now We Have … Ron DeSantis.
abstract: DeSantis and Trump project weakness and moral ambiguity in the face of a weaker power.
lead_paragraph: On March 8, 1983, Ronald Reagan gave one of the most famous speeches of his presidency, an address that would go down in history as the “evil empire speech.” If you watch it today — and you remember the Reagan presidency — you can see that it was vintage Reagan, full of confidence in the American nation and the American people, replete with references to the necessity of both liberty and morality to the success of the United States.
snippet: DeSantis and Trump project weakness and moral ambiguity in the face of a weaker power.

headline: Trump and DeSantis Could Both Lose
abstract: The Post-Tucker conservatives have arrived.
lead_paragraph: There are two different narratives running through the Republican Party right now. The first is the Trumpian populist narrative we’re all familiar with: American carnage … the elites have betrayed us … the left is destroying us … I am your retribution.
snippet: The Post-Tucker conservatives have arrived.

headline: You Don’t Have to Be a Doctor to Know How Much Trouble the N.H.S. Is In
abstract: But it’s not too late to save it.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 15, nurses walked out and began the largest nurses’ strike in the history of Britain’s National Health Service. They were protesting working conditions that have left them burned out and stretched thin — and compromised patient safety — and wages that fell in the last decade in real terms. Ambulance workers joined them. This week, thousands of junior doctors went on strike for three consecutive days.
snippet: But it’s not too late to save it.

author.Original: By Allyson Pollock and Peter Roderick

headline: If You Want to Know What Republicans Think About How Americans Feel, Ask Walgreens
abstract: The abortion pill decision by Walgreens reflects the right’s success in using corporations to affect public policy.
lead_paragraph: The corporate culture wars have reached a turning point: A number of companies that once championed social justice and equity seem to be beating a hasty retreat.
snippet: The abortion pill decision by Walgreens reflects the right’s success in using corporations to affect public policy.

headline: What’s Wrong With Getting a Little Free Legal Advice?
abstract: State laws prohibiting the “unauthorized practice of law” hurt those who cannot afford a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: When the United States was founded, friends and neighbors could freely advise one another how to deal with legal problems. Anyone could give advice about the law or draft legal documents for others. One had to be a lawyer to advocate before certain courts, but that was all that lawyers had an exclusive right to do.
snippet: State laws prohibiting the “unauthorized practice of law” hurt those who cannot afford a lawyer.

author.Original: By Bruce A. Green and David Udell

headline: What Liberal Catholicism Gets Right
abstract: On the obvious limits of the church’s infallibility.
lead_paragraph: My column on Wednesday cast a cold eye on the 10th anniversary of Pope Francis’ pontificate. But this is the Lenten season, and as a longtime critic of the present pontiff, it wouldn’t be particularly penitential for me to focus exclusively on his struggles. So in this newsletter I’m going to find some points of agreement with a school of thought I usually argue with, and talk about what liberal Catholicism, as a broad worldview that clearly influences the Francis pontificate, has gotten right.
snippet: On the obvious limits of the church’s infallibility.

headline: The Fed’s Balance Sheet Looks Like Silicon Valley Bank’s
abstract: The world’s largest central bank isn’t in crisis, but it is losing money at the moment.
lead_paragraph: A bad balance sheet killed Silicon Valley Bank. You know what other bank has a similar balance sheet? The Federal Reserve, the world’s largest and most influential central bank.
snippet: The world’s largest central bank isn’t in crisis, but it is losing money at the moment.

headline: America Has Decided It Went Overboard on Covid-19
abstract: The idea that pandemic response went too far is no longer confined to the margins.
lead_paragraph: In both the United States and Britain, there is suddenly a front-and-center debate about the very earliest days of the pandemic and how each country responded. Did mitigation measures imposed in the spring of 2020, amid great anxiety and uncertainty, actually work? And considering the costs, were they worth it?
snippet: The idea that pandemic response went too far is no longer confined to the margins.

headline: Stop the Partisan Bickering. We Need Smart Solutions to Save Our Banking System.
abstract: A former S.E.C. chief and a former National Economic Council director on what regulators need to do to keep America’s small banks alive.
lead_paragraph: We have spent the past 15 years focused on whether some banks are too big to fail. Today we need to focus on the small and medium-size institutions that account for almost a third of all bank lending and are essential to many communities and industries. It is a perilous moment for them. What happens next could determine not only their survival but also have profound effects on our future.
snippet: A former S.E.C. chief and a former National Economic Council director on what regulators need to do to keep America’s small banks alive.

headline: Tradition, ‘Tradition!’ and the Memory of Topol on the Roof
abstract: Tevye was a creature of the old world, but the man who immortalized him on film was something entirely new.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I bought my father a T-shirt printed with the Yiddish words “Shver tsu zayn a yid” (“It’s hard to be a Jew”). The expression is something between a joke and a boast.
snippet: Tevye was a creature of the old world, but the man who immortalized him on film was something entirely new.

headline: Can a Neuroscientist Fight Cancer With Mere Thought?
abstract: The neuroscientist David J. Linden on what might be causing the delayed progress of his cancer.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three months ago, I underwent surgery to remove a huge mass from my heart. While the surgeon was able to excise most of it, a portion about the size of an apricot had become interwoven with my heart wall and could not be removed.
snippet: The neuroscientist David J. Linden on what might be causing the delayed progress of his cancer.

headline: Ancient Judaism Recognized a Range of Genders. It’s Time We Did, Too.
abstract: Trans liberation is a gift to everyone because it expands the categories for what it means to be human.
lead_paragraph: I’m not a detail-oriented person. My clothes are usually rumpled; when I write, I rarely dot every i or cross each t (either literally or metaphorically). But when I am officiating at a funeral, I meticulously study each letter of the name of the person who died — especially when I’m leading a memorial service for a transgender or nonbinary person. Our names are so often disrespected in life, let alone death.
snippet: Trans liberation is a gift to everyone because it expands the categories for what it means to be human.

headline: Being an Open and Democratic Country Does Not Mean Being a Sucker
abstract: China poses a broad range of data security risks.
lead_paragraph: There’s growing momentum in Congress to ban TikTok, the social media app owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, for reasons of national security. Last week, the White House expressed support for a bipartisan bill in the Senate that would give President Biden the power to ban the app, and the White House is also reportedly pressing ByteDance to sell the company.
snippet: China poses a broad range of data security risks.

author.Original: By Peter Harrell and Tim Wu

headline: He’s the World’s Most Popular Leader. Beware.
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India is building roads while also dangerously corroding democracy.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — All over the Indian capital these days loom posters of Narendra Modi, presenting him as the great modernizing prime minister pulling India forward. But those posters also hint at the opposite: an emerging personality cult and an authoritarian streak that is dragging India backward.
snippet: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India is building roads while also dangerously corroding democracy.

headline: Can We Slow This All Down, Please?
abstract: Banking is a critical form of public infrastructure that we pretend is a private act of risk management.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, an observation by Matt Klein, a financial journalist, has gotten passed around quite a bit. “This was more a case of a ‘bank-run by idiots’ rather than a ‘bank run by idiots,’” he wrote, referring to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank.
snippet: Banking is a critical form of public infrastructure that we pretend is a private act of risk management.

headline: Women’s Health Care Is Underfunded. The Consequences Are Dire.
abstract: We don’t know enough about perinatal maladies like hyperemesis and postpartum psychosis.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, I talked to Marlena Fejzo about her research on hyperemesis gravidarum — morning sickness so extreme it “can lead to dehydration, weight loss and vitamin deficiencies.” At the time, I noted that Fejzo, who had suffered from the condition herself, was one of the few researchers studying the malady, despite that in Western societies it’s the most common reason for first-trimester hospitalizations and can be, in extreme cases, life threatening.
snippet: We don’t know enough about perinatal maladies like hyperemesis and postpartum psychosis.

headline: What It Means to Be Woke
abstract: It boils down to cultural and psychological project.
lead_paragraph: This week the conservative writer Bethany Mandel had the kind of moment that can happen to anyone who talks in public for a living: While promoting a new book critiquing progressivism, she was asked to define the term “woke” by an interviewer — a reasonable question, but one that made her brain freeze and her words stumble. The viral clip, in turn, yielded an outpouring of arguments about the word itself: Can it be usefully defined? Is it just a right-wing pejorative? Is there any universally accepted label for what it’s trying to describe?
snippet: It boils down to cultural and psychological project.

headline: What if Kids Are Sad and Stressed Because Their Parents Are?
abstract: To heal our children, we need to heal ourselves.
lead_paragraph: There is a depressing familiarity now to the conversations I’m hearing among parents of teenagers. After the obligatory pleasantries, talk often turns to mental health. Someone’s daughter is struggling, battling body image issues. Someone’s son is sullen and lost in video games. The parental concerns of previous generations (sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll) have been replaced by a new triumvirate: anxiety, depression and suicidal ideation.
snippet: To heal our children, we need to heal ourselves.

headline: Ron DeSantis Has a Secret Theory of Trump
abstract: It’s buried in “The Courage to Be Free,” but it’s unmistakably there.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis has an enemies list, and you can probably guess who’s on it.
snippet: It’s buried in “The Courage to Be Free,” but it’s unmistakably there.

creative_works: The Courage to Be Free: Florida's Blueprint for America's Revival (Book)
subject: Presidential Election of 2024

headline: My Dangerous, Lonely Life in Myanmar’s Resistance
abstract: Opposing the military coup means a life of safe houses, code words and peril, and it’s getting harder.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — When the military seized power in a coup on the morning of Feb. 1, 2021, I grabbed some clothes and other essentials and stumbled out onto the streets of Yangon. I haven’t returned home since.
snippet: Opposing the military coup means a life of safe houses, code words and peril, and it’s getting harder.

subject: Demonstrations, Protests and Riots
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Defense and Military Forces

headline: Bill Gates: ‘I Worry We’re Making the Same Mistakes Again’
abstract: “We can’t afford to get caught flat-footed again.”
lead_paragraph: Imagine there’s a small fire in your kitchen. Your fire alarm goes off, warning everyone nearby about the danger. Someone calls 911. You try to put the fire out yourself — maybe you even have a fire extinguisher under the sink. If that doesn’t work, you know how to safely evacuate. By the time you get outside, a fire truck is already pulling up. Firefighters use the hydrant in front of your house to extinguish the flames before any of your neighbors’ homes are ever at risk of catching fire.
snippet: “We can’t afford to get caught flat-footed again.”

headline: On Pets, Moral Logic and Love
abstract: I didn’t think I was a dog person. Then Herbie showed up and taught me a lesson about love.
lead_paragraph: In January, I fell in love with someone. It was the last thing I’d expect and caught me completely off guard.
snippet: I didn’t think I was a dog person. Then Herbie showed up and taught me a lesson about love.

headline: I Fantasized About Multiple Timelines, and It Nearly Ruined My Life
abstract: The multiverse has become a favorite pop cosmology. But there’s a danger in getting fixated on the fantasy that there are other, better versions of our world.
lead_paragraph: The patient was elderly and lived alone. She was showing signs of depression, but it was clear that something more was amiss. She insisted she was trapped in the wrong timeline.
snippet: The multiverse has become a favorite pop cosmology. But there’s a danger in getting fixated on the fantasy that there are other, better versions of our world.

subject: Capgras Syndrome

headline: Before His Death, I Asked the Manhattan D.A. What His Greatest Fear Was. He Answered: ‘Trump.’
abstract: The history behind the unlikely friendship between Robert Morgenthau and Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: IN THE SUMMER OF 2019, when Robert M. Morgenthau, who reigned over New York law enforcement for six decades, died, 10 days short of his 100th birthday, eulogies filled the newspapers, the governor ordered flags to half-staff, and the man in the White House weighed in. “I was saddened to learn of the recent passing of Bob Morgenthau, a truly great man!” Donald Trump wrote on Twitter.
snippet: The history behind the unlikely friendship between Robert Morgenthau and Donald Trump.

headline: How to Fix the TikTok Problem
abstract: If only Big Tech were getting the same scrutiny and enforced accountability that TikTok is enduring.
lead_paragraph: Banning TikTok won’t keep us safe.
snippet: If only Big Tech were getting the same scrutiny and enforced accountability that TikTok is enduring.

headline: Never Mind About Ron DeSantis
abstract: The governor of Florida has the national interest all wrong.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I guess we have to talk about Donald Trump’s potential indictment and arrest, right? But before we go there: You know how I told you that I’d vote for Ron DeSantis over Joe Biden?
snippet: The governor of Florida has the national interest all wrong.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: The Colorado River Is Running Dry, but Nobody Wants to Talk About the Mud
abstract: It’s time to drill holes in Glen Canyon Dam on the Colorado River and empty Lake Powell.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult to fathom how the Colorado River could possibly carve the mile-deep chasm that is the Grand Canyon. But if one thinks of the river as a flume of liquid sandpaper rubbing the land over millions of years, it begins to make sense. “The finest workers in stone are not copper or steel tools,” Henry David Thoreau wrote, “but the gentle touches of air and water working at their leisure with a liberal allowance of time.”
snippet: It’s time to drill holes in Glen Canyon Dam on the Colorado River and empty Lake Powell.

headline: Americans Have Mostly Forgotten the Iraq War. I Haven’t.
abstract: For some, even 20 years later, the war hasn’t ended.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a farewell party.
snippet: For some, even 20 years later, the war hasn’t ended.

headline: How to Fight Climate Change for a Bargain
abstract: A new study argues that ramping up renewable energy production would bring down costs more quickly.
lead_paragraph: Conventional economic wisdom says that it’s costly and inefficient to spend a lot of money fixing a problem before the necessary technology has matured. By that logic, the environmental pluses from quickly stopping climate change have to be weighed against the economic minus of higher costs.
snippet: A new study argues that ramping up renewable energy production would bring down costs more quickly.

headline: Break the Chain Between Russian Oligarchs and Managers, and You Break Everything
abstract: Impose sanctions on the wealth managers who create these complex offshore shell games.
lead_paragraph: Russian oligarchs were hit with sanctions last year in an effort to cut off Vladimir Putin’s overseas lieutenants from their vast offshore wealth — an estimated 60 percent of their net worth. Mega-yachts, private jets and luxury villas were seized, sometimes with news cameras rolling. Yet for all that drama, much of the oligarchs’ money was quietly moved to safer havens.
snippet: Impose sanctions on the wealth managers who create these complex offshore shell games.

headline: A.I. Is About to Get Much Weirder. Here’s What to Watch For.
abstract: The Vox writer Kelsey Piper talks about the increasing pace of A.I. development, how it’s changing the world and what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI last week released its most powerful language model yet: GPT-4, which vastly outperforms its predecessor GPT-3.5 on a variety of tasks.
snippet: The Vox writer Kelsey Piper talks about the increasing pace of A.I. development, how it’s changing the world and what to do about it.

headline: In This Story, George W. Bush Is the Hero
abstract: Twenty years ago, Bush did something amazing. Hint: It wasn’t the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: When President George W. Bush invaded Iraq 20 years ago this week, I was in the middle of the smoke and chaos of that cataclysmic war that became his best-known legacy. I wrote countless columns opposing an invasion, then I was scathing as I covered the war, and I still see it as a practical and moral catastrophe.
snippet: Twenty years ago, Bush did something amazing. Hint: It wasn’t the Iraq war.

headline: Make No Mistake, the Investigation of Donald Trump and the Stormy Daniels Scheme Is Serious
abstract: Trump’s former job does not, and should not, immunize him from the accountability that would be sought for anyone else.
lead_paragraph: Though it may be tempting to do so, it is a mistake to assess the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation of Donald Trump by comparing its relative severity with those of myriad other crimes possibly committed by him. That is not how state and federal prosecutors will — or should — be thinking about the issue of charging Mr. Trump or, for that matter, any other defendant.
snippet: Trump’s former job does not, and should not, immunize him from the accountability that would be sought for anyone else.

author.Original: By Ryan Goodman and Andrew Weissmann

headline: Even the Supreme Court Can’t Save the N.C.A.A. From Itself
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling paved the way for college athletes to earn financial payments. But a governing body’s neglect means the players are still powerless pawns.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. is the easiest target in sports, and that’s entirely its own fault. Decades of defending a system premised on the unpaid labor of its athletes — a system that Walter Byers, one of its architects, later regretfully compared to a “neo-plantation” — has whittled the N.C.A.A.’s credibility to near nonexistence.
snippet: A Supreme Court ruling paved the way for college athletes to earn financial payments. But a governing body’s neglect means the players are still powerless pawns.

headline: Trump Could Stand in the Middle of Fifth Avenue and Not Lose Mike Pence
abstract: Pence is still afraid of the former president, and he is not alone.
lead_paragraph: Mike Pence wants to have it both ways.
snippet: Pence is still afraid of the former president, and he is not alone.

abstract: The Mar. 21, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kelsey Piper. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: How Big a Deal Is the Banking Mess?
abstract: A murky economic outlook just got even murkier.
lead_paragraph: I’m on vacation and trying to spend a few weeks not thinking about the usual stuff. But it turns out that I can’t stay completely out of the debate over the sudden wave of banking crises and their effect on the economic outlook.
snippet: A murky economic outlook just got even murkier.

headline: 20 Years On, I Don’t Regret Supporting the Iraq War
abstract: The rationale was wrong, and the execution was lousy. But getting rid of Saddam Hussein was the right call.
lead_paragraph: Of those who supported the U.S. invasion of Iraq 20 years ago — not just warmongering neocons like yours truly but also plenty of liberals, such as the current president of the United States — most have disavowed it.
snippet: The rationale was wrong, and the execution was lousy. But getting rid of Saddam Hussein was the right call.

headline: Our New Promethean Moment
abstract: I just saw magic, and it’s the future.
lead_paragraph: I had a most remarkable but unsettling experience last week. Craig Mundie, the former chief research and strategy officer for Microsoft, was giving me a demonstration of GPT-4, the most advanced version of the artificial intelligence chatbot ChatGPT, developed by OpenAI and launched in November. Craig was preparing to brief the board of my wife’s museum, Planet Word, of which he is a member, about the effect ChatGPT will have on words, language and innovation.
snippet: I just saw magic, and it’s the future.

headline: Today’s Woke Excesses Were Born in the ’60s
abstract: When rhetoric overtakes action in the fight for equality.
lead_paragraph: Various books I’ve been reading lately have me thinking about 1966. I have often said that the history of Black America could be divided between what happened before and after that year.
snippet: When rhetoric overtakes action in the fight for equality.

headline: The Politics of a Trump Indictment
abstract: It could hurt him at the polls and still be a very bad long-term idea.
lead_paragraph: If you intend to indict and try a former president of the United States, especially a former president of the United States whose career has benefited from the collapse of public trust in the neutrality of all our institutions, you had better have clear evidence, all-but-obvious guilt and loads of legal precedent behind your case.
snippet: It could hurt him at the polls and still be a very bad long-term idea.

headline: The Unsettling Truth About Trump’s First Great Victory
abstract: His electoral triumph in 2016 continues to confound election experts. But it’s hardly just an academic question.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s 2016 election victory continues to confound election experts. How could American voters put such a fractious figure into the White House?
snippet: His electoral triumph in 2016 continues to confound election experts. But it’s hardly just an academic question.

headline: Is Working From Home Really Working?
abstract: The attitude of many Americans toward their jobs appears to have changed during the long pandemic — and not for the better.
lead_paragraph: Quiet quitting. Working from home. The Great Resignation.
snippet: The attitude of many Americans toward their jobs appears to have changed during the long pandemic — and not for the better.

headline: NIMBYs Threaten a Plan to Build More Suburban Housing
abstract: Whether they like it or not, New York officials fighting to maintain exclusionary housing policies are on the wrong side of history.
lead_paragraph: In an insult to New Yorkers suffering from spiraling rents and home prices, both houses of New York’s Democratic-controlled Legislature rejected an ambitious set of proposals from Gov. Kathy Hochul last week that would begin to address the crisis in available housing.
snippet: Whether they like it or not, New York officials fighting to maintain exclusionary housing policies are on the wrong side of history.

headline: The U.S. Is Not an Indispensable Peacemaker
abstract: America needs to accept more peacemakers in the world.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when all roads to peace went through Washington. From the 1978 Camp David Accords between Israel and Egypt brokered by President Jimmy Carter to the 1993 Oslo Accords signed on the White House lawn to Senator George Mitchell’s Good Friday Agreement that ended the fighting in Northern Ireland in 1998, America was the indispensable nation for peacemaking. To Paul Nitze, a longtime diplomat and Washington insider, “making evident its qualifications as an honest broker” was central to America’s influence after the end of the Cold War.
snippet: America needs to accept more peacemakers in the world.

headline: Seven Ideas to Prevent the Next Bank Crisis
abstract: It’s time for some fresh thinking.
lead_paragraph: If there’s ever been a topic about which fresh thinking is sorely needed, it’s how to fix the banks so they stop doing what they’ve been doing lately. It’s worth casting the net wide to include even ideas that aren’t fully developed or that are politically unrealistic.
snippet: It’s time for some fresh thinking.

headline: Can’t Read? Here’s a ‘Barefoot College’ for You.
abstract: This is a campus that trains even illiterate people in job skills, while messing with people’s heads.
lead_paragraph: TILONIA, India — It’s the Harvard of rural India, minus wingtips or heels: a 50-year-old institution called Barefoot College that offers lessons for empowering people worldwide. Maybe even in America.
snippet: This is a campus that trains even illiterate people in job skills, while messing with people’s heads.

headline: Trump May Face Prosecution. America Faces a Test.
abstract: We are called to endure what I call the inconvenience of the necessary, a point at which something is morally right but the political timing is problematic.
lead_paragraph: Of course, Donald Trump went to social media to speculate that he’d be arrested on Tuesday of this week and — big surprise — that turned out not to be true.
snippet: We are called to endure what I call the inconvenience of the necessary, a point at which something is morally right but the political timing is problematic.

headline: Sex, Lies and … Trump. What More Can You Ask For?
abstract: Things are getting Stormy.
lead_paragraph: One thing we can be sure of: If this Stormy Daniels thing hurts Donald Trump politically, it will be for reasons having nothing whatsoever to do with sex.
snippet: Things are getting Stormy.

headline: Banks Can’t Be Trusted. A ‘Golden Share’ Might Help.
abstract: Saule Omarova, who was forced to withdraw her nomination as comptroller of the currency because she opposed loosening bank regulations, offers a creative solution to the banking mess.
lead_paragraph: I had the honor of being nominated by President Biden in 2021 to head the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the top regulator of federally chartered banks. If confirmed, I would have been the first minority woman — an immigrant — to lead the 160-year-old agency.
snippet: Saule Omarova, who was forced to withdraw her nomination as comptroller of the currency because she opposed loosening bank regulations, offers a creative solution to the banking mess.

headline: The Shameful Secret at the Heart of My War Reporting
abstract: I won awards covering Iraq, but my Iraqi colleague lost everything.
lead_paragraph: I first met Ali Hamdani in Baghdad in 2003, just months after the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq. He’d recently finished his medical school training, but instead of becoming a doctor, he started working with me and other foreign journalists. We covered the conflict together for years, and he was my guide as Iraq descended into all-out civil war. Ali saved my life on more than one occasion, at great personal risk to himself — and he’s become a dear friend.
snippet: I won awards covering Iraq, but my Iraqi colleague lost everything.

headline: Liberal Professors Can Rescue the G.O.P.
abstract: Professors have to do a better job of exposing students to a rich intellectual tradition that stretches back to Edmund Burke and Adam Smith.
lead_paragraph: When conservative undergraduates look around for mentors these days, who do they find? Not conservative professors, at least not very often. Our ranks have been slowly vanishing since the 1980s. Instead, those students find organizers from the MAGA-verse who teach them how to own the libs. That’s who is instructing the next generation of Republican leaders, modeling how to act and think like good conservatives. It’s a squalid education, one that deepens their alienation from the university and guarantees that the next generation of elected officials will make Ron DeSantis’s war against higher education look tame.
snippet: Professors have to do a better job of exposing students to a rich intellectual tradition that stretches back to Edmund Burke and Adam Smith.

headline: College Sports Are a Treasure. Don’t Turn Them Into the Minor Leagues.
abstract: The best way to support student-athletes is to ensure that they are students first.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — In a teary locker room this month, after the Notre Dame men’s basketball team ended its season with a close loss in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, the coach spoke not about lost opportunities on the court, but rather about the six master’s degrees (in addition to undergraduate degrees) that members of the team had earned, the lifelong friendships they had formed, and the invaluable lessons they had learned about leadership, teamwork and growing through adversity. The locker room is a classroom where the lesson that athletics can and should be part of a university’s educational mission is lived every day. Even Knute Rockne said that college athletics should be secondary to academics.
snippet: The best way to support student-athletes is to ensure that they are students first.

author.Original: By John I. Jenkins and Jack Swarbrick

headline: Women Are Still Stuck in ‘A Doll’s House’
abstract: It’s shocking that Ibsen’s 1879 play remains so shocking.
lead_paragraph: When Henrik Ibsen’s play “A Doll’s House” opened in 1879 at the Royal Theater in Copenhagen, it was an instant success — and an outrage to many. The story of Nora, a woman who walks out on her husband and three children, was considered scandalous in a country in which marriage was held as a sacred bond, and one that held women to exacting strictures.
snippet: It’s shocking that Ibsen’s 1879 play remains so shocking.

headline: Stop Treating Adolescent Girls as Emotionally Abnormal
abstract: Let’s approach adolescent mental health with concern, not panic.
lead_paragraph: In February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released a report titled the “Youth Risk Behavior Survey Data Summary & Trends Report: 2011-2021,” or Y.R.B.S. According to the C.D.C., “nearly 3 in 5 (57 percent) U.S. teen girls felt persistently sad or hopeless in 2021 — double that of boys” and “the highest level reported over the past decade.”
snippet: Let’s approach adolescent mental health with concern, not panic.

headline: Free Speech Doesn’t Mean Free Rein to Shout Down Others
abstract: When protests amount to mob censorship.
lead_paragraph: If you pay any attention to legal news at all, you’re familiar with the Stanford Law School shout-down. The story is simple and disturbing. The Federalist Society chapter at Stanford Law School invited Judge Kyle Duncan of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to speak on a fascinating and important topic (for legal nerds, anyway): How do lower courts decide cases on legal issues in which Supreme Court case law is unsettled or changing?
snippet: When protests amount to mob censorship.

headline: The Cold War With China Is Changing Everything
abstract: Both sides are spending lots of money on technological elites.
lead_paragraph: So I guess we’re in a new cold war. Leaders of both parties have become China hawks. There are rumblings of war over Taiwan. Xi Jinping vows to dominate the century.
snippet: Both sides are spending lots of money on technological elites.

headline: France Is Furious
abstract: The damage of the past weeks can’t be undone.
lead_paragraph: FOS-SUR-MER, France — “This government just does not listen to us,” said Renald, a 50-year-old electrical mechanic at the Port of Marseille, as his co-workers assembled a barricade this week on the route leading to a fuel depot. “There’s a deep anger here.”
snippet: The damage of the past weeks can’t be undone.

headline: A Radical Way of Thinking About Money
abstract: Morgan Ricks argues that stricter regulations on “private money” can help panic-proof our financial system.
lead_paragraph: It’s been two weeks since the Silicon Valley Bank run, and we’re still feeling the ripple effects — not just at banks like Signature, First Republic and Credit Suisse, which are definitely taking a beating. Across the industry, too, banks are on edge, and regulators are rushing to keep the system together.
snippet: Morgan Ricks argues that stricter regulations on “private money” can help panic-proof our financial system.

headline: The Man Who Leaked the Pentagon Papers Is Scared
abstract: The whistle-blower Daniel Ellsberg has never run out of secrets.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Ellsberg, famous for leaking the Pentagon Papers and his activism against nuclear weapons, announced recently that he has been diagnosed with terminal cancer.
snippet: The whistle-blower Daniel Ellsberg has never run out of secrets.

headline: There’s a Problem With Banning TikTok. It’s Called the First Amendment.
abstract: American users of the social media platform are indisputably exercising their constitutional rights when they post and consume content on the site.
lead_paragraph: The First Amendment has so far played only a bit part in the debate about banning TikTok. This may change. If the U.S. government tries to shut down this major communications platform, the First Amendment will certainly have something to say about it.
snippet: American users of the social media platform are indisputably exercising their constitutional rights when they post and consume content on the site.

headline: This Column Is Dedicated to Silicon Valley Venture Capitalists
abstract: The tech industry is far from perfect, but it remains essential to America’s future.
lead_paragraph: Bust out your tiniest violin, because I’m about to stand up for Silicon Valley venture capitalists. The industry is not nearly as insufferable and out of touch as some of its blustering online influencers might lead you to believe. And despite its recent troubles, the world continues to need places like Silicon Valley and its financiers of risky ideas.
snippet: The tech industry is far from perfect, but it remains essential to America’s future.

headline: Don’t Be Fooled. Ron DeSantis Is a Bush-Cheney Republican.
abstract: It is simply wrong to attribute the pathologies of today’s Republican Party to the influence of Donald Trump alone.
lead_paragraph: One of the strangest ads of the 2022 election cycle was an homage to “Top Gun,” featuring Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida. In it, DeSantis is the “Top Gov,” setting his sights on his political enemies: “Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is your governor speaking. Today’s training evolution: dogfighting, taking on the corporate media.”
snippet: It is simply wrong to attribute the pathologies of today’s Republican Party to the influence of Donald Trump alone.

headline: You Can Have the Blue Pill or the Red Pill, and We’re Out of Blue Pills
abstract: In games like chess, no human can hope to beat a computer. What happens when the same thing occurs in art, politics or religion?
lead_paragraph: Imagine that as you are boarding an airplane, half the engineers who built it tell you there is a 10 percent chance the plane will crash, killing you and everyone else on it. Would you still board?
snippet: In games like chess, no human can hope to beat a computer. What happens when the same thing occurs in art, politics or religion?

author.People: Harari Yuval, Harris Tristan, Raskin Aza

headline: How Far Will the Fed Have to Go to Tame Inflation?
abstract: The answer is partly in our heads.
lead_paragraph: Ordinary reality doesn’t change depending on whether you believe in it or not, as Neil deGrasse Tyson, the astrophysicist and science educator, likes to observe. But ordinary reality isn’t the world central bankers live in. They live in a world of self-fulfilling expectations. We saw that this week when Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, addressed reporters at a news conference on Wednesday.
snippet: The answer is partly in our heads.

headline: Was Iraq a Worse Disaster for America Than Vietnam?
abstract: Both wars reflected American hubris, but Iraq looks more like our empire’s nemesis.
lead_paragraph: At the 20th anniversary of the Iraq war, we stand in the same position relative to the initial invasion as America stood in 1985 relative to the 1965 arrival of our first combat troops in Vietnam. This makes it a useful moment to compare the two conflicts and their effects, and to consider — provisionally, always provisionally — which was more disastrous, which intervention deserves to be remembered as the worst foreign policy decision in our history.
snippet: Both wars reflected American hubris, but Iraq looks more like our empire’s nemesis.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Morgan Ricks
abstract: The Mar. 24, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Morgan Ricks. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The Mar. 24, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”

headline: Her Son Says She’s ‘the Greatest Mom Ever.’ We Should Know Her Story.
abstract: “After all her hard work, her sacrifices, we had to give her something,” her son explains.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — This is a story of human trafficking, but mostly it’s a story of a mother’s love, the adoring son she raised and the highest-return investment in the world today.
snippet: “After all her hard work, her sacrifices, we had to give her something,” her son explains.

headline: On ‘Succession,’ There’s One Thing Logan Roy Can’t Buy
abstract: Lots of TV shows are about trauma. This one examines what happens when trauma collides with power.
lead_paragraph: Most discussions around HBO’s enormously successful series “Succession,” which returns on Sunday after 15 months, focus on the show’s depiction of the ultrawealthy and the media. With good reason: The absurdly rich Roy family at the drama’s center controls a huge media empire, and its members squabble for control. This fourth and final season will likely determine which Roy will end up on top.
snippet: Lots of TV shows are about trauma. This one examines what happens when trauma collides with power.

headline: People Can’t Get Their A.D.H.D. Medicine, and That’s a Sign of a Larger Problem
abstract: The Drug Enforcement Administration is failing at its mission.
lead_paragraph: Since last August, America has been experiencing a severe shortage of Adderall and related stimulant medications used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. While the origin of the shortfall is contested, some blame rigid manufacturing quotas imposed by the Drug Enforcement Administration, which the agency hasn’t lifted despite increased diagnoses, insisting that the manufacturers have not used all of their existing allowances. The D.E.A. also has yet to provide a clear explanation of the shortage or to take emergency actions to help alleviate it.
snippet: The Drug Enforcement Administration is failing at its mission.

headline: Welcome to Muskville, Texas
abstract: Companies shouldn’t need to build worker housing. Workers shouldn’t have to live in company towns.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, who inhabits the role of a gonzo captain of industry like no other figure in modern American life, has lately been dreaming aloud about building his own version of an old-fashioned company town.
snippet: Companies shouldn’t need to build worker housing. Workers shouldn’t have to live in company towns.

headline: Whatever the Problem, It’s Probably Solved by Walking
abstract: A walk begins to carve out space between my thoughts that allows clarity to rise up through my shoes.
lead_paragraph: Walking is the worst-kept secret I know. Its rewards hide under every step.
snippet: A walk begins to carve out space between my thoughts that allows clarity to rise up through my shoes.

headline: I Am Haunted by What I Have Seen at Great Salt Lake
abstract: The Latter-day Saints church has the moral authority and political sway to save the Great Salt Lake.
lead_paragraph: From a distance, it is hard to tell whether the three figures walking the salt playa are human, bird or some other animal. Through binoculars, I see they are pelicans, juveniles, gaunt and emaciated without water or food. In feathered robes, they walk with the focus of fasting monks toward enlightenment or death.
snippet: The Latter-day Saints church has the moral authority and political sway to save the Great Salt Lake.
