headline: The Potential Trump Indictment Is Unwise
abstract: Why I’m skeptical of the Manhattan district attorney’s case.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in American history, a hotly anticipated indictment of a former American president may actually be handed up. Manhattan’s district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, seems set to bring charges related to Donald Trump’s allegedly paying off a porn star named Stormy Daniels to cover up their affair. There are, however, significant problems with the case.
snippet: Why I’m skeptical of the Manhattan district attorney’s case.

headline: When I Got Cancer, My Dreams Told Me What My Doctors Could Not
abstract: When all the rational decision-making options are bad, relying on dreams offers a different kind of logic that can be a lifesaver in its own way.
lead_paragraph: As soon as I woke up from the dream about two helicopters crashing onto a highway, I called my doctor’s office and asked for a mammogram.
snippet: When all the rational decision-making options are bad, relying on dreams offers a different kind of logic that can be a lifesaver in its own way.

headline: A.I. Can’t Write My Cat Story Because It Hasn’t Felt What I Feel
abstract: A.I. hasn’t suffered enough to write this essay.
lead_paragraph: For a few years, I’ve been trying to write a story about a cat. A.I. will not be able to write this, partly because the story is still inside my imagination and on a few rough pages that were originally drafted in Boston, on sheets of notebook paper, as I sat in my daughter’s apartment on a hot summer day.
snippet: A.I. hasn’t suffered enough to write this essay.

headline: How China Keeps Putting Off Its Lehman Moment
abstract: Chinese regulators have proved the financial doomsayers wrong again and again. But their biggest test may yet lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Remember the Evergrande crisis?
snippet: Chinese regulators have proved the financial doomsayers wrong again and again. But their biggest test may yet lie ahead.

headline: The Global Transformation of Christianity Is Here
abstract: The influx of nonwhite believers will challenge white religious conservatives to choose between xenophobia and building alliances with immigrants who share their views on social issues.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I went to a worship service that, in many ways, was like a thousand evangelical services I’d seen before. People raised their hands while singing and cried out “Glory to God!” and “Amen.” People stood and gave “testimony,” telling stories of finding hope or healing from pain. They read Bible verses and prayed prayers. There was a clear difference, however, from most worship services I’ve attended: Nearly everyone in the room was an immigrant and a person of color. We sang in English but also in Spanish, Portuguese, Igbo and Nepali.
snippet: The influx of nonwhite believers will challenge white religious conservatives to choose between xenophobia and building alliances with immigrants who share their views on social issues.

headline: We Have Cutting-Edge Science to Make Vaccines, but Will Everyone Benefit?
abstract: A vaccine scientist on what needs to change.
lead_paragraph: As a physician-scientist who has spent nearly 40 years studying viruses and immunity, I can speak to the scientific advances that made rapid Covid-19 vaccine development possible. I oversaw the work at the National Institutes of Health’s Vaccine Research Center that provided the basis for designing and evaluating the initial Covid-19 vaccines and antibodies.
snippet: A vaccine scientist on what needs to change.

headline: Trump’s Rally Was Just What I Expected. He’s Stuck in a Rut.
abstract: Trump is still fighting old battles. But Republicans have moved on to their own war, a new war, a culture war.
lead_paragraph: WACO, Texas — In the first big rally of his 2024 presidential campaign, Donald Trump didn’t dwell on the symbolism of speaking in Waco amid the 30th anniversary of the deadly siege there that still serves as a right-wing cri de coeur against federal authority.
snippet: Trump is still fighting old battles. But Republicans have moved on to their own war, a new war, a culture war.

headline: MAGA, Not Trump, Controls the Movement Now
abstract: It’s clear who runs today’s G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: The most telling exchange in Donald Trump’s Waco, Texas, rally on Saturday didn’t come from Trump himself. It came at the beginning, when the aging rock star Ted Nugent was warming up the crowd. “I want my money back,” he yelled. “I didn’t authorize any money to Ukraine, to some homosexual weirdo.”
snippet: It’s clear who runs today’s G.O.P.

headline: How ‘Build Your Own College Rankings’ Was Built
abstract: A guide to Times Opinion’s college ranking tool.
lead_paragraph: Times Opinion has built a tool that we hope will help students, parents and other readers think anew about the high-stress process of choosing the right college or university — and whether one “right” school ever really exists. This tool allows you to design your own college rankings: You tell us what matters to you and we’ll give you a list of schools that best matches your priorities.
snippet: A guide to Times Opinion’s college ranking tool.

headline: There’s Only One College Rankings List That Matters
abstract: My advice to the many anxious college applicants and their parents is to think about what you really want.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Within a few months of joining the faculty at Duke University in 2021, I could spot them: the high school seniors, juniors and even sophomores on their pilgrimages to our verdant and coveted wonderland, with its Gothic Revival spires, ecstatic basketball fans and acceptance rate of 6 percent.
snippet: My advice to the many anxious college applicants and their parents is to think about what you really want.

headline: The Slow-Motion Tidal Wave Consuming Our Economy
abstract: Economic models are failing us because they don’t reflect large forces that are starting to affect our economy: climate change, demographics, deglobalization and artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Our economy today has been described variously as “weird,” “really weird” and “very, very weird.”
snippet: Economic models are failing us because they don’t reflect large forces that are starting to affect our economy: climate change, demographics, deglobalization and artificial intelligence.

headline: Are We Actually Arguing About Whether 14-Year-Olds Should Work in Meatpacking Plants?
abstract: Rollbacks on child labor protections are happening amid a surge of child labor violations.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas signed a bill this month rolling back the state’s child labor protections, making it easier for employers to hire children under 16. Elsewhere, bills to allow 14- and 15-year-olds to work in meatpacking plants and other dangerous jobs in Iowa as part of training programs and 16- and 17-year-olds to take jobs at construction sites in Minnesota are under consideration.
snippet: Rollbacks on child labor protections are happening amid a surge of child labor violations.

headline: Trump Would Like a Word
abstract: Or maybe more than a word.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I have to admit that when the subject of Donald Trump comes up these days, I tend to start telling sex-scandal stories. My bad.
snippet: Or maybe more than a word.

author.Original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

headline: A.I. Is Being Built by People Who Think It Might Destroy Us
abstract: Silicon Valley’s futurists have gone from utopian to dystopian.
lead_paragraph: All of a sudden, it’s as if we’ve come face to face with a new species on our smartphone screens.
snippet: Silicon Valley’s futurists have gone from utopian to dystopian.

headline: Netanyahu Is Gambling With Israel’s Future
abstract: “The ax has not come down yet, but it’s still hanging.”
lead_paragraph: Karnit Flug was the governor of the Bank of Israel, the nation’s central bank, from 2013 to 2018. “One of my biggest challenges was the strengthening of the shekel,” she told me on Monday.
snippet: “The ax has not come down yet, but it’s still hanging.”

headline: Israel’s Crisis Has a Distinctly American Flavor
abstract: Israel has learned some unhealthy habits from the United States.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Hours before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu delayed a proposed judicial overhaul that has prompted mass protests, the head of one of Israel’s most powerful unions made a small, seemingly off-topic remark as he announced a nationwide strike Monday.
snippet: Israel has learned some unhealthy habits from the United States.

headline: Netanyahu Cannot Be Trusted
abstract: The Israeli prime minister has become an irrational actor.
lead_paragraph: Thank goodness that Israel’s civil society has forced Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to pause, for now, his attempt to impose his control over Israel’s independent judiciary and gain a free hand to rule as he wishes. But this whole affair has exposed a new and troubling reality for the United States: For the first time, the leader of Israel is an irrational actor, a danger not only to Israelis but also to important American interests and values.
snippet: The Israeli prime minister has become an irrational actor.

headline: Alexander Skarsgard Explains the Answer to Everything. (It Involves Doing Some Math.)
abstract: It’s time to completely rethink how we measure economic success.
lead_paragraph: Partha Dasgupta is a Cambridge University economist who in 2021 prepared a more than 600-page report for the British government about the financial value of nature.
snippet: It’s time to completely rethink how we measure economic success.

author.Original: By Nathan Grossman, Tom Mustill and Cecilia Nessen
author.People: Grossman Nathan, Mustill Tom, Nessen Cecilia

headline: I Am Going Blind, and I Now Find It Strangely Exhilarating
abstract: Now that I signal my disability with a white cane, I find that I have tapped a well of visible kindness.
lead_paragraph: I have been gradually going blind for the past 20 years. I didn’t pay attention — I thought I needed better glasses — until one night I popped out to go to the bathroom in a crowded movie theater. When I returned, the people and the seats had disappeared. I couldn’t see anything except the screen. I stood in the back of the theater until my partner, Laurie, came to find me. This was disconcerting, but I went about my business in my usual state of cheerful denial.
snippet: Now that I signal my disability with a white cane, I find that I have tapped a well of visible kindness.

headline: What the Republican Push for ‘Parents’ Rights’ Is Really About
abstract: The culture war that conservatives are currently waging over education is, like the culture wars in other areas of American society, a cover for a more material and ideological agenda.
lead_paragraph: You may have heard the phrase “parents’ rights.”
snippet: The culture war that conservatives are currently waging over education is, like the culture wars in other areas of American society, a cover for a more material and ideological agenda.

headline: Dr. Fauci Could Have Said a Lot More
abstract: If officials don’t trust the public, the public won’t trust them.
lead_paragraph: Covid had just reached American shores on Feb. 9, 2020, when Newt Gingrich invited Anthony Fauci, the longtime head of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and the British zoologist Peter Daszak onto his podcast, “Newt’s World.”
snippet: If officials don’t trust the public, the public won’t trust them.

headline: Trump’s Legal Jeopardy and America’s Political Crossroads
abstract: David French takes stock of the cases involving the ex-president and the challenges they present to the political system.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s legal troubles are mounting. A Manhattan grand jury investigation into the hush-money payment to Stormy Daniels could soon make Trump the first former American president ever to be criminally indicted.
snippet: David French takes stock of the cases involving the ex-president and the challenges they present to the political system.

headline: As a Doctor, I Know Being Ready to Die Is an Illusion
abstract: It is easier to search for readiness than to process what its absence means.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, near the end of my residency training, I sat opposite a patient, wondering whether he’d accepted that he was dying. He was in his 60s, an artist with sinewy arms and serene eyes, someone I’d come to know well over the past three years. Cancer had broken into his liver and bone marrow, robbing him of hunger and energy.
snippet: It is easier to search for readiness than to process what its absence means.

headline: We’re About to Find Out How Far the Supreme Court Will Go to Arm America
abstract: The Biden administration has asked the justices to overturn an appeals court decision on guns that can charitably be described as nuts.
lead_paragraph: How much further will the Supreme Court go to assist in the arming of America? That has been the question since last June, when the court ruled that New York’s century-old gun licensing law violated the Second Amendment. Sooner than expected, we are likely to find out the answer.
snippet: The Biden administration has asked the justices to overturn an appeals court decision on guns that can charitably be described as nuts.

subject: Gun Control
Decisions and Verdicts
Domestic Violence
Law and Legislation
Second Amendment (US Constitution)
Appeals Courts (US)
United States Politics and Government

headline: I Know How Nuclear War Is Waged, So I’m Calling for Peace With North Korea
abstract: Pursuing a long-overdue official end to the Korean War could be a game changer.
lead_paragraph: Not many people know how to wage nuclear war. I’m one of them.
snippet: Pursuing a long-overdue official end to the Korean War could be a game changer.

subject: Nuclear Weapons
Defense and Military Forces
Korean War
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

headline: How the Right Turned Radical and the Left Became Depressed
abstract: A new poll offers the outline of a unifying theory of right-wing recklessness and liberal anomie.
lead_paragraph: One of the notable dynamics of American life today is that conservatives report being personally happier than liberals but also seem more politically discontented. The political left has become more institutionalist, more invested in experts and establishments, even as progressive culture seems more shadowed by unhappiness and even mental illness. Meanwhile conservatives claim greater contentment in their private lives — and then go out and vote for paranoid outsiders and burn-it-down populists.
snippet: A new poll offers the outline of a unifying theory of right-wing recklessness and liberal anomie.

headline: Do You Live in a ‘Tight’ State or a ‘Loose’ One? Turns Out It Matters Quite a Bit.
abstract: What has happened to produce such intense hostility between left and right?
lead_paragraph: Political biases are omnipresent, but what we don’t fully understand yet is how they come about in the first place.
snippet: What has happened to produce such intense hostility between left and right?

headline: Will Ambitious Plans for a ‘New’ New York Get Crushed in Albany?
abstract: The State Legislature appears ready to block plans to significantly expand housing in the city and suburbs.
lead_paragraph: Since the pandemic began to wane, New York-watchers have stoked fears about an urban doom loop: Millennials like me — liberated from the chains of our desks — would abandon Midtown Manhattan and perhaps the city or state altogether in search of lower costs of living. The commercial tax base would be obliterated, leaving no funds to support essential services like the subway.
snippet: The State Legislature appears ready to block plans to significantly expand housing in the city and suburbs.

headline: Eastern Kentucky Needs Flood Relief, Not Another Federal Prison
abstract: Exploitation is not an economic development strategy.
lead_paragraph: Along the riverbanks of Eastern Kentucky, the redbud trees are just starting to bloom, their branches still lumbering under the weight of last summer’s catastrophic flood: Lawn chairs, trampolines, twisted gutters and school backpacks remain high in the treetops, each item a persistent and disorienting sign of how life here was turned upside down last July when shallow streams surged more than 18 feet in 10 hours in parts of the state, killing more than 40 people and leaving hundreds homeless. Yet while residents reach for the possibility of renewal, the largest regional investment being offered is a federal prison proposed for Letcher County, the heart of the flood zone.
snippet: Exploitation is not an economic development strategy.

author.Original: By Sylvia Ryerson and Judah Schept

headline: Money Is Up. Patriotism and Religion Are Down.
abstract: A new survey revealed a striking decline in traditional American values. What should we make of it?
snippet: A new survey revealed a striking decline in traditional American values. What should we make of it?

headline: In the Face of Tragedy, Petitioning God Is an Act of Faith
abstract: “We’re praying for you” has been ridiculed as an empty phrase. But it can be an incitement to action rather than an excuse for inaction.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The sun was still shining brightly when I pulled into the parking lot of Christ Presbyterian Church here on Tuesday. Traffic was backed up outside the church, and I was a few minutes late for the start of a prayer service for the victims of the Covenant School shooting that had occurred just a few miles up the road the day before. Christ Presbyterian is a sister church of Covenant Presbyterian Church, a member of the same evangelical denomination, the Presbyterian Church in America, P.C.A. for short.
snippet: “We’re praying for you” has been ridiculed as an empty phrase. But it can be an incitement to action rather than an excuse for inaction.

headline: Can India Change the World?
abstract: For most of history, it was one of the world’s leading economies, and it now has a fighting chance to recover that role.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Is India the world’s next tiger economy, poised to succeed a slowing China as a pillar of the global economy?
snippet: For most of history, it was one of the world’s leading economies, and it now has a fighting chance to recover that role.

headline: A Florida School Banned a Disney Movie About Ruby Bridges. Here’s What That Really Means.
abstract: The state’s crusading censors are choosing the comfort of ignorance over the inconvenience of truth.
lead_paragraph: This month, an elementary school in St. Petersburg, Fla., stopped showing a 1998 Disney movie about Ruby Bridges, the 6-year-old Black girl who integrated a public elementary school in New Orleans in 1960, because of a complaint lodged by a single parent who said she feared the film might teach children that white people hate Black people.
snippet: The state’s crusading censors are choosing the comfort of ignorance over the inconvenience of truth.

headline: Affirmative Action Is in Peril and ‘Model Minority’ Stories Don’t Help
abstract: Asian Americans are being exploited by white activists with an agenda.
lead_paragraph: Michael Wang was an ideal college applicant. He had a 4.67 G.P.A., a product of excelling in the more than a dozen A.P. classes that he’d taken. He was also on the debate team, played piano and sang in the choir for President Barack Obama’s inauguration in 2008.
snippet: Asian Americans are being exploited by white activists with an agenda.

headline: What Would It Take for One Party to Dominate America Again?
abstract: Even without a financial debacle or outbreak of civil conflict, there may be ways for a party to achieve at least short periods of dominance.
lead_paragraph: Not since Joe Biden first claimed his desk in the Senate half a century ago have either Republicans or Democrats governed the nation through more than one or two election cycles. The score in the past dozen presidential contests is a flat-out tie — six to six. Control of one or both houses of Congress has ping-ponged back and forth since the 1980s as well.
snippet: Even without a financial debacle or outbreak of civil conflict, there may be ways for a party to achieve at least short periods of dominance.

headline: Do We Really Need to Have a Cold War With China?
abstract: A Cold War mentality toward China degrades the freedoms and cultural confidence that make America great.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — I wore red underpants for much of last year.
snippet: A Cold War mentality toward China degrades the freedoms and cultural confidence that make America great.

headline: The Most Profound Loss on Campus Isn’t Free Speech. It’s Listening.
abstract: It isn’t enough to challenge someone unless you’re willing to be challenged back.
lead_paragraph: On April 8, 1991, when I was a sophomore at Brown University, Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia came to campus to speak. Conservatives allegedly existed at Brown, but the school was as true to its left-leaning reputation then as it is now. This was where Amy Carter, the daughter of the former president, got in trouble for protesting apartheid, where a longhaired John F. Kennedy Jr. was also an anti-apartheid activist, where the most popular campus newspaper comic strip featured a character named P.C. Person.
snippet: It isn’t enough to challenge someone unless you’re willing to be challenged back.

headline: San Quentin Could Be the Future of Prisons in America
abstract: Governor Newsom’s plans to re-engineer San Quentin could change how tens of thousands of Californians transition out of prison each year.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to measure the disaster that is America’s prison system: the sheer, monstrous size of the captive population, the wildly disproportionate confinement of Black and brown prisoners, the recidivism rate, the prevalence of sexual assault, suicide and mental illness rates.
snippet: Governor Newsom’s plans to re-engineer San Quentin could change how tens of thousands of Californians transition out of prison each year.

headline: This Election Could Be the Beginning of the End of Scott Walker’s Legacy in Wisconsin
abstract: A state Supreme Court contest could break the right’s lock on the state. Abortion, representation and election integrity are all on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, as tens of thousands of left-leaning demonstrators occupied the Wisconsin state capitol to protest a new bill gutting public employee unions, a prank caller posing as the right-wing billionaire David Koch got the Wisconsin governor, Scott Walker, on the phone. Just two years after Barack Obama won Wisconsin by 14 points, Walker had been swept into office by the Tea Party wave. He saw the anti-union law, Act 10, as his chance to follow in the footsteps of his idol, Ronald Reagan, who’d fired over 11,000 striking air traffic controllers in 1981, a devastating blow to the labor movement. Republican governors nationwide, Walker boasted, would follow his lead. “This is our moment,” he told the man he thought was Koch.
snippet: A state Supreme Court contest could break the right’s lock on the state. Abortion, representation and election integrity are all on the ballot.

author.Original: By Michelle Goldberg and Madeleine Hordinski

headline: How Did No-Mandate Sweden End Up With Such an Average Pandemic?
abstract: Reconsidering the country’s libertarian Covid response.
lead_paragraph: If you know one thing about Sweden’s pandemic, it is almost certainly that the country followed a radical, contrarian public health path. Its hands-off approach to Covid-19 mitigation — no stay-at-home orders to begin with, and no mask mandates later on — was one that many on the pandemic left quickly derided as sadistic public policy and many on the pandemic right praised as enlightened.
snippet: Reconsidering the country’s libertarian Covid response.

headline: I Worry About a Failed Prosecution of Trump, but I Worry More About No Prosecution
abstract: There are legitimate concerns about this indictment, but how could we give the boss a pass after convicting his fixer?
lead_paragraph: In 1872, President Ulysses S. Grant was arrested by a police officer for speeding in his horse-drawn coach in Washington. The officer stuck out his hand to signal a stop, and Grant obeyed and then accompanied the officer to the police station.
snippet: There are legitimate concerns about this indictment, but how could we give the boss a pass after convicting his fixer?

headline: The Necessity of Patriotism (Even in Times Like These)
abstract: America is rebounding, but will cynicism stop the renewal?
lead_paragraph: Dear Zoomers,
snippet: America is rebounding, but will cynicism stop the renewal?

headline: Why Do Russians Still Want to Fight?
abstract: The war in Ukraine may be a horror, but it’s also an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: From the perspective of a Russian soldier, the war in Ukraine must look nightmarish. In over a year of combat, nearly 200,000 Russian troops have been killed or wounded, according to American officials, in a military operation that has proved both incompetent and ill equipped. Morale is reportedly low and complaints common. And yet a significant number of Russian men are still keen to fight — more, in fact, than at the war’s outset. What explains the disconnect?
snippet: The war in Ukraine may be a horror, but it’s also an opportunity.

author.Original: By Marlene Laruelle and Ivan Grek

headline: The Solution to Israel’s Crisis Might Be in America’s Constitution
abstract: It might learn from the American experience that a crisis can open unexpected vistas for the Jewish state.
lead_paragraph: The political crisis engulfing Israel has raised profound and fundamental questions about the roots of democratic legitimacy. Now that the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has blinked, and a vote on its proposed transformation of the judiciary has been delayed, Israelis might just have a chance to consider those broader questions and negotiate toward some long-needed political reforms. As they contemplate such prospects, they should consider the experience of America’s Constitution makers.
snippet: It might learn from the American experience that a crisis can open unexpected vistas for the Jewish state.

headline: There Is No Point in Hiding That We Threw Parades for War Criminals
abstract: Ticker-tape parades are an honor that we bestow as a people, and to edit the record of them is to blot out our own mistakes.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan borough president, Mark Levine, recently demanded that the names of Philippe Pétain and Pierre Laval, notorious for leading the French collaborationist government in World War II, be removed from the stretch of Lower Broadway where they were recognized with ticker-tape parades over 90 years ago.
snippet: Ticker-tape parades are an honor that we bestow as a people, and to edit the record of them is to blot out our own mistakes.

headline: The Republican Party Says It Wants to ‘Protect Children,’ but Not All Children
abstract: When Tucker Carlson, Christopher Rufo and Moms for Liberty say jump, the only question is: “How High?”
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the things the Republican Party is prepared to do to protect children.
snippet: When Tucker Carlson, Christopher Rufo and Moms for Liberty say jump, the only question is: “How High?”

headline: Don’t Sacrifice Good Jobs to Tame Inflation
abstract: When the Federal Reserve uses interest rate hikes as a blunt tool, American workers are the inevitable casualty.
lead_paragraph: Despite the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and the shock waves it sent through the banking sector — due, in part, to the bank’s risky exposure to higher interest rates — the Federal Reserve raised interest rates again, the ninth increase in the past year. Jerome Powell, the chairman of the Fed, has made one thing crystal clear: He is not going to let up on his war on inflation. American workers are the inevitable casualty.
snippet: When the Federal Reserve uses interest rate hikes as a blunt tool, American workers are the inevitable casualty.

headline: Don’t Ban TikTok. Fix Internet Privacy.
abstract: Blocking the popular app isn’t the solution.
lead_paragraph: There’s been an average of more than one school shooting per week in the United States so far in 2023, so it’s great to see lawmakers from both parties finally reaching consensus on how to protect America’s children: Ban TikTok.
snippet: Blocking the popular app isn’t the solution.
